<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Mahatma Gandhi</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>

<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Indian nationalist leader and nonviolence advocate (1869–1948)</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Gandhi" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Gandhi_(disambiguation)" title="Gandhi (disambiguation)">Gandhi (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

<p><b>Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ɡ/: 'g' in 'guy'">ɡ</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'d' in 'dye'">d</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ɡ/: 'g' in 'guy'">ɡ</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'d' in 'dye'">d</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span></span>/</a></span></span>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling">GAHN-dee</i></a>; 2 October 1869 – 30 January 1948) was an Indian lawyer,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-colonial_nationalism" title="Anti-colonial nationalism">anti-colonial nationalist</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GangulyDocker20082_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-GangulyDocker20082-5">[5]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Political_ethics" title="Political ethics">political ethicist</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parel20162_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-Parel20162-6">[6]</a></sup> who employed <a href="/wiki/Nonviolent_resistance" title="Nonviolent resistance">nonviolent resistance</a> to lead the successful <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">campaign for India's independence</a> from <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British rule</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stein20102_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-Stein20102-7">[7]</a></sup> and to later inspire movements for <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights_movements" title="Civil rights movements">civil rights</a> and freedom across the world. The honorific <b><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81tm%C4%81" title="Mahātmā">Mahātmā</a></b> (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: "great-souled", "venerable"), first applied to him in 1914 in <a href="/wiki/Union_of_South_Africa" title="Union of South Africa">South Africa</a>, is now used throughout the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McGregor19932_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-McGregor19932-8">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rajmohan_gandhi_p1722_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-rajmohan_gandhi_p1722-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>Born and raised in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> family in coastal <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>, Gandhi trained in the law at the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Temple" title="Inner Temple">Inner Temple</a>, London, and was <a href="/wiki/Call_to_the_bar" title="Call to the bar">called to the bar</a> at age 22 in June 1891. After two uncertain years in India, where he was unable to start a successful law practice, he moved to South Africa in 1893 to represent an Indian merchant in a lawsuit. He went on to live in South Africa for 21 years. It was here that Gandhi raised a family and first employed nonviolent resistance in a campaign for civil rights. In 1915, aged 45, he returned to India and soon set about organising peasants, farmers, and urban labourers to protest against excessive land-tax and discrimination.
</p><p>Assuming leadership of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a> in 1921, Gandhi led nationwide campaigns for easing poverty, expanding women's rights, building religious and ethnic amity, ending <a href="/wiki/Untouchability" title="Untouchability">untouchability</a>, and, above all, achieving <i><a href="/wiki/Swaraj" title="Swaraj">swaraj</a></i> or self-rule. Gandhi adopted the short <i><a href="/wiki/Dhoti" title="Dhoti">dhoti</a></i> woven with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charkha_(spinning_wheel)" title="Charkha (spinning wheel)">hand-spun</a> yarn as a mark of identification with India's rural poor. He began to live in a <a href="/wiki/Sabarmati_Ashram" title="Sabarmati Ashram">self-sufficient residential community</a>, to eat simple food, and undertake <a href="/wiki/List_of_fasts_undertaken_by_Mahatma_Gandhi" title="List of fasts undertaken by Mahatma Gandhi">long fasts</a> as a means of both introspection and political protest. Bringing anti-colonial nationalism to the common Indians, Gandhi led them in challenging the British-imposed salt tax with the 400 km (250 mi) <a href="/wiki/Salt_March" title="Salt March">Dandi Salt March</a> in 1930 and in calling for the British to <a href="/wiki/Quit_India_Movement" title="Quit India Movement">quit India</a> in 1942. He was imprisoned many times and for many years in both South Africa and India.
</p><p>Gandhi's vision of an independent India based on <a href="/wiki/Religious_pluralism" title="Religious pluralism">religious pluralism</a> was challenged in the early 1940s by a Muslim nationalism which demanded a separate homeland for Muslims within <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_India" title="British India">British India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Khan2007-page1_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-Khan2007-page1-10">[10]</a></sup> In August 1947, Britain granted independence, but the British Indian Empire<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Khan2007-page1_10-1"><a href="#cite_note-Khan2007-page1-10">[10]</a></sup> was <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partitioned</a> into two <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">dominions</a>, a Hindu-majority <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_India" title="Dominion of India">India</a> and a Muslim-majority <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Pakistan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-11">[11]</a></sup> As many displaced Hindus, Muslims, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sikh" title="Sikh">Sikhs</a> made their way to their new lands, religious violence broke out, especially in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punjab_region" title="Punjab region">Punjab</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a>. Abstaining from the <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(India)" title="Independence Day (India)">official celebration of independence</a>, Gandhi visited the affected areas, attempting to alleviate distress. In the months following, he undertook several <a href="/wiki/Hunger_strike" title="Hunger strike">hunger strikes</a> to stop the religious violence. The last of these, begun in Delhi on 12 January 1948 when he was 78,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown1991-p380_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-p380-12">[12]</a></sup> also had the indirect goal of pressuring India to pay out some cash assets owed to Pakistan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown1991-p380_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-p380-12">[12]</a></sup> Although the Government of India relented, as did the religious rioters, the belief that Gandhi had been too resolute in his defence of both Pakistan and Indian Muslims, especially those besieged in Delhi, spread among some Hindus in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-talbot-singh-delhi_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-talbot-singh-delhi-13">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown1991-p380_12-2"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-p380-12">[12]</a></sup> Among these was <a href="/wiki/Nathuram_Godse" title="Nathuram Godse">Nathuram Godse</a>, a militant <a href="/wiki/Hindu_nationalism" title="Hindu nationalism">Hindu nationalist</a> from western India, who <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Assassination of Mahatma Gandhi">assassinated Gandhi</a> by firing three bullets into his chest at an interfaith prayer meeting in Delhi on 30 January 1948.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CushRobinson2008_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-CushRobinson2008-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's birthday, 2 October, is commemorated in India as <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Jayanti" title="Gandhi Jayanti">Gandhi Jayanti</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_India" title="Public holidays in India">national holiday</a>, and worldwide as the <a href="/wiki/International_Day_of_Non-Violence" title="International Day of Non-Violence">International Day of Nonviolence</a>. Gandhi is commonly, though not formally, considered the <a href="/wiki/Father_of_the_Nation" title="Father of the Nation">Father of the Nation</a> in India<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive.indianexpress.com_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-archive.indianexpress.com-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-timesofindia.indiatimes.com_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-timesofindia.indiatimes.com-16">[16]</a></sup> and was commonly called <b>Bapu</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nehru_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nehru-17">[17]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>: endearment for <i>father</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McAllister1982_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-McAllister1982-18">[18]</a></sup> <i>papa</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McAllister1982_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-McAllister1982-18">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eck2003_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-Eck2003-19">[19]</a></sup>).
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_background">Early life and background</span></h3>
<p>Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi_name_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi_name-20">[20]</a></sup> was born on 2 October 1869<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi_DOB_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi_DOB-21">[21]</a></sup> into a <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_people" title="Gujarati people">Gujarati</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> <a href="/wiki/Modh" title="Modh">Modh</a> <a href="/wiki/Bania_(caste)" title="Bania (caste)">Bania</a> family<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/Porbandar" title="Porbandar">Porbandar</a> (also known as <i>Sudamapuri</i>), a coastal town on the <a href="/wiki/Kathiawar" title="Kathiawar">Kathiawar</a> Peninsula and then part of the small <a href="/wiki/Princely_state" title="Princely state">princely state</a> of <a href="/wiki/Porbandar_State" title="Porbandar State">Porbandar</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Kathiawar_Agency" title="Kathiawar Agency">Kathiawar Agency</a> of the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>. His father, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karamchand_Uttamchand_Gandhi" title="Karamchand Uttamchand Gandhi">Karamchand Uttamchand Gandhi</a> (1822–1885), served as the <i><a href="/wiki/Dewan" title="Dewan">dewan</a></i> (chief minister) of Porbandar state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GangulyDocker2008_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-GangulyDocker2008-25">[25]</a></sup> His family originated from the then village of <a href="/wiki/Kutiyana" title="Kutiyana">Kutiana</a> in what was then <a href="/wiki/Junagadh_State" title="Junagadh State">Junagadh State</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi_before_India_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi_before_India-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although he only had an elementary education and had previously been a clerk in the state administration, Karamchand proved a capable chief minister.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GuhaPP19to21_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-GuhaPP19to21-27">[27]</a></sup> During his tenure, Karamchand married four times. His first two wives died young, after each had given birth to a daughter, and his third marriage was childless. In 1857, Karamchand sought his third wife's permission to remarry; that year, he married Putlibai (1844–1891), who also came from Junagadh,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GuhaPP19to21_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-GuhaPP19to21-27">[27]</a></sup> and was from a <a href="/wiki/Pranami" title="Pranami">Pranami</a> <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnava</a> family.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Karamchand and Putlibai had three children over the ensuing decade: a son, Laxmidas (c. 1860–1914); a daughter, Raliatbehn (1862–1960); and another son, Karsandas (c. 1866–1913).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 2 October 1869, Putlibai gave birth to her last child, Mohandas, in a dark, windowless ground-floor room of the Gandhi family residence in Porbandar city. As a child, Gandhi was described by his sister Raliat as "restless as mercury, either playing or roaming about. One of his favourite pastimes was twisting dogs' ears."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> The Indian classics, especially the stories of <a href="/wiki/Shravan#In_Hindu_epics" title="Shravan">Shravana</a> and king <a href="/wiki/Harishchandra" title="Harishchandra">Harishchandra</a>, had a great impact on Gandhi in his childhood. In his autobiography, he admits that they left an indelible impression on his mind. He writes: "It haunted me and I must have acted Harishchandra to myself times without number." Gandhi's early self-identification with truth and love as supreme values is traceable to these epic characters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sorokin2002_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sorokin2002-32">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RudolphRudolph1983_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-RudolphRudolph1983-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>The family's religious background was eclectic. Gandhi's father Karamchand was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> and his mother Putlibai was from a Pranami <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vaishnava" title="Vaishnava">Vaishnava</a> Hindu family.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sharma11_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-sharma11-35">[35]</a></sup> Gandhi's father was of Modh Baniya caste in the <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">varna</a> of <a href="/wiki/Vaishya" title="Vaishya">Vaishya</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> His mother came from the medieval <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Krishna</a> bhakti-based <a href="/wiki/Pranami" title="Pranami">Pranami</a> tradition, whose religious texts include the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavata_Purana" title="Bhagavata Purana">Bhagavata Purana</a></i>, and a collection of 14 texts with teachings that the tradition believes to include the essence of the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> and the Bible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sharma11_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-sharma11-35">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> Gandhi was deeply influenced by his mother, an extremely pious lady who "would not think of taking her meals without her daily prayers... she would take the hardest vows and keep them without flinching. To keep two or three consecutive fasts was nothing to her."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1874, Gandhi's father Karamchand left Porbandar for the smaller state of <a href="/wiki/Rajkot" title="Rajkot">Rajkot</a>, where he became a counsellor to its ruler, the Thakur Sahib; though Rajkot was a less prestigious state than Porbandar, the British regional political agency was located there, which gave the state's <i>diwan</i> a measure of security.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> In 1876, Karamchand became <i>diwan</i> of Rajkot and was succeeded as <i>diwan</i> of Porbandar by his brother Tulsidas. His family then rejoined him in Rajkot.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_and_Laxmidas_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1052" data-file-width="786" decoding="async" height="254" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Gandhi_and_Laxmidas_2.jpg/190px-Gandhi_and_Laxmidas_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Gandhi_and_Laxmidas_2.jpg/285px-Gandhi_and_Laxmidas_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Gandhi_and_Laxmidas_2.jpg/380px-Gandhi_and_Laxmidas_2.jpg 2x" width="190"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_and_Laxmidas_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi (right) with his eldest brother Laxmidas in 1886<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fischer1982p96_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fischer1982p96-41">[41]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>At age 9, Gandhi entered the local school in <a href="/wiki/Rajkot" title="Rajkot">Rajkot</a>, near his home. There he studied the rudiments of arithmetic, history, the Gujarati language and geography.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-40">[40]</a></sup> At age 11, he joined the High School in Rajkot, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_High_School_(Rajkot)" title="Alfred High School (Rajkot)">Alfred High School</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-42">[42]</a></sup> He was an average student, won some prizes, but was a shy and tongue tied student, with no interest in games; his only companions were books and school lessons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 1883, the 13-year-old Mohandas was married to 14-year-old <a href="/wiki/Kasturba_Gandhi" title="Kasturba Gandhi">Kasturbai Makhanji Kapadia</a> (her first name was usually shortened to "Kasturba", and affectionately to "Ba") in an <a href="/wiki/Arranged_marriage" title="Arranged marriage">arranged marriage</a>, according to the custom of the region at that time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mohanty2011_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mohanty2011-44">[44]</a></sup> In the process, he lost a year at school but was later allowed to make up by accelerating his studies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Childhood_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-Childhood-45">[45]</a></sup> His wedding was a joint event, where his brother and cousin were also married. Recalling the day of their marriage, he once said, "As we didn't know much about marriage, for us it meant only wearing new clothes, eating sweets and playing with relatives." As was prevailing tradition, the adolescent bride was to spend much time at her parents' house, and away from her husband.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Husband_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-Husband-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>Writing many years later, Mohandas described with regret the lustful feelings he felt for his young bride, "even at school I used to think of her, and the thought of nightfall and our subsequent meeting was ever haunting me." He later recalled feeling jealous and possessive of her, such as when she would visit a temple with her girlfriends, and being sexually lustful in his feelings for her.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>In late 1885, Gandhi's father Karamchand died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-48">[48]</a></sup> Gandhi, then 16 years old, and his wife of age 17 had their first baby, who survived only a few days. The two deaths anguished Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_48-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-48">[48]</a></sup> The Gandhi couple had four more children, all sons: <a href="/wiki/Harilal_Gandhi" title="Harilal Gandhi">Harilal</a>, born in 1888; <a href="/wiki/Manilal_Gandhi" title="Manilal Gandhi">Manilal</a>, born in 1892; <a href="/wiki/Ramdas_Gandhi" title="Ramdas Gandhi">Ramdas</a>, born in 1897; and <a href="/wiki/Devdas_Gandhi" title="Devdas Gandhi">Devdas</a>, born in 1900.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mohanty2011_44-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mohanty2011-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 1887, the 18-year-old Gandhi graduated from high school in <a href="/wiki/Ahmedabad" title="Ahmedabad">Ahmedabad</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> In January 1888, he enrolled at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samaldas_College" title="Samaldas College">Samaldas College</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bhavnagar_State" title="Bhavnagar State">Bhavnagar State</a>, then the sole degree-granting institution of higher education in the region. But he dropped out and returned to his family in Porbandar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated32_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated32-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Three_years_in_London">Three years in London</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Student_of_law">Student of law</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MAHATMA_GANDHI_1869-1948_lived_here_as_a_law_student.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MAHATMA_GANDHI_1869-1948_lived_here_as_a_law_student.jpg/170px-MAHATMA_GANDHI_1869-1948_lived_here_as_a_law_student.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MAHATMA_GANDHI_1869-1948_lived_here_as_a_law_student.jpg/255px-MAHATMA_GANDHI_1869-1948_lived_here_as_a_law_student.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MAHATMA_GANDHI_1869-1948_lived_here_as_a_law_student.jpg/340px-MAHATMA_GANDHI_1869-1948_lived_here_as_a_law_student.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MAHATMA_GANDHI_1869-1948_lived_here_as_a_law_student.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Commemorative plaque at 20 Baron's Court Road, Barons Court, London</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi had dropped out of the cheapest college he could afford in Bombay.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Preparation_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-Preparation-51">[51]</a></sup> Mavji Dave Joshiji, a <a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmin</a> priest and family friend, advised Gandhi and his family that he should consider law studies in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> In July 1888, his wife Kasturba gave birth to their first surviving son, Harilal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated33_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated33-53">[53]</a></sup> His mother was not comfortable about Gandhi leaving his wife and family, and going so far from home. Gandhi's uncle Tulsidas also tried to dissuade his nephew. Gandhi wanted to go. To persuade his wife and mother, Gandhi made a vow in front of his mother that he would abstain from meat, alcohol and women. Gandhi's brother Laxmidas, who was already a lawyer, cheered Gandhi's London studies plan and offered to support him. Putlibai gave Gandhi her permission and blessing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated32_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated32-50">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi2006a_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi2006a-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_student.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="486" data-file-width="368" decoding="async" height="238" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Gandhi_student.jpg/180px-Gandhi_student.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Gandhi_student.jpg/270px-Gandhi_student.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Gandhi_student.jpg/360px-Gandhi_student.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_student.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi in London as a law student</div></div></div>
<p>On 10 August 1888, Gandhi aged 18, left Porbandar for Mumbai, then known as Bombay. Upon arrival, he stayed with the local Modh Bania community whose elders warned him that England would tempt him to compromise his religion, and eat and drink in Western ways. Despite Gandhi informing them of his promise to his mother and her blessings, he was excommunicated from his caste. Gandhi ignored this, and on 4 September, he sailed from Bombay to London, with his brother seeing him off.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated33_53-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated33-53">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Gandhi attended <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_College,_London" title="University College, London">University College, London</a>, a constituent college of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_London" title="University of London">University of London</a>.
</p><p>At UCL, he studied law and <a href="/wiki/Jurisprudence" title="Jurisprudence">jurisprudence</a> and was invited to enrol at <a href="/wiki/Inner_Temple" title="Inner Temple">Inner Temple</a> with the intention of becoming a <a href="/wiki/Barrister" title="Barrister">barrister</a>. His childhood shyness and self-withdrawal had continued through his teens. He retained these traits when he arrived in London, but joined a public speaking practice group and overcame his shyness sufficiently to practise law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p>He demonstrated a keen interest in the welfare of London’s impoverished dockland communities. In 1889, a <a href="/wiki/London_dock_strike,_1889" title="London dock strike, 1889">bitter trade dispute</a> broke out in London, with dockers striking for better pay and conditions, and seamen, shipbuilders, factory girls and other joining the strike in solidarity. The strikers were successful, in part due to the mediation of <a href="/wiki/Henry_Edward_Manning" title="Henry Edward Manning">Cardinal Manning</a>, leading Gandhi and an Indian friend to make a point of visiting the cardinal and thanking him for his work.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vegetarianism_and_committee_work">Vegetarianism and committee work</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi's time in London was influenced by the vow he had made to his mother. He tried to adopt "English" customs, including taking dancing lessons. However, he did not appreciate the bland vegetarian food offered by his landlady and was frequently hungry until he found one of London's few vegetarian restaurants. Influenced by <a href="/wiki/Henry_Stephens_Salt" title="Henry Stephens Salt">Henry Salt's</a> writing, he joined the <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian_Society" title="Vegetarian Society">London Vegetarian Society</a> and was elected to its executive committee<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown1991_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-58">[58]</a></sup> under the aegis of its president and benefactor <a href="/wiki/Arnold_Hills" title="Arnold Hills">Arnold Hills</a>. An achievement while on the committee was the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/Bayswater" title="Bayswater">Bayswater</a> chapter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-59">[59]</a></sup> Some of the vegetarians he met were members of the <a href="/wiki/Theosophical_Society" title="Theosophical Society">Theosophical Society</a>, which had been founded in 1875 to further universal brotherhood, and which was devoted to the study of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> literature. They encouraged Gandhi to join them in reading the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a></i> both in translation as well as in the original.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown1991_58-1"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi had a friendly and productive relationship with Hills, but the two men took a different view on the continued LVS membership of fellow committee member <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Allinson" title="Thomas Allinson">Thomas Allinson</a>. Their disagreement is the first known example of Gandhi challenging authority, despite his shyness and temperamental disinclination towards confrontation.
</p><p>Allinson had been promoting <a href="/wiki/Birth_control#Birth_control_movement" title="Birth control">newly available birth control methods</a>, but Hills disapproved of these, believing they undermined public morality. He believed <a href="/wiki/History_of_vegetarianism#19th_century" title="History of vegetarianism">vegetarianism to be a moral movement</a> and that Allinson should therefore no longer remain a member of the LVS. Gandhi shared Hills' views on the dangers of birth control, but defended Allinson's right to differ.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shyness_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-shyness-60">[60]</a></sup> It would have been hard for Gandhi to challenge Hills; Hills was 12 years his senior and unlike Gandhi, highly eloquent. He bankrolled the LVS and was a <a href="/wiki/Captain_of_industry" title="Captain of industry">captain of industry</a> with his <a href="/wiki/Thames_Ironworks_and_Shipbuilding_Company" title="Thames Ironworks and Shipbuilding Company">Thames Ironworks</a> company employing more than 6,000 people in the <a href="/wiki/East_End_of_London" title="East End of London">East End of London</a>. He was also a highly accomplished sportsman who later founded the football club <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Ham_United" title="West Ham United">West Ham United</a>. In his 1927 <i>An Autobiography, Vol. I</i>, Gandhi wrote:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p> The question deeply interested me...I had a high regard for Mr. Hills and his generosity. But I thought it was quite improper to exclude a man from a vegetarian society simply because he refused to regard puritan morals as one of the objects of the society<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shyness_60-1"><a href="#cite_note-shyness-60">[60]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>A motion to remove Allinson was raised, and was debated and voted on by the committee. Gandhi's shyness was an obstacle to his defence of Allinson at the committee meeting. He wrote his views down on paper but shyness prevented him from reading out his arguments, so Hills, the President, asked another committee member to read them out for him. Although some other members of the committee agreed with Gandhi, the vote was lost and Allinson excluded. There were no hard feelings, with Hills proposing the toast at the LVS farewell dinner in honour of Gandhi's return to India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Called_to_the_bar">Called to the bar</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi, at age 22, was <a href="/wiki/Call_to_the_bar" title="Call to the bar">called to the bar</a> in June 1891 and then left London for India, where he learned that his mother had died while he was in London and that his family had kept the news from him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown1991_58-2"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-58">[58]</a></sup> His attempts at establishing a law practice in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bombay" title="Bombay">Bombay</a> failed because he was psychologically unable to <a href="/wiki/Cross-examination" title="Cross-examination">cross-examine</a> witnesses. He returned to Rajkot to make a modest living drafting petitions for litigants, but he was forced to stop when he ran afoul of a British officer Sam Sunny.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown1991_58-3"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1893, a Muslim merchant in Kathiawar named Dada Abdullah contacted Gandhi. Abdullah owned a large successful shipping business in South Africa. His distant cousin in Johannesburg needed a lawyer, and they preferred someone with Kathiawari heritage. Gandhi inquired about his pay for the work. They offered a total salary of £105 (~$17,200 in 2019 money) plus travel expenses. He accepted it, knowing that it would be at least a one-year commitment in the <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_Natal" title="Colony of Natal">Colony of Natal</a>, South Africa, also a part of the British Empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_59-2"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman_2008_pp._82_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herman_2008_pp._82-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Civil_rights_activist_in_South_Africa_.281893.E2.80.931914.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_rights_activist_in_South_Africa_(1893–1914)">Civil rights activist in South Africa (1893–1914)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Jee%27s_Statue.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Gandhi_Jee%27s_Statue.jpg/220px-Gandhi_Jee%27s_Statue.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Gandhi_Jee%27s_Statue.jpg/330px-Gandhi_Jee%27s_Statue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Gandhi_Jee%27s_Statue.jpg/440px-Gandhi_Jee%27s_Statue.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Jee%27s_Statue.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bronze statue of Gandhi commemorating the centenary of the incident at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pietermaritzburg_Railway_Station" title="Pietermaritzburg Railway Station">Pietermaritzburg Railway Station</a>, unveiled by Archbishop <a href="/wiki/Desmond_Tutu" title="Desmond Tutu">Desmond Tutu</a> on Church Street, Pietermaritzburg, in June 1993</div></div></div>
<p>In April 1893, Gandhi aged 23, set sail for South Africa to be the lawyer for Abdullah's cousin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman_2008_pp._82_62-1"><a href="#cite_note-Herman_2008_pp._82-62">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NHOA-193_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-NHOA-193-63">[63]</a></sup> He spent 21 years in South Africa, where he developed his political views, ethics and politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi-64">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Immediately upon arriving in South Africa, Gandhi faced discrimination because of his skin colour and heritage, like all people of colour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parekh2001_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-Parekh2001-66">[66]</a></sup> He was not allowed to sit with European passengers in the stagecoach and told to sit on the floor near the driver, then beaten when he refused; elsewhere he was kicked into a gutter for daring to walk near a house, in another instance thrown off a train at <a href="/wiki/Pietermaritzburg" title="Pietermaritzburg">Pietermaritzburg</a> after refusing to leave the first-class.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stagecoach_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Stagecoach-67">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhiman25_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-dhiman25-68">[68]</a></sup> He sat in the train station, shivering all night and pondering if he should return to India or protest for his rights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhiman25_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-dhiman25-68">[68]</a></sup> He chose to protest and was allowed to board the train the next day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-(Mahatma)Fischer2002_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-(Mahatma)Fischer2002-69">[69]</a></sup> In another incident, the magistrate of a <a href="/wiki/Durban" title="Durban">Durban</a> court ordered Gandhi to remove his turban, which he refused to do.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turban_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Turban-70">[70]</a></sup> Indians were not allowed to walk on public footpaths in South Africa. Gandhi was kicked by a police officer out of the footpath onto the street without warning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-What_it_is_to_be_a_coolie_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-What_it_is_to_be_a_coolie-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>When Gandhi arrived in South Africa, according to Herman, he thought of himself as "a Briton first, and an Indian second".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> However, the prejudice against him and his fellow Indians from British people that Gandhi experienced and observed deeply bothered him. He found it humiliating, struggling to understand how some people can feel honour or superiority or pleasure in such inhumane practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhiman25_68-2"><a href="#cite_note-dhiman25-68">[68]</a></sup> Gandhi began to question his people's standing in the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen2011_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-Allen2011-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Abdullah case that had brought him to South Africa concluded in May 1894, and the Indian community organised a farewell party for Gandhi as he prepared to return to India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman_2008_pp._88_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herman_2008_pp._88-74">[74]</a></sup> However, a new Natal government discriminatory proposal led to Gandhi extending his original period of stay in South Africa. He planned to assist Indians in opposing a bill to <a href="/wiki/Disfranchisement" title="Disfranchisement">deny them the right to vote</a>, a right then proposed to be an exclusive European right. He asked <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Chamberlain" title="Joseph Chamberlain">Joseph Chamberlain</a>, the British Colonial Secretary, to reconsider his position on this bill.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi_64-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi-64">[64]</a></sup> Though unable to halt the bill's passage, his campaign was successful in drawing attention to the grievances of Indians in South Africa. He helped found the <a href="/wiki/Natal_Indian_Congress" title="Natal Indian Congress">Natal Indian Congress</a> in 1894,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_59-3"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-(Mahatma)Fischer2002_69-1"><a href="#cite_note-(Mahatma)Fischer2002-69">[69]</a></sup> and through this organisation, he moulded the Indian community of South Africa into a unified political force. In January 1897, when Gandhi landed in Durban, a mob of white settlers attacked him<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> and he escaped only through the efforts of the wife of the police superintendent. However, he refused to press charges against any member of the mob.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_59-4"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Boer_War.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2136" data-file-width="3644" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Gandhi_Boer_War.jpg/220px-Gandhi_Boer_War.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Gandhi_Boer_War.jpg/330px-Gandhi_Boer_War.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Gandhi_Boer_War.jpg/440px-Gandhi_Boer_War.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Boer_War.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi with the stretcher-bearers of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ambulance_Corps" title="Indian Ambulance Corps">Indian Ambulance Corps</a> during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boer_War" title="Boer War">Boer War</a></div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Second_Boer_War" title="Second Boer War">Boer War</a>, Gandhi volunteered in 1900 to form a group of stretcher-bearers as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natal_Indian_Ambulance_Corps" title="Natal Indian Ambulance Corps">Natal Indian Ambulance Corps</a>. According to Arthur Herman, Gandhi wanted to disprove the British colonial stereotype that Hindus were not fit for "manly" activities involving danger and exertion, unlike the Muslim "<a href="/wiki/Martial_race" title="Martial race">martial races</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> Gandhi raised eleven hundred Indian volunteers, to support British combat troops against the Boers. They were trained and medically certified to serve on the front lines. They were auxiliaries at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Colenso" title="Battle of Colenso">Battle of Colenso</a> to a White volunteer ambulance corps. At the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Spion_Kop" title="Battle of Spion Kop">battle of Spion Kop</a> Gandhi and his bearers moved to the front line and had to carry wounded soldiers for miles to a field hospital because the terrain was too rough for the ambulances. Gandhi and thirty-seven other Indians received the <a href="/wiki/Queen%27s_South_Africa_Medal" title="Queen's South Africa Medal">Queen's South Africa Medal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-medals_south_african_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-medals_south_african-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_and_Kasturbhai_1902.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="610" data-file-width="935" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Gandhi_and_Kasturbhai_1902.jpg/220px-Gandhi_and_Kasturbhai_1902.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Gandhi_and_Kasturbhai_1902.jpg/330px-Gandhi_and_Kasturbhai_1902.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Gandhi_and_Kasturbhai_1902.jpg/440px-Gandhi_and_Kasturbhai_1902.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_and_Kasturbhai_1902.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi (left) and his wife <a href="/wiki/Kasturba_Gandhi" title="Kasturba Gandhi">Kasturba</a> (right) (1902)</div></div></div>
<p>In 1906, the <a href="/wiki/Transvaal_Colony" title="Transvaal Colony">Transvaal</a> government promulgated a new Act compelling registration of the colony's Indian and Chinese populations. At a mass protest meeting held in Johannesburg on 11 September that year, Gandhi adopted his still evolving methodology of <i><a href="/wiki/Satyagraha" title="Satyagraha">Satyagraha</a></i> (devotion to the truth), or nonviolent protest, for the first time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rai2000_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rai2000-79">[79]</a></sup> According to Anthony Parel, Gandhi was also influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a> moral text <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tirukku%E1%B9%9Ba%E1%B8%B7" title="Tirukkuṛaḷ">Tirukkuṛaḷ</a></i> after <a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> mentioned it in their correspondence that began with "<a href="/wiki/A_Letter_to_a_Hindu" title="A Letter to a Hindu">A Letter to a Hindu</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LetterToAHindu_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-LetterToAHindu-80">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gandhi_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-gandhi-81">[81]</a></sup> Gandhi urged Indians to defy the new law and to suffer the punishments for doing so. Gandhi's ideas of protests, persuasion skills and public relations had emerged. He took these back to India in 1915.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Europeans.2C_Indians_and_Africans"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Europeans,_Indians_and_Africans">Europeans, Indians and Africans</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi focused his attention on Indians while in South Africa. He initially was not interested in politics. This changed, however, after he was discriminated against and bullied, such as by being thrown out of a train coach because of his skin colour by a white train official. After several such incidents with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_South_African" title="White South African">Whites in South Africa</a>, Gandhi's thinking and focus changed, and he felt he must resist this and fight for rights. He entered politics by forming the Natal Indian Congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> According to Ashwin Desai and Goolam Vahed, Gandhi's views on racism are contentious, and in some cases, distressing to those who admire him. Gandhi suffered persecution from the beginning in South Africa. Like with other coloured people, white officials denied him his rights, and the press and those in the streets bullied and called him a "parasite", "semi-barbarous", "canker", "squalid coolie", "yellow man", and other epithets. People would spit on him as an expression of racial hate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Desai2015p26_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Desai2015p26-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>While in South Africa, Gandhi focused on racial persecution of Indians but ignored those of Africans. In some cases, state Desai and Vahed, his behaviour was one of being a willing part of racial stereotyping and African exploitation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Desai2015p26_85-1"><a href="#cite_note-Desai2015p26-85">[85]</a></sup> During a speech in September 1896, Gandhi complained that the whites in the British colony of South Africa were degrading Indian Hindus and Muslims to "a level of <a href="/wiki/Kaffir_(racial_term)" title="Kaffir (racial term)">Kaffir</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> Scholars cite it as an example of evidence that Gandhi at that time thought of Indians and black South Africans differently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Desai2015p26_85-2"><a href="#cite_note-Desai2015p26-85">[85]</a></sup> As another example given by Herman, Gandhi, at age 24, prepared a legal brief for the Natal Assembly in 1895, seeking voting rights for Indians. Gandhi cited race history and European Orientalists' opinions that "Anglo-Saxons and Indians are sprung from the same Aryan stock or rather the Indo-European peoples", and argued that Indians should not be grouped with the Africans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman_2008_pp._88_74-1"><a href="#cite_note-Herman_2008_pp._88-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>Years later, Gandhi and his colleagues served and helped Africans as nurses and by opposing racism, according to the Nobel Peace Prize winner <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a>. The general image of Gandhi, state Desai and Vahed, has been reinvented since his assassination as if he was always a saint when in reality his life was more complex, contained inconvenient truths and was one that evolved over time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Desai2015p26_85-3"><a href="#cite_note-Desai2015p26-85">[85]</a></sup> In contrast, other Africa scholars state the evidence points to a rich history of co-operation and efforts by Gandhi and Indian people with nonwhite South Africans against persecution of Africans and the <a href="/wiki/Apartheid" title="Apartheid">Apartheid</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1906, when the <a href="/wiki/Bambatha_Rebellion" title="Bambatha Rebellion">Bambatha Rebellion</a> broke out in the <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_Natal" title="Colony of Natal">colony of Natal</a>, then 36-year old Gandhi, despite sympathising with the Zulu rebels encouraged Indian South Africans to form a volunteer stretcher-bearer unit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2010_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2010-88">[88]</a></sup> Writing in the <i><a href="/wiki/Indian_Opinion" title="Indian Opinion">Indian Opinion</a></i>, Gandhi argued that military service would be beneficial to the Indian community and claimed it would give them "health and happiness."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2010p281_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2010p281-89">[89]</a></sup> Gandhi eventually led a volunteer mixed unit of Indian and African stretcher-bearers to treat wounded combatants during the suppression of the rebellion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2010_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2010-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_suit.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="509" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Gandhi_suit.jpg/170px-Gandhi_suit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Gandhi_suit.jpg/255px-Gandhi_suit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Gandhi_suit.jpg/340px-Gandhi_suit.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_suit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi photographed in South Africa (1909)</div></div></div>
<p>The medical unit commanded by Gandhi operated for less than two months before being disbanded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2010_88-2"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2010-88">[88]</a></sup> After the suppression of the rebellion, the colonial establishment showed no interest in extending to the Indian community the civil rights granted to <a href="/wiki/White_South_Africans" title="White South Africans">white South Africans</a>. This led Gandhi to becoming disillusioned with the Empire and aroused a spiritual awakening with him; historian <a href="/wiki/Arthur_L._Herman" title="Arthur L. Herman">Arthur L. Herman</a> wrote that his African experience was a part of his great disillusionment with the West, transforming him into an "uncompromising non-cooperator".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2010p281_89-1"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2010p281-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1910, Gandhi established, with the help of his friend <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Kallenbach" title="Hermann Kallenbach">Hermann Kallenbach</a>, an idealistic community they named <a href="/wiki/Tolstoy_Farm" title="Tolstoy Farm">Tolstoy Farm</a> near Johannesburg.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> There he nurtured his policy of peaceful resistance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the years after black South Africans gained the right to vote in South Africa (1994), Gandhi was proclaimed a national hero with numerous monuments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mbeki2006_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mbeki2006-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Struggle_for_Indian_independence_.281915.E2.80.931947.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Struggle_for_Indian_independence_(1915–1947)">Struggle for Indian independence (1915–1947)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">Indian independence movement</a></div>
<p>At the request of <a href="/wiki/Gopal_Krishna_Gokhale" title="Gopal Krishna Gokhale">Gopal Krishna Gokhale</a>, conveyed to him by <a href="/wiki/Charles_Freer_Andrews" title="Charles Freer Andrews">C. F. Andrews</a>, Gandhi returned to India in 1915. He brought an international reputation as a leading Indian nationalist, theorist and community organiser.
</p><p>Gandhi joined the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a> and was introduced to Indian issues, politics and the Indian people primarily by <a href="/wiki/Gopal_Krishna_Gokhale" title="Gopal Krishna Gokhale">Gokhale</a>. Gokhale was a key leader of the Congress Party best known for his restraint and moderation, and his insistence on working inside the system. Gandhi took Gokhale's liberal approach based on British Whiggish traditions and transformed it to make it look Indian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Whiggism_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-Whiggism-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi took leadership of the Congress in 1920 and began escalating demands until on 26 January 1930 the Indian National Congress declared the independence of India. The British did not recognise the declaration but negotiations ensued, with the Congress taking a role in provincial government in the late 1930s. Gandhi and the Congress withdrew their support of the Raj when the Viceroy declared war on Germany in September 1939 without consultation. Tensions escalated until Gandhi demanded immediate independence in 1942 and the British responded by imprisoning him and tens of thousands of Congress leaders. Meanwhile, the Muslim League did co-operate with Britain and moved, against Gandhi's strong opposition, to demands for a totally separate Muslim state of Pakistan. In August 1947 the British partitioned the land with India and Pakistan each achieving independence on terms that Gandhi disapproved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Role_in_World_War_I">Role in World War I</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Indian_Army_during_World_War_I" title="Indian Army during World War I">The role of India in World War I</a></div>
<p>In April 1918, during the latter part of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Frederic_Thesiger,_1st_Viscount_Chelmsford" title="Frederic Thesiger, 1st Viscount Chelmsford">Viceroy</a> invited Gandhi to a War Conference in Delhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> Gandhi agreed to actively recruit Indians for the war effort.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wikilivres.ca_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-wikilivres.ca-96">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Recruiting_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-Recruiting-97">[97]</a></sup> In contrast to the <a href="/wiki/Bambatha_Rebellion" title="Bambatha Rebellion">Zulu War</a> of 1906 and the outbreak of World War I in 1914, when he recruited volunteers for the Ambulance Corps, this time Gandhi attempted to recruit combatants. In a June 1918 leaflet entitled "Appeal for Enlistment", Gandhi wrote "To bring about such a state of things we should have the ability to defend ourselves, that is, the ability to bear arms and to use them... If we want to learn the use of arms with the greatest possible despatch, it is our duty to enlist ourselves in the army."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CollectedWorks17b_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-CollectedWorks17b-98">[98]</a></sup> He did, however, stipulate in a letter to the <a href="/wiki/John_Maffey,_1st_Baron_Rugby" title="John Maffey, 1st Baron Rugby">Viceroy's private secretary</a> that he "personally will not kill or injure anybody, friend or foe."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CollectedWorks17c_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-CollectedWorks17c-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's war recruitment campaign brought into question his consistency on nonviolence. <a href="/wiki/Mahadev_Desai" title="Mahadev Desai">Gandhi's private secretary</a> noted that "The question of the consistency between his creed of '<a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">Ahimsa</a>' (nonviolence) and his recruiting campaign was raised not only then but has been discussed ever since."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wikilivres.ca_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-wikilivres.ca-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Champaran_agitations">Champaran agitations</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Champaran_Satyagraha" title="Champaran Satyagraha">Champaran Satyagraha</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:221px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Kheda_1918.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="345" data-file-width="219" decoding="async" height="345" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/11/Gandhi_Kheda_1918.jpg" width="219"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Kheda_1918.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi in 1918, at the time of the Kheda and Champaran Satyagrahas</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi's first major achievement came in 1917 with the <a href="/wiki/Champaran" title="Champaran">Champaran</a> agitation in <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a>. The Champaran agitation pitted the local peasantry against largely Anglo-Indian plantation owners who were backed by the local administration. The peasants were forced to grow <a href="/wiki/Indigofera" title="Indigofera">Indigofera</a>, a cash crop for <a href="/wiki/Indigo_dye" title="Indigo dye">Indigo dye</a> whose demand had been declining over two decades, and were forced to sell their crops to the planters at a fixed price. Unhappy with this, the peasantry appealed to Gandhi at his ashram in Ahmedabad. Pursuing a strategy of nonviolent protest, Gandhi took the administration by surprise and won concessions from the authorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hardiman2001_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hardiman2001-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Kheda_agitations">Kheda agitations</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kheda_Satyagraha" title="Kheda Satyagraha">Kheda Satyagraha</a></div>
<p>In 1918, <a href="/wiki/Kheda" title="Kheda">Kheda</a> was hit by floods and famine and the peasantry was demanding relief from taxes. Gandhi moved his headquarters to <a href="/wiki/Nadiad" title="Nadiad">Nadiad</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laboratory_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-Laboratory-101">[101]</a></sup> organising scores of supporters and fresh volunteers from the region, the most notable being <a href="/wiki/Vallabhbhai_Patel" title="Vallabhbhai Patel">Vallabhbhai Patel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi_Patel_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi_Patel-102">[102]</a></sup> Using non-co-operation as a technique, Gandhi initiated a signature campaign where peasants pledged non-payment of revenue even under the threat of confiscation of land. A social boycott of <i>mamlatdars</i> and <i>talatdars</i> (revenue officials within the district) accompanied the agitation. Gandhi worked hard to win public support for the agitation across the country. For five months, the administration refused, but by the end of May 1918, the Government gave way on important provisions and relaxed the conditions of payment of revenue tax until the famine ended. In Kheda, Vallabhbhai Patel represented the farmers in negotiations with the British, who suspended revenue collection and released all the prisoners.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown1974_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1974-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Khilafat_movement">Khilafat movement</span></h4>
<blockquote><p>Every revolution begins with a single act of defiance.</p></blockquote>
<p>In 1919, following World War I, Gandhi (aged 49) sought political co-operation from Muslims in his fight against British imperialism by supporting the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> that had been defeated in the World War. Before this initiative of Gandhi, communal disputes and religious riots between Hindus and Muslims were common in British India, such as the riots of 1917–18. Gandhi had already supported the British crown with resources and by recruiting Indian soldiers to fight the war in Europe on the British side. This effort of Gandhi was in part motivated by the British promise to reciprocate the help with <i>swaraj</i> (self-government) to Indians after the end of World War I.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-robbins133_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-robbins133-104">[104]</a></sup> The British government, instead of self government, had offered minor reforms instead, disappointing Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-green89_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-green89-105">[105]</a></sup> Gandhi announced his <i>satyagraha</i> (civil disobedience) intentions. The British colonial officials made their counter move by passing the <a href="/wiki/Rowlatt_Act" title="Rowlatt Act">Rowlatt Act</a>, to block Gandhi's movement. The Act allowed the British government to treat civil disobedience participants as criminals and gave it the legal basis to arrest anyone for "preventive indefinite detention, incarceration without judicial review or any need for a trial".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-minault68_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-minault68-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi felt that Hindu-Muslim co-operation was necessary for political progress against the British. He leveraged the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khilafat_movement" title="Khilafat movement">Khilafat movement</a>, wherein <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunni" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> Muslims in India, their leaders such as the sultans of princely states in India and Ali brothers championed the Turkish <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caliph" title="Caliph">Caliph</a> as a solidarity symbol of Sunni Islamic community (<i><a href="/wiki/Ummah" title="Ummah">ummah</a></i>). They saw the Caliph as their means to support Islam and the Islamic law after the defeat of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> in World War I.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paine20_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-paine20-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghosep161_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-ghosep161-109">[109]</a></sup> Gandhi's support to the Khilafat movement led to mixed results. It initially led to a strong Muslim support for Gandhi. However, the Hindu leaders including Rabindranath Tagore questioned Gandhi's leadership because they were largely against recognising or supporting the Sunni Islamic Caliph in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[a]</a></sup>
</p><p>The increasing Muslim support for Gandhi, after he championed the Caliph's cause, temporarily stopped the Hindu-Muslim communal violence. It offered evidence of inter-communal harmony in joint Rowlatt <i>satyagraha</i> demonstration rallies, raising Gandhi's stature as the political leader to the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[114]</a></sup> His support for the Khilafat movement also helped him sideline <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a>, who had announced his opposition to the <i>satyagraha</i> non-co-operation movement approach of Gandhi. Jinnah began creating his independent support, and later went on to lead the demand for West and East Pakistan. Though they agreed in general terms on Indian independence, they disagreed on the means of achieving this. Jinnah was mainly interested in dealing with the British via constitutional negotiation, rather than attempting to agitate the masses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the end of 1922 the Khilafat movement had collapsed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[118]</a></sup> Turkey's Atatürk had <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Caliphate" title="Abolition of the Caliphate">ended the Caliphate</a>, Khilafat movement ended, and Muslim support for Gandhi largely evaporated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paine20_108-1"><a href="#cite_note-paine20-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghosep161_109-1"><a href="#cite_note-ghosep161-109">[109]</a></sup> Muslim leaders and delegates abandoned Gandhi and his Congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[119]</a></sup> Hindu-Muslim communal conflicts reignited. Deadly religious riots re-appeared in numerous cities, with 91 in <a href="/wiki/United_Provinces_of_Agra_and_Oudh" title="United Provinces of Agra and Oudh">United Provinces of Agra and Oudh</a> alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Non-co-operation">Non-co-operation</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-co-operation_movement" title="Non-co-operation movement">Non-co-operation movement</a></div>
<p>With his book <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hind_Swaraj" title="Hind Swaraj">Hind Swaraj</a></i> (1909) Gandhi, aged 40, declared that British rule was established in India with the co-operation of Indians and had survived only because of this co-operation. If Indians refused to co-operate, British rule would collapse and <i><a href="/wiki/Swaraj" title="Swaraj">swaraj</a></i> (Indian independence) would come.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[122]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_besant_madras1921.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="346" decoding="async" height="318" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Gandhi_besant_madras1921.jpg/220px-Gandhi_besant_madras1921.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Gandhi_besant_madras1921.jpg/330px-Gandhi_besant_madras1921.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ed/Gandhi_besant_madras1921.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_besant_madras1921.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi with Dr. <a href="/wiki/Annie_Besant" title="Annie Besant">Annie Besant</a> en route to a meeting in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madras" title="Madras">Madras</a> in September 1921. Earlier, in <a href="/wiki/Madurai" title="Madurai">Madurai</a>, on 21 September 1921, Gandhi had adopted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Loin-cloth" title="Loin-cloth">loin-cloth</a> for the first time as a symbol of his identification with India's poor.</div></div></div>
<p>In February 1919, Gandhi cautioned the Viceroy of India with a cable communication that if the British were to pass the <a href="/wiki/Rowlatt_Act" title="Rowlatt Act">Rowlatt Act</a>, he would appeal to Indians to start civil disobedience.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpert2002p99_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpert2002p99-124">[123]</a></sup> The British government ignored him and passed the law, stating it would not yield to threats. The <i>satyagraha</i> civil disobedience followed, with people assembling to protest the Rowlatt Act. On 30 March 1919, British law officers opened fire on an assembly of unarmed people, peacefully gathered, participating in <i>satyagraha</i> in Delhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpert2002p99_124-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpert2002p99-124">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>People rioted in retaliation. On 6 April 1919, a Hindu festival day, he asked a crowd to remember not to injure or kill British people, but to express their frustration with peace, to boycott British goods and burn any British clothing they owned. He emphasised the use of non-violence to the British and towards each other, even if the other side used violence. Communities across India announced plans to gather in greater numbers to protest. Government warned him to not enter Delhi. Gandhi defied the order. On 9 April, Gandhi was arrested.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpert2002p99_124-2"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpert2002p99-124">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>People rioted. On 13 April 1919, people including women with children gathered in an Amritsar park, and <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Army" title="British Indian Army">British Indian Army</a> officer <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reginald_Edward_Harry_Dyer" title="Reginald Edward Harry Dyer">Reginald Dyer</a> surrounded them and ordered troops under his command to fire on them. The resulting <a href="/wiki/Jallianwala_Bagh_massacre" title="Jallianwala Bagh massacre">Jallianwala Bagh massacre</a> (or Amritsar massacre) of hundreds of Sikh and Hindu civilians enraged the subcontinent, but was supported by some Britons and parts of the British media as a necessary response. Gandhi in Ahmedabad, on the day after the massacre in Amritsar, did not criticise the British and instead criticised his fellow countrymen for not exclusively using 'love' to deal with the 'hate' of the British government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpert2002p99_124-3"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpert2002p99-124">[123]</a></sup> Gandhi demanded that the Indian people stop all violence, stop all property destruction, and went on fast-to-death to pressure Indians to stop their rioting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>The massacre and Gandhi's non-violent response to it moved many, but also made some Sikhs and Hindus upset that Dyer was getting away with murder. Investigation committees were formed by the British, which Gandhi asked Indians to boycott.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpert2002p99_124-4"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpert2002p99-124">[123]</a></sup> The unfolding events, the massacre and the British response, led Gandhi to the belief that Indians will never get a fair equal treatment under British rulers, and he shifted his attention to <i>swaraj</i> and political independence for India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chakrabarty2008_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chakrabarty2008-126">[125]</a></sup> In 1921, Gandhi was the leader of the Indian National Congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghosep161_109-2"><a href="#cite_note-ghosep161-109">[109]</a></sup> He reorganised the Congress. With Congress now behind him, and Muslim support triggered by his backing the Khilafat movement to restore the Caliph in Turkey,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghosep161_109-3"><a href="#cite_note-ghosep161-109">[109]</a></sup> Gandhi had the political support and the attention of the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roberts1923_112-1"><a href="#cite_note-Roberts1923-112">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-minault68_106-2"><a href="#cite_note-minault68-106">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paine20_108-2"><a href="#cite_note-paine20-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_spinning.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2312" data-file-width="3104" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Gandhi_spinning.jpg/220px-Gandhi_spinning.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Gandhi_spinning.jpg/330px-Gandhi_spinning.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Gandhi_spinning.jpg/440px-Gandhi_spinning.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_spinning.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi spinning yarn, in the late 1920s</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi expanded his nonviolent non-co-operation platform to include the <a href="/wiki/Swadeshi_movement" title="Swadeshi movement"><i>swadeshi</i> policy</a> – the boycott of foreign-made goods, especially British goods. Linked to this was his advocacy that <i><a href="/wiki/Khadi" title="Khadi">khadi</a></i> (homespun cloth) be worn by all Indians instead of British-made textiles. Gandhi exhorted Indian men and women, rich or poor, to spend time each day spinning <i>khadi</i> in support of the independence movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[126]</a></sup> In addition to boycotting British products, Gandhi urged the people to boycott British institutions and law courts, to resign from government employment, and to forsake <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_honours_system" title="British honours system">British titles and honours</a>. Gandhi thus began his journey aimed at crippling the British India government economically, politically and administratively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shashi1996_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-Shashi1996-128">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>The appeal of "Non-cooperation" grew, its social popularity drew participation from all strata of Indian society. Gandhi was arrested on 10 March 1922, tried for sedition, and sentenced to six years' imprisonment. He began his sentence on 18 March 1922. With Gandhi isolated in prison, the Indian National Congress split into two factions, one led by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chitta_Ranjan_Das" title="Chitta Ranjan Das">Chitta Ranjan Das</a> and <a href="/wiki/Motilal_Nehru" title="Motilal Nehru">Motilal Nehru</a> favouring party participation in the legislatures, and the other led by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chakravarti_Rajagopalachari" title="Chakravarti Rajagopalachari">Chakravarti Rajagopalachari</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sardar_Vallabhbhai_Patel" title="Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel">Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel</a>, opposing this move.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[128]</a></sup> Furthermore, co-operation among Hindus and Muslims ended as Khilafat movement collapsed with the rise of Atatürk in Turkey. Muslim leaders left the Congress and began forming Muslim organisations. The political base behind Gandhi had broken into factions. Gandhi was released in February 1924 for an <a href="/wiki/Appendicitis" title="Appendicitis">appendicitis</a> operation, having served only two years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Datta2006_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-Datta2006-131">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Salt_Satyagraha_.28Salt_March.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Salt_Satyagraha_(Salt_March)">Salt Satyagraha (Salt March)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salt_Satyagraha" title="Salt Satyagraha">Salt Satyagraha</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><video class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="81" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Salt_March.ogv" height="165" id="mwe_player_0" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Salt_March.ogv/220px--Salt_March.ogv.jpg" preload="none" width="220"><source data-bandwidth="284504" data-framerate="29.97002997003" data-height="240" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-transcodekey="240p.webm" data-width="320" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/de/Salt_March.ogv/Salt_March.ogv.240p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="382504" data-framerate="29.97002997003" data-height="240" data-shorttitle="VP9 240P" data-title="Small VP9 (240P)" data-transcodekey="240p.vp9.webm" data-width="320" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/de/Salt_March.ogv/Salt_March.ogv.240p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm;
