codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="462107" data-framerate="29.97002997003" data-height="240" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file, 320 × 240 (462 kbps)" data-width="320" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/de/Salt_March.ogv" type='video/ogg; codecs="theora, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="195352" data-framerate="29.97002997003" data-height="120" data-shorttitle="VP9 120P" data-title="Lowest bandwidth VP9 (120P)" data-transcodekey="120p.vp9.webm" data-width="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/de/Salt_March.ogv/Salt_March.ogv.120p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="168448" data-framerate="29.97002997003" data-height="160" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-transcodekey="160p.webm" data-width="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/de/Salt_March.ogv/Salt_March.ogv.160p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="273336" data-framerate="29.97002997003" data-height="180" data-shorttitle="VP9 180P" data-title="Low bandwidth VP9 (180P)" data-transcodekey="180p.vp9.webm" data-width="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/de/Salt_March.ogv/Salt_March.ogv.180p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"'/></video> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Salt_March.ogv" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Original footage of Gandhi and his followers marching to Dandi in the Salt Satyagraha</div></div></div>
<p>After his early release from prison for political crimes in 1924, over the second half of the 1920s Gandhi continued to pursue <i>swaraj</i>. He pushed through a resolution at the Calcutta Congress in December 1928 calling on the British government to grant India <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">dominion</a> status or face a new campaign of non-cooperation with complete independence for the country as its goal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990172_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990172-132">[131]</a></sup> After his support for World War I with Indian combat troops, and the failure of Khilafat movement in preserving the rule of Caliph in Turkey, followed by a collapse in Muslim support for his leadership, some such as <a href="/wiki/Subhas_Chandra_Bose" title="Subhas Chandra Bose">Subhas Chandra Bose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhagat_Singh" title="Bhagat Singh">Bhagat Singh</a> questioned his values and non-violent approach.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paine20_108-3"><a href="#cite_note-paine20-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghose199_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-ghose199-133">[132]</a></sup> While many Hindu leaders championed a demand for immediate independence, Gandhi revised his own call to a one-year wait, instead of two.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990172_132-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990172-132">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>The British did not respond favourably to Gandhi's proposal. British political leaders such as Lord Birkenhead and <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> announced opposition to "the appeasers of Gandhi" in their discussions with European diplomats who sympathised with Indian demands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[133]</a></sup> On 31 December 1929, an Indian flag was unfurled in <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>. Gandhi led Congress in a celebration on 26 January 1930 of <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(India)" title="Independence Day (India)">India's Independence Day</a> in Lahore. This day was commemorated by almost every other Indian organisation. Gandhi then launched a new Satyagraha against the British salt tax in March 1930. Gandhi sent an ultimatum in the form of a letter personally addressed to Lord Irwin, the viceroy of India, on 2 March. Gandhi condemned British rule in the letter, describing it as "a curse" that "has impoverished the dumb millions by a system of progressive exploitation and by a ruinously expensive military and civil administration...It has reduced us politically to serfdom." Gandhi also mentioned in the letter that the viceroy received a salary "over five thousand times India's average income." In the letter, Gandhi also stressed his continued adherence to non-violent forms of protest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>This was highlighted by the Salt March to Dandi from 12 March to 6 April, where, together with 78 volunteers, he marched 388 kilometres (241 mi) from Ahmedabad to Dandi, Gujarat to make salt himself, with the declared intention of breaking the salt laws. The march took 25 days to cover 240 miles with Gandhi speaking to often huge crowds along the way. Thousands of Indians joined him in Dandi. On 5 May he was interned under a regulation dating from 1827 in anticipation of a protest that he had planned. The protest at Dharasana salt works on 21 May went ahead without him see. A horrified American journalist, <a href="/wiki/Webb_Miller_(journalist)" title="Webb Miller (journalist)">Webb Miller</a>, described the British response thus:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>In complete silence the Gandhi men drew up and halted a hundred yards from the stockade. A picked column advanced from the crowd, waded the ditches and approached the barbed wire stockade... at a word of command, scores of native policemen rushed upon the advancing marchers and rained blows on their heads with their steel-shot lathis [long bamboo sticks]. Not one of the marchers even raised an arm to fend off blows. They went down like ninepins. From where I stood I heard the sickening whack of the clubs on unprotected skulls... Those struck down fell sprawling, unconscious or writhing with fractured skulls or broken shoulders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[135]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>This went on for hours until some 300 or more protesters had been beaten, many seriously injured and two killed. At no time did they offer any resistance.
</p><p>This campaign was one of his most successful at upsetting British hold on India; Britain responded by imprisoning over 60,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hatt2002_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hatt2002-137">[136]</a></sup> Congress estimates, however, put the figure at 90,000. Among them was one of Gandhi's lieutenants, <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a>.
</p><p>According to Sarma, Gandhi recruited women to participate in the salt tax campaigns and the boycott of foreign products, which gave many women a new self-confidence and dignity in the mainstream of Indian public life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sarma1994_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sarma1994-138">[137]</a></sup> However, other scholars such as Marilyn French state that Gandhi barred women from joining his civil disobedience movement because he feared he would be accused of using women as a political shield.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-french219_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-french219-139">[138]</a></sup> When women insisted on joining the movement and participating in public demonstrations, Gandhi asked the volunteers to get permissions of their guardians and only those women who can arrange child-care should join him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-suruchi77_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-suruchi77-140">[139]</a></sup> Regardless of Gandhi's apprehensions and views, Indian women joined the Salt March by the thousands to defy the British salt taxes and monopoly on salt mining. After Gandhi's arrest, the women marched and picketed shops on their own, accepting violence and verbal abuse from British authorities for the cause in the manner Gandhi inspired.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-french219_139-1"><a href="#cite_note-french219-139">[138]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Gandhi_as_folk_hero">Gandhi as folk hero</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indian_workers_on_strike_in_support_of_Mahatma_Gandhi_in_1930.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="595" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Indian_workers_on_strike_in_support_of_Mahatma_Gandhi_in_1930.jpg/220px-Indian_workers_on_strike_in_support_of_Mahatma_Gandhi_in_1930.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Indian_workers_on_strike_in_support_of_Mahatma_Gandhi_in_1930.jpg/330px-Indian_workers_on_strike_in_support_of_Mahatma_Gandhi_in_1930.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Indian_workers_on_strike_in_support_of_Mahatma_Gandhi_in_1930.jpg/440px-Indian_workers_on_strike_in_support_of_Mahatma_Gandhi_in_1930.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indian_workers_on_strike_in_support_of_Mahatma_Gandhi_in_1930.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Indian workers on strike in support of Gandhi in 1930</div></div></div>
<p>Indian Congress in the 1920s appealed to <a href="/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh" title="Andhra Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a> peasants by creating Telugu language plays that combined Indian mythology and legends, linked them to Gandhi's ideas, and portrayed Gandhi as a <a href="/wiki/Messiah" title="Messiah">messiah</a>, a reincarnation of ancient and medieval Indian nationalist leaders and saints. The plays built support among peasants steeped in traditional Hindu culture, according to Murali, and this effort made Gandhi a folk hero in Telugu speaking villages, a sacred messiah-like figure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Murali1985_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-Murali1985-141">[140]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Dennis Dalton, it was Gandhi's ideas that were responsible for his wide following. Gandhi criticised Western civilisation as one driven by "brute force and immorality", contrasting it with his categorisation of Indian civilisation as one driven by "soul force and morality".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dennis20_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-dennis20-142">[141]</a></sup> Gandhi captured the imagination of the people of his heritage with his ideas about winning "hate with love". These ideas are evidenced in his pamphlets from the 1890s, in South Africa, where too he was popular among the Indian <a href="/wiki/Indian_indenture_system" title="Indian indenture system">indentured workers</a>. After he returned to India, people flocked to him because he reflected their values.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dennis20_142-1"><a href="#cite_note-dennis20-142">[141]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_first_visit_to_Odisha.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Gandhi_first_visit_to_Odisha.jpg/220px-Gandhi_first_visit_to_Odisha.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Gandhi_first_visit_to_Odisha.jpg/330px-Gandhi_first_visit_to_Odisha.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Gandhi_first_visit_to_Odisha.jpg/440px-Gandhi_first_visit_to_Odisha.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_first_visit_to_Odisha.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi's first visit to <a href="/wiki/Odisha" title="Odisha">Odisha</a> in 1921, a general meeting held at the riverbed of Kathajodi</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi also campaigned hard going from one rural corner of the Indian subcontinent to another. He used terminology and phrases such as <i><a href="/wiki/Rama" title="Rama">Rama</a>-rajya</i> from <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Prahlada" title="Prahlada">Prahlada</a> as a paradigmatic icon, and such cultural symbols as another facet of <i>swaraj</i> and <i>satyagraha</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[142]</a></sup> During his lifetime, these ideas sounded strange outside India, but they readily and deeply resonated with the culture and historic values of his people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dennis20_142-2"><a href="#cite_note-dennis20-142">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[143]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Negotiations">Negotiations</span></h4>
<p>The government, represented by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/E._F._L._Wood,_1st_Earl_of_Halifax" title="E. F. L. Wood, 1st Earl of Halifax">Lord Irwin</a>, decided to negotiate with Gandhi. The <a href="/wiki/Gandhi%E2%80%93Irwin_Pact" title="Gandhi–Irwin Pact">Gandhi–Irwin Pact</a> was signed in March 1931. The British Government agreed to free all <a href="/wiki/Political_prisoner" title="Political prisoner">political prisoners</a>, in return for the suspension of the civil disobedience movement. According to the pact, Gandhi was invited to attend the Round Table Conference in London for discussions and as the sole representative of the Indian National Congress. The conference was a disappointment to Gandhi and the nationalists. Gandhi expected to discuss India's independence, while the British side focused on the Indian princes and Indian minorities rather than on a transfer of power. Lord Irwin's successor, <a href="/wiki/Freeman_Freeman-Thomas,_1st_Marquess_of_Willingdon" title="Freeman Freeman-Thomas, 1st Marquess of Willingdon">Lord Willingdon</a>, took a hard line against India as an independent nation, began a new campaign of controlling and subduing the nationalist movement. Gandhi was again arrested, and the government tried and failed to negate his influence by completely isolating him from his followers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2008_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2008-145">[144]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Britain, <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>, a prominent Conservative politician who was then out of office but later became its prime minister, became a vigorous and articulate critic of Gandhi and opponent of his long-term plans. Churchill often ridiculed Gandhi, saying in a widely reported 1931 speech:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>It is alarming and also nauseating to see Mr Gandhi, a seditious Middle Temple lawyer, now posing as a fakir of a type well known in the East, striding half-naked up the steps of the Vice-regal palace....to parley on equal terms with the representative of the King-Emperor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herman-146">[145]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Churchill's bitterness against Gandhi grew in the 1930s. He called Gandhi as the one who was "seditious in aim" whose evil genius and multiform menace was attacking the British empire. Churchill called him a dictator, a "Hindu <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mussolini" title="Mussolini">Mussolini</a>", fomenting a race war, trying to replace the Raj with <a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmin</a> cronies, playing on the ignorance of Indian masses, all for selfish gain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2008p378_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2008p378-147">[146]</a></sup> Churchill attempted to isolate Gandhi, and his criticism of Gandhi was widely covered by European and American press. It gained Churchill sympathetic support, but it also increased support for Gandhi among Europeans. The developments heightened Churchill's anxiety that the "British themselves would give up out of pacifism and misplaced conscience".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2008p378_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2008p378-147">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Round_Table_Conferences">Round Table Conferences</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mahadev_Desai_and_Gandhi_2_1939.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="320" data-file-width="247" decoding="async" height="285" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Mahadev_Desai_and_Gandhi_2_1939.jpg/220px-Mahadev_Desai_and_Gandhi_2_1939.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/98/Mahadev_Desai_and_Gandhi_2_1939.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mahadev_Desai_and_Gandhi_2_1939.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi and his personal assistant <a href="/wiki/Mahadev_Desai" title="Mahadev Desai">Mahadev Desai</a> at Birla House, 1939</div></div></div>
<p>During the discussions between Gandhi and the British government over 1931–32 at the <a href="/wiki/Round_Table_Conferences_(India)" title="Round Table Conferences (India)">Round Table Conferences</a>, Gandhi, now aged about 62, sought constitutional reforms as a preparation to the end of colonial British rule, and begin the self-rule by Indians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muldoon92_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-Muldoon92-148">[147]</a></sup> The British side sought reforms that would keep the Indian subcontinent as a colony. The British negotiators proposed constitutional reforms on a British Dominion model that established separate electorates based on religious and social divisions. The British questioned the Congress party and Gandhi's authority to speak for all of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[148]</a></sup> They invited Indian religious leaders, such as Muslims and Sikhs, to press their demands along religious lines, as well as <a href="/wiki/B._R._Ambedkar" title="B. R. Ambedkar">B. R. Ambedkar</a> as the representative leader of the untouchables.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muldoon92_148-1"><a href="#cite_note-Muldoon92-148">[147]</a></sup> Gandhi vehemently opposed a constitution that enshrined rights or representations based on communal divisions, because he feared that it would not bring people together but divide them, perpetuate their status, and divert the attention from India's struggle to end the colonial rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[150]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Second Round Table conference was the only time he left India between 1914 and his death in 1948. He declined the government's offer of accommodation in an expensive <a href="/wiki/West_End_of_London" title="West End of London">West End</a> hotel, preferring to stay in the <a href="/wiki/East_End_of_London" title="East End of London">East End</a>, to live among working-class people, as he did in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[151]</a></sup> He based himself in a small <a href="/wiki/Monastic_cell" title="Monastic cell">cell-bedroom</a> at <a href="/wiki/Kingsley_Hall" title="Kingsley Hall">Kingsley Hall</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Kingsley_Hall#Gandhi" title="Kingsley Hall">three-month duration of his stay</a> and was enthusiastically received by East Enders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[152]</a></sup> During this time he renewed his links with the <a href="/wiki/Vegetarianism_by_country#United_Kingdom" title="Vegetarianism by country">British vegetarian movement</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:An_admiring_East_End_crowd_gathers_to_witness_the_arrival_of_Mahatma_Gandhi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2472" data-file-width="3626" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/An_admiring_East_End_crowd_gathers_to_witness_the_arrival_of_Mahatma_Gandhi.jpg/220px-An_admiring_East_End_crowd_gathers_to_witness_the_arrival_of_Mahatma_Gandhi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/An_admiring_East_End_crowd_gathers_to_witness_the_arrival_of_Mahatma_Gandhi.jpg/330px-An_admiring_East_End_crowd_gathers_to_witness_the_arrival_of_Mahatma_Gandhi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/An_admiring_East_End_crowd_gathers_to_witness_the_arrival_of_Mahatma_Gandhi.jpg/440px-An_admiring_East_End_crowd_gathers_to_witness_the_arrival_of_Mahatma_Gandhi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:An_admiring_East_End_crowd_gathers_to_witness_the_arrival_of_Mahatma_Gandhi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An admiring <a href="/wiki/East_End_of_London" title="East End of London">East End</a> crowd gathers to witness the arrival of Mahatma Gandhi, 1931</div></div></div>
<p>After Gandhi returned from the Second Round Table conference, he started a new <i>satyagraha</i>. He was arrested and imprisoned at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yerwada_Jail" title="Yerwada Jail">Yerwada Jail</a>, Pune. While he was in prison, the British government enacted a new law that granted untouchables a separate electorate. It came to be known as the <a href="/wiki/Communal_Award" title="Communal Award">Communal Award</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[153]</a></sup> In protest, Gandhi started a fast-unto-death, while he was held in prison.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dirks2011p267_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dirks2011p267-155">[154]</a></sup> The resulting public outcry forced the government, in consultations with Ambedkar, to replace the Communal Award with a compromise <a href="/wiki/Poona_Pact" title="Poona Pact">Poona Pact</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yer_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-yer-156">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Congress_politics">Congress politics</span></h4>
<p>In 1934 Gandhi resigned from Congress party membership. He did not disagree with the party's position but felt that if he resigned, his popularity with Indians would cease to stifle the party's membership, which actually varied, including communists, socialists, trade unionists, students, religious conservatives, and those with pro-business convictions, and that these various voices would get a chance to make themselves heard. Gandhi also wanted to avoid being a target for Raj propaganda by leading a party that had temporarily accepted political accommodation with the Raj.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990246_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990246-158">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi returned to active politics again in 1936, with the Nehru presidency and the Lucknow session of the Congress. Although Gandhi wanted a total focus on the task of winning independence and not speculation about India's future, he did not restrain the Congress from adopting socialism as its goal. Gandhi had a clash with Subhas Chandra Bose, who had been elected president in 1938, and who had previously expressed a lack of faith in nonviolence as a means of protest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[158]</a></sup> Despite Gandhi's opposition, Bose won a second term as Congress President, against Gandhi's nominee, <a href="/wiki/Bhogaraju_Pattabhi_Sitaramayya" title="Bhogaraju Pattabhi Sitaramayya">Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya</a>; but left the Congress when the All-India leaders resigned en masse in protest of his abandonment of the principles introduced by Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990277–281_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990277–281-160">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sarkar2006_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sarkar2006-161">[160]</a></sup> Gandhi declared that Sitaramayya's defeat was his defeat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II_and_Quit_India_movement">World War II and <i>Quit India movement</i></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Quit_India_Movement" title="Quit India Movement">Quit India Movement</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_and_Nehru_in_1946.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1276" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Gandhi_and_Nehru_in_1946.jpg/220px-Gandhi_and_Nehru_in_1946.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Gandhi_and_Nehru_in_1946.jpg/330px-Gandhi_and_Nehru_in_1946.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Gandhi_and_Nehru_in_1946.jpg/440px-Gandhi_and_Nehru_in_1946.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_and_Nehru_in_1946.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi talking with <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a>, his designated political heir, during the drafting of the Quit India Resolution in Bombay, August 1942</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi opposed providing any help to the British war effort and he campaigned against any Indian participation in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herman467_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-herman467-163">[162]</a></sup> Gandhi's campaign did not enjoy the support of the Indian population nor of many Indian leaders, such as Sardar Patel and Rajendra Prasad, and as such failed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herman467_163-1"><a href="#cite_note-herman467-163">[162]</a></sup> Despite his efforts, over 2.5 million Indians volunteered and joined the British military to fight on various fronts of the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied Forces</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herman467_163-2"><a href="#cite_note-herman467-163">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's opposition to the Indian participation in World War II was motivated by his belief that India could not be party to a war ostensibly being fought for democratic freedom while that freedom was denied to India itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[163]</a></sup> He also condemned Nazism and Fascism, a view which won endorsement of other Indian leaders. As the war progressed, Gandhi intensified his demand for independence, calling for the British to <i>Quit India</i> in a 1942 speech in Mumbai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpertp74_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpertp74-165">[164]</a></sup> This was Gandhi's and the Congress Party's most definitive revolt aimed at securing the British exit from India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990309_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGandhi1990309-166">[165]</a></sup> The British government responded quickly to the Quit India speech, and within hours after Gandhi's speech arrested Gandhi and all the members of the Congress Working Committee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[166]</a></sup> His countrymen retaliated the arrests by damaging or burning down hundreds of government owned railway stations, police stations, and cutting down telegraph wires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpertp205_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpertp205-168">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1942, Gandhi now nearing age 73, urged his people to completely stop co-operating with the imperial government. In this effort, he urged that they neither kill nor injure British people, but be willing to suffer and die if violence is initiated by the British officials.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpertp74_165-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpertp74-165">[164]</a></sup> He clarified that the movement would not be stopped because of any individual acts of violence, saying that the <i>"ordered anarchy"</i> of <i>"the present system of administration"</i> was <i>"worse than real anarchy."</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[169]</a></sup> He urged Indians to <i>Karo ya maro</i> ("Do or die") in the cause of their rights and freedoms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpertp74_165-2"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpertp74-165">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_writing_1942.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="608" decoding="async" height="278" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Gandhi_writing_1942.jpg/220px-Gandhi_writing_1942.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Gandhi_writing_1942.jpg/330px-Gandhi_writing_1942.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Gandhi_writing_1942.jpg/440px-Gandhi_writing_1942.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_writing_1942.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi in 1942, the year he launched the <a href="/wiki/Quit_India_Movement" title="Quit India Movement">Quit India Movement</a></div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi's arrest lasted two years, as he was held in the <a href="/wiki/Aga_Khan_Palace" title="Aga Khan Palace">Aga Khan Palace</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pune" title="Pune">Pune</a>. During this period, his long time secretary Mahadev Desai died of a heart attack, his wife Kasturba died after 18 months' imprisonment on 22 February 1944; and Gandhi suffered a severe <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a> attack.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpertp205_168-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpertp205-168">[167]</a></sup> While in jail, he agreed to an interview with Stuart Gelder, a British journalist. Gelder then composed and released an interview summary, cabled it to the mainstream press, that announced sudden concessions Gandhi was willing to make, comments that shocked his countrymen, the Congress workers and even Gandhi. The latter two claimed that it distorted what Gandhi actually said on a range of topics and falsely repudiated the Quit India movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpertp205_168-2"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpertp205-168">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi was released before the end of the war on 6 May 1944 because of his failing health and necessary surgery; the Raj did not want him to die in prison and enrage the nation. He came out of detention to an altered political scene – the <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">Muslim League</a> for example, which a few years earlier had appeared marginal, "now occupied the centre of the political stage"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lapping1989_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lapping1989-172">[171]</a></sup> and the topic of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a>'s campaign for Pakistan was a major talking point. Gandhi and Jinnah had extensive correspondence and the two men met several times over a period of two weeks in September 1944 at Jinnah's house in Bombay, where Gandhi insisted on a united religiously plural and independent India which included Muslims and non-Muslims of the Indian subcontinent coexisting. Jinnah rejected this proposal and insisted instead for partitioning the subcontinent on religious lines to create a separate Muslim India (later Pakistan).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Khan2007-page1_10-2"><a href="#cite_note-Khan2007-page1-10">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[172]</a></sup> These discussions continued through 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>While the leaders of Congress languished in jail, the other parties supported the war and gained organisational strength. Underground publications flailed at the ruthless suppression of Congress, but it had little control over events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BhattacharyaStudies2001_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-BhattacharyaStudies2001-175">[174]</a></sup> At the end of the war, the British gave clear indications that power would be transferred to Indian hands. At this point Gandhi called off the struggle, and around 100,000 political prisoners were released, including the Congress's leadership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-176">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Partition_and_independence">Partition and independence</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">Indian independence movement</a> and <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition of India</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Jinnah_1944.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="667" data-file-width="1022" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Gandhi_Jinnah_1944.jpg/220px-Gandhi_Jinnah_1944.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Gandhi_Jinnah_1944.jpg/330px-Gandhi_Jinnah_1944.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Gandhi_Jinnah_1944.jpg/440px-Gandhi_Jinnah_1944.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Jinnah_1944.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi with <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a> in September 1944</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_the_partition_of_India" title="Opposition to the partition of India">opposed the partition of the Indian subcontinent</a> along religious lines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[176]</a></sup> The Indian National Congress and Gandhi called for the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British</a> to <a href="/wiki/Quit_India_Movement" title="Quit India Movement">Quit India</a>. However, the <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">Muslim League</a> demanded "Divide and Quit India".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[178]</a></sup> Gandhi suggested an agreement which required the Congress and the Muslim League to co-operate and attain independence under a provisional government, thereafter, the question of partition could be resolved by a plebiscite in the districts with a Muslim majority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-(Mahatma)Jack1994_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-(Mahatma)Jack1994-180">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jinnah rejected Gandhi's proposal and called for <a href="/wiki/Direct_Action_Day" title="Direct Action Day">Direct Action Day</a>, on 16 August 1946, to press Muslims to publicly gather in cities and support his proposal for the partition of the Indian subcontinent into a Muslim state and non-Muslim state. <a href="/wiki/Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy" title="Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy">Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy</a>, the Muslim League Chief Minister of Bengal – now <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>, gave Calcutta's police special holiday to celebrate the Direct Action Day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpert118_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpert118-181">[180]</a></sup> The Direct Action Day triggered a mass murder of Calcutta Hindus and the torching of their property, and holidaying police were missing to contain or stop the conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chapter_1_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chapter_1-182">[181]</a></sup> The British government did not order its army to move in to contain the violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpert118_181-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpert118-181">[180]</a></sup> The violence on Direct Action Day led to retaliatory violence against Muslims across India. Thousands of Hindus and Muslims were murdered, and tens of thousands were injured in the cycle of violence in the days that followed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[182]</a></sup> Gandhi visited the most riot-prone areas to appeal a stop to the massacres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chapter_1_182-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chapter_1-182">[181]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mountbattens_with_Gandhi_(IND_5298).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="781" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Mountbattens_with_Gandhi_%28IND_5298%29.jpg/220px-Mountbattens_with_Gandhi_%28IND_5298%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Mountbattens_with_Gandhi_%28IND_5298%29.jpg/330px-Mountbattens_with_Gandhi_%28IND_5298%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Mountbattens_with_Gandhi_%28IND_5298%29.jpg/440px-Mountbattens_with_Gandhi_%28IND_5298%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mountbattens_with_Gandhi_(IND_5298).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi in 1947, with <a href="/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma">Louis Mountbatten</a>, Britain's last Viceroy of India, and his wife <a href="/wiki/Edwina_Mountbatten,_Countess_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Edwina Mountbatten, Countess Mountbatten of Burma">Edwina Mountbatten</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Archibald_Wavell,_1st_Earl_Wavell" title="Archibald Wavell, 1st Earl Wavell">Archibald Wavell</a>, the Viceroy and Governor-General of British India for three years through February 1947, had worked with Gandhi and Jinnah to find a common ground, before and after accepting Indian independence in principle. Wavell condemned Gandhi's character and motives as well as his ideas. Wavell accused Gandhi of harbouring the single minded idea to "overthrow British rule and influence and to establish a Hindu raj", and called Gandhi a "malignant, malevolent, exceedingly shrewd" politician.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dalton2012p65_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dalton2012p65-184">[183]</a></sup> Wavell feared a civil war on the Indian subcontinent, and doubted Gandhi would be able to stop it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dalton2012p65_184-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dalton2012p65-184">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>The British reluctantly agreed to grant independence to the people of the Indian subcontinent, but accepted Jinnah's proposal of partitioning the land into Pakistan and India. Gandhi was involved in the final negotiations, but <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Wolpert" title="Stanley Wolpert">Stanley Wolpert</a> states the "plan to carve up British India was never approved of or accepted by Gandhi".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[184]</a></sup>
</p><p>The partition was controversial and violently disputed. More than half a million were killed in religious riots as 10 million to 12 million non-Muslims (Hindus and Sikhs mostly) migrated from Pakistan into India, and Muslims migrated from India into Pakistan, across the newly created borders of India, West Pakistan and East Pakistan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MetcalfMetcalf2006_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2006-186">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi spent the day of independence not celebrating the end of the British rule but appealing for peace among his countrymen by fasting and spinning in Calcutta on 15 August 1947. The partition had gripped the Indian subcontinent with religious violence and the streets were filled with corpses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gs_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-gs-187">[186]</a></sup> Some writers credit Gandhi's fasting and protests for stopping the religious riots and communal violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dalton2012p65_184-2"><a href="#cite_note-Dalton2012p65-184">[183]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Assassination of Mahatma Gandhi">Assassination of Mahatma Gandhi</a></div>
<p>At 5:17 pm on 30 January 1948, Gandhi was with his grandnieces in the garden of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Birla_House" title="Birla House">Birla House</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Smriti" title="Gandhi Smriti">Gandhi Smriti</a>), on his way to address a prayer meeting, when <a href="/wiki/Nathuram_Godse" title="Nathuram Godse">Nathuram Godse</a>, a Hindu nationalist, fired three bullets into his chest from a pistol at close range. According to some accounts, Gandhi died instantly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi2007_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi2007-189">[188]</a></sup> In other accounts, such as one prepared by an eyewitness journalist, Gandhi was carried into the Birla House, into a bedroom. There he died about 30 minutes later as one of Gandhi's family members read verses from Hindu scriptures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru addressed his countrymen over the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-India_Radio" title="All-India Radio">All-India Radio</a> saying:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghose1991_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ghose1991-191">[190]</a></sup>
</p>
<blockquote><p>Friends and comrades, the light has gone out of our lives, and there is darkness everywhere, and I do not quite know what to tell you or how to say it. Our beloved leader, Bapu as we called him, the father of the nation, is no more. Perhaps I am wrong to say that; nevertheless, we will not see him again, as we have seen him for these many years, we will not run to him for advice or seek solace from him, and that is a terrible blow, not only for me, but for millions and millions in this country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jai1996_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jai1996-192">[191]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mohandas_K._Gandhi,_Memorial_assassination_spot,_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Mohandas_K._Gandhi%2C_Memorial_assassination_spot%2C_2013.jpg/200px-Mohandas_K._Gandhi%2C_Memorial_assassination_spot%2C_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Mohandas_K._Gandhi%2C_Memorial_assassination_spot%2C_2013.jpg/300px-Mohandas_K._Gandhi%2C_Memorial_assassination_spot%2C_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Mohandas_K._Gandhi%2C_Memorial_assassination_spot%2C_2013.jpg/400px-Mohandas_K._Gandhi%2C_Memorial_assassination_spot%2C_2013.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mohandas_K._Gandhi,_Memorial_assassination_spot,_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Memorial at the location of Gandhi's assassination in 1948. His stylised footsteps lead to the memorial.</div></div></div>
<p>Godse, a Hindu nationalist with links to the extremist <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Mahasabha" title="Hindu Mahasabha">Hindu Mahasabha</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[192]</a></sup> made no attempt to escape; several other conspirators were soon arrested as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[194]</a></sup> They were tried in court at Delhi's Red Fort. At his trial, Godse did not deny the charges nor express any remorse. According to Claude Markovits, a French historian noted for his studies of colonial India, Godse stated that he killed Gandhi because of his complacence towards Muslims, holding Gandhi responsible for the frenzy of violence and sufferings during the subcontinent's partition into Pakistan and India. Godse accused Gandhi of subjectivism and of acting as if only he had a monopoly of the truth. Godse was found guilty and executed in 1949.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Markovits2004p57_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-Markovits2004p57-196">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-godse1948_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-godse1948-197">[196]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_funeral.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2302" data-file-width="3324" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Gandhi_funeral.jpg/220px-Gandhi_funeral.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Gandhi_funeral.jpg/330px-Gandhi_funeral.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Gandhi_funeral.jpg/440px-Gandhi_funeral.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_funeral.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi's funeral was marked by millions of Indians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi94_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi94-198">[197]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi's death was mourned nationwide. Over a million people joined the five-mile-long funeral procession that took over five hours to reach Raj Ghat from Birla house, where he was assassinated, and another million watched the procession pass by.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi94_198-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi94-198">[197]</a></sup> Gandhi's body was transported on a weapons carrier, whose chassis was dismantled overnight to allow a high-floor to be installed so that people could catch a glimpse of his body. The engine of the vehicle was not used; instead four drag-ropes held by 50 people each pulled the vehicle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ie48_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-ie48-199">[198]</a></sup> All Indian-owned establishments in London remained closed in mourning as thousands of people from all faiths and denominations and Indians from all over Britain converged at <a href="/wiki/India_House,_London" title="India House, London">India House</a> in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ie48pg5_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-ie48pg5-200">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's assassination dramatically changed the political landscape. Nehru became his political heir. According to Markovits, while Gandhi was alive, Pakistan's declaration that it was a "Muslim state" had led Indian groups to demand that it be declared a "Hindu state".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Markovits2004p57_196-1"><a href="#cite_note-Markovits2004p57-196">[195]</a></sup> Nehru used Gandhi's martyrdom as a political weapon to silence all advocates of Hindu nationalism as well as his political challengers. He linked Gandhi's assassination to politics of hatred and ill-will.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Markovits2004p57_196-2"><a href="#cite_note-Markovits2004p57-196">[195]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Guha, Nehru and his Congress colleagues called on Indians to honour Gandhi's memory and even more his ideals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[201]</a></sup> Nehru used the assassination to consolidate the authority of the new Indian state. Gandhi's death helped marshal support for the new government and legitimise the Congress Party's control, leveraged by the massive outpouring of Hindu expressions of grief for a man who had inspired them for decades. The government suppressed the <a href="/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh" title="Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh">RSS</a>, the Muslim National Guards, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khaksars" title="Khaksars">Khaksars</a>, with some 200,000 arrests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Khan2011_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-Khan2011-203">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p>For years after the assassination, states Markovits, "Gandhi's shadow loomed large over the political life of the new Indian Republic". The government quelled any opposition to its economic and social policies, despite these being contrary to Gandhi's ideas, by reconstructing Gandhi's image and ideals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[203]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Funeral_and_memorials">Funeral and memorials</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cremation_at_Rajghat.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="241" data-file-width="325" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Cremation_at_Rajghat.gif/220px-Cremation_at_Rajghat.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/38/Cremation_at_Rajghat.gif 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cremation_at_Rajghat.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Cremation of Mahatma Gandhi at <a href="/wiki/Raj_Ghat_and_associated_memorials" title="Raj Ghat and associated memorials">Rajghat</a>, 31 January 1948. It was attended by <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma">Louis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edwina_Mountbatten,_Countess_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Edwina Mountbatten, Countess Mountbatten of Burma">Edwina Mountbatten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abul_Kalam_Azad" title="Abul Kalam Azad">Maulana Azad</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rajkumari_Amrit_Kaur" title="Rajkumari Amrit Kaur">Rajkumari Amrit Kaur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarojini_Naidu" title="Sarojini Naidu">Sarojini Naidu</a> and other national leaders. His son <a href="/wiki/Devdas_Gandhi" title="Devdas Gandhi">Devdas Gandhi</a> lit the pyre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[204]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi was cremated in accordance with Hindu tradition. Gandhi's ashes were poured into urns which were sent across India for memorial services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[205]</a></sup> Most of the ashes were immersed at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sangam_at_Allahabad" title="Sangam at Allahabad">Sangam at Allahabad</a> on 12 February 1948, but some were secretly taken away. In 1997, <a href="/wiki/Tushar_Gandhi" title="Tushar Gandhi">Tushar Gandhi</a> immersed the contents of one urn, found in a bank vault and reclaimed through the courts, at the Sangam at Allahabad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guardian-2008-ashes_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian-2008-ashes-207">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kumar2006_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kumar2006-208">[207]</a></sup> Some of Gandhi's ashes were scattered at the source of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nile_River" title="Nile River">Nile River</a> near <a href="/wiki/Jinja,_Uganda" title="Jinja, Uganda">Jinja, Uganda</a>, and a memorial plaque marks the event. On 30 January 2008, the contents of another urn were immersed at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Girgaum_Chowpatty" title="Girgaum Chowpatty">Girgaum Chowpatty</a>. Another urn is at the <a href="/wiki/Aga_Khan_Palace" title="Aga Khan Palace">palace</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Aga_Khan" title="Aga Khan">Aga Khan</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pune" title="Pune">Pune</a> (where Gandhi was held as a political prisoner from 1942 to 1944<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[209]</a></sup>) and another in the <a href="/wiki/Self-Realization_Fellowship_Lake_Shrine" title="Self-Realization Fellowship Lake Shrine">Self-Realization Fellowship Lake Shrine</a> in Los Angeles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guardian-2008-ashes_207-1"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian-2008-ashes-207">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GWPM_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-GWPM-211">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Birla House site where Gandhi was assassinated is now a memorial called Gandhi Smriti. The place near Yamuna river where he was cremated is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raj_Ghat_and_other_memorials" title="Raj Ghat and other memorials">Rāj Ghāt</a> memorial in New Delhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup> A black marble platform, it bears the epigraph "Hē Rāma" (<a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a>: <i>हे ! राम</i> or, <i>Hey <a href="/wiki/Rama" title="Rama">Raam</a></i>). These are widely believed to be Gandhi's last words after he was shot, though the veracity of this statement has been questioned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[212]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Principles.2C_practices.2C_and_beliefs"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Principles,_practices,_and_beliefs">Principles, practices, and beliefs</span></h2>
<p>Gandhi's statements, letters and life have attracted much political and scholarly analysis of his principles, practices and beliefs, including what influenced him. Some writers present him as a paragon of ethical living and pacifism, while others present him as a more complex, contradictory and evolving character influenced by his culture and circumstances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[214]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Influences">Influences</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tagore_Gandhi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="912" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Tagore_Gandhi.jpg/220px-Tagore_Gandhi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Tagore_Gandhi.jpg/330px-Tagore_Gandhi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Tagore_Gandhi.jpg/440px-Tagore_Gandhi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tagore_Gandhi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi with poet <a href="/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Rabindranath Tagore">Rabindranath Tagore</a>, 1940</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi grew up in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jain" title="Jain">Jain</a> religious atmosphere in his native Gujarat, which were his primary influences, but he was also influenced by his personal reflections and literature of Hindu Bhakti saints, <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, and thinkers such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tolstoy" title="Tolstoy">Tolstoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Ruskin" title="John Ruskin">Ruskin</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thoreau" title="Thoreau">Thoreau</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brown93_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-brown93-216">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup> At age 57 he declared himself to be <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaitist Hindu</a> in his religious persuasion, but added that he supported <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dvaita" title="Dvaita">Dvaitist</a> viewpoints and religious pluralism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[218]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi was influenced by his devout Vaishnava Hindu mother, the regional Hindu temples and <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">saint tradition</a> which co-existed with Jain tradition in Gujarat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brown93_216-1"><a href="#cite_note-brown93-216">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[220]</a></sup> Historian R.B. Cribb states that Gandhi's thought evolved over time, with his early ideas becoming the core or scaffolding for his mature philosophy. He committed himself early to truthfulness, <a href="/wiki/Temperance_(virtue)" title="Temperance (virtue)">temperance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chastity" title="Chastity">chastity</a>, and vegetarianism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[221]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's London lifestyle incorporated the values he had grown up with. When he returned to India in 1891, his outlook was parochial and he could not make a living as a lawyer. This challenged his belief that practicality and morality necessarily coincided. By moving in 1893 to South Africa he found a solution to this problem and developed the central concepts of his mature philosophy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crib1985_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-Crib1985-223">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Bhikhu Parekh, three books that influenced Gandhi most in South Africa were <a href="/wiki/William_Mackintire_Salter" title="William Mackintire Salter">William Salter's</a> <i>Ethical Religion</i> (1889); <a href="/wiki/Henry_David_Thoreau" title="Henry David Thoreau">Henry David Thoreau</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Civil_Disobedience_(Thoreau)" title="Civil Disobedience (Thoreau)">On the Duty of Civil Disobedience</a></i> (1849); and <a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Kingdom_of_God_Is_Within_You" title="The Kingdom of God Is Within You">The Kingdom of God Is Within You</a></i> (1894). The art critic and critic of political economy <a href="/wiki/John_Ruskin" title="John Ruskin">John Ruskin</a> inspired his decision to live an austere life on a commune, at first on the Phoenix Farm in Natal and then on the Tolstoy Farm just outside Johannesburg, South Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parekh2001_66-1"><a href="#cite_note-Parekh2001-66">[66]</a></sup> The most profound influence on Gandhi were those from Hinduism, Christianity and Jainism, states Parekh, with his thoughts "in harmony with the classical Indian traditions, specially the Advaita or monistic tradition".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Indira Carr and others, Gandhi was influenced by Vaishnavism, Jainism and Advaita Vedanta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[225]</a></sup> Balkrishna Gokhale states that Gandhi was influenced by Hinduism and Jainism, and his studies of Sermon on the Mount of Christianity, <a href="/wiki/John_Ruskin" title="John Ruskin">Ruskin</a> and Tolstoy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BGB_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-BGB-227">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p>Additional theories of possible influences on Gandhi have been proposed. For example, in 1935, N. A. Toothi stated that Gandhi was influenced by the reforms and teachings of the <a href="/wiki/Swaminarayan" title="Swaminarayan">Swaminarayan</a> tradition of <a href="/wiki/John_Ruskin" title="John Ruskin">Hinduism</a>. According to Raymond Williams, Toothi may have overlooked the influence of the Jain community, and adds close parallels do exist in programs of social reform in the Swaminarayan tradition and those of Gandhi, based on "nonviolence, truth-telling, cleanliness, temperance and upliftment of the masses."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rbw01_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-rbw01-228">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mhe94_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-mhe94-229">[228]</a></sup> Historian Howard states the culture of Gujarat influenced Gandhi and his methods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spodek_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-Spodek-230">[229]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Leo_Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Tolstoy_Farm.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="479" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Gandhi_Tolstoy_Farm.jpg/220px-Gandhi_Tolstoy_Farm.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Gandhi_Tolstoy_Farm.jpg/330px-Gandhi_Tolstoy_Farm.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Gandhi_Tolstoy_Farm.jpg/440px-Gandhi_Tolstoy_Farm.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Tolstoy_Farm.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mohandas K. Gandhi and other residents of <a href="/wiki/Tolstoyan_movement#Africa" title="Tolstoyan movement">Tolstoy Farm</a>, South Africa, 1910</div></div></div>
<p>Along with the book mentioned above, in 1908 <a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> wrote <i><a href="/wiki/A_Letter_to_a_Hindu" title="A Letter to a Hindu">A Letter to a Hindu</a>,</i> which said that only by using love as a weapon through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Passive_resistance" title="Passive resistance">passive resistance</a> could the Indian people overthrow colonial rule. In 1909, Gandhi wrote to Tolstoy seeking advice and permission to republish <i>A Letter to a Hindu</i> in Gujarati. Tolstoy responded and the two continued a correspondence until Tolstoy's death in 1910 (Tolstoy's last letter was to Gandhi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup> The letters concern practical and theological applications of nonviolence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup> Gandhi saw himself a disciple of Tolstoy, for they agreed regarding opposition to state authority and colonialism; both hated violence and preached <a href="/wiki/Nonresistance" title="Nonresistance">non-resistance</a>. However, they differed sharply on political strategy. Gandhi called for political involvement; he was a nationalist and was prepared to use nonviolent force. He was also willing to compromise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Green1986_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-Green1986-233">[232]</a></sup> It was at <a href="/wiki/Tolstoy_Farm" title="Tolstoy Farm">Tolstoy Farm</a> where Gandhi and <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Kallenbach" title="Hermann Kallenbach">Hermann Kallenbach</a> systematically trained their disciples in the philosophy of nonviolence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhana_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bhana-234">[233]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Shrimad_Rajchandra">Shrimad Rajchandra</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi credited <a href="/wiki/Shrimad_Rajchandra" title="Shrimad Rajchandra">Shrimad Rajchandra</a>, a poet and Jain philosopher, as his influential counsellor. In <i>Modern Review</i>, June 1930, Gandhi wrote about their first encounter in 1891 at Dr. P.J. Mehta's residence in Bombay. He was introduced to Shrimad by Dr. Pranjivan Mehta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup> Gandhi exchanged letters with Rajchandra when he was in South Africa, referring to him as <i>Kavi</i> (literally, "poet"). In 1930, Gandhi wrote, "Such was the man who captivated my heart in religious matters as no other man ever has till now."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup> "I have said elsewhere that in moulding my inner life Tolstoy and Ruskin vied with Kavi. But Kavi's influence was undoubtedly deeper if only because I had come in closest personal touch with him."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi, in his autobiography, called Rajchandra his "guide and helper" and his "refuge [...] in moments of spiritual crisis". He had advised Gandhi to be patient and to study Hinduism deeply.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi1957_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi1957-238">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Weber2004_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-Weber2004-239">[238]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Religious_texts">Religious texts</span></h4>
<p>During his stay in South Africa, along with scriptures and philosophical texts of Hinduism and other Indian religions, Gandhi read translated texts of Christianity such as the Bible, and Islam such as the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britgandhirel_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-britgandhirel-240">[239]</a></sup> A Quaker mission in South Africa attempted to convert him to Christianity. Gandhi joined them in their prayers and debated Christian theology with them, but refused conversion stating he did not accept the theology therein or that Christ was the only son of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britgandhirel_240-1"><a href="#cite_note-britgandhirel-240">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[241]</a></sup>
</p><p>His comparative studies of religions and interaction with scholars, led him to respect all religions as well as become concerned about imperfections in all of them and frequent misinterpretations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britgandhirel_240-2"><a href="#cite_note-britgandhirel-240">[239]</a></sup> Gandhi grew fond of Hinduism, and referred to the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a></i> as his spiritual dictionary and greatest single influence on his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britgandhirel_240-3"><a href="#cite_note-britgandhirel-240">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup> Later, Gandhi translated the <i>Gita</i> into Gujarati in 1930.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[244]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Sufism">Sufism</span></h5>
<p>Gandhi was acquainted with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sufi_Islam" title="Sufi Islam">Sufi Islam</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Chishti_Order" title="Chishti Order">Chishti Order</a> during his stay in South Africa. He attended <a href="/wiki/Khanqah" title="Khanqah">Khanqah</a> gatherings there at Riverside. According to Margaret Chatterjee, Gandhi as a Vaishnava Hindu shared values such as humility, devotion and brotherhood for the poor that is also found in <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[246]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> also compared Gandhi to a Sufi <a href="/wiki/Fakir" title="Fakir">fakir</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman_146-1"><a href="#cite_note-Herman-146">[145]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="On_wars_and_nonviolence">On wars and nonviolence</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Support_for_wars">Support for wars</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi participated in forming the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ambulance_Corps" title="Indian Ambulance Corps">Indian Ambulance Corps</a> in the South African war against the Boers, on the British side in 1899.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghose275_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-ghose275-248">[247]</a></sup> Both the Dutch settlers called Boers and the imperial British at that time discriminated against the coloured races they considered as inferior, and Gandhi later wrote about his conflicted beliefs during the Boer war. He stated that "when the war was declared, my personal sympathies were all with the Boers, but my loyalty to the British rule drove me to participation with the British in that war. I felt that, if I demanded rights as a British citizen, it was also my duty, as such to participate in the defence of the British Empire, so I collected together as many comrades as possible, and with very great difficulty got their services accepted as an ambulance corps."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup>
</p><p>During World War I (1914–1918), nearing the age of 50, Gandhi supported the British and its allied forces by recruiting Indians to join the British army, expanding the Indian contingent from about 100,000 to over 1.1 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-green89_105-1"><a href="#cite_note-green89-105">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghose275_248-1"><a href="#cite_note-ghose275-248">[247]</a></sup> He encouraged Indian people to fight on one side of the war in Europe and Africa at the cost of their lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghose275_248-2"><a href="#cite_note-ghose275-248">[247]</a></sup> Pacifists criticised and questioned Gandhi, who defended these practices by stating, according to Sankar Ghose, "it would be madness for me to sever my connection with the society to which I belong".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghose275_248-3"><a href="#cite_note-ghose275-248">[247]</a></sup> According to Keith Robbins, the recruitment effort was in part motivated by the British promise to reciprocate the help with <i>swaraj</i> (self-government) to Indians after the end of World War I.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-robbins133_104-1"><a href="#cite_note-robbins133-104">[104]</a></sup> After the war, the British government offered minor reforms instead, which disappointed Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-green89_105-2"><a href="#cite_note-green89-105">[105]</a></sup> He launched his <i>satyagraha</i> movement in 1919. In parallel, Gandhi's fellowmen became sceptical of his pacifist ideas and were inspired by the ideas of nationalism and anti-imperialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a 1920 essay, after the World War I, Gandhi wrote, "where there is only a choice between cowardice and violence, I would advise violence." Rahul Sagar interprets Gandhi's efforts to recruit for the British military during the War, as Gandhi's belief that, at that time, it would demonstrate that Indians were willing to fight. Further, it would also show the British that his fellow Indians were "their subjects by choice rather than out of cowardice." In 1922, Gandhi wrote that abstinence from violence is effective and true forgiveness only when one has the power to punish, not when one decides not to do anything because one is helpless.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>After World War II engulfed Britain, Gandhi actively campaigned to oppose any help to the British war effort and any Indian participation in the war. According to Arthur Herman, Gandhi believed that his campaign would strike a blow to imperialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herman467_163-3"><a href="#cite_note-herman467-163">[162]</a></sup> Gandhi's position was not supported by many Indian leaders, and his campaign against the British war effort was a failure. The Hindu leader, <a href="/wiki/Tej_Bahadur_Sapru" title="Tej Bahadur Sapru">Tej Bahadur Sapru</a>, declared in 1941, states Herman, "A good many Congress leaders are fed up with the barren program of the Mahatma".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herman467_163-4"><a href="#cite_note-herman467-163">[162]</a></sup> Over 2.5 million Indians ignored Gandhi, volunteered and joined on the British side. They fought and died as a part of the Allied forces in Europe, North Africa and various fronts of the World War II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herman467_163-5"><a href="#cite_note-herman467-163">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Truth_and_Satyagraha">Truth and Satyagraha</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mahatma_Gandhi_on_Rumours.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Mahatma_Gandhi_on_Rumours.jpg/220px-Mahatma_Gandhi_on_Rumours.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Mahatma_Gandhi_on_Rumours.jpg/330px-Mahatma_Gandhi_on_Rumours.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Mahatma_Gandhi_on_Rumours.jpg/440px-Mahatma_Gandhi_on_Rumours.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mahatma_Gandhi_on_Rumours.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Plaque displaying one of Gandhi's quotes on rumour</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi dedicated his life to discovering and pursuing truth, or <i><a href="/wiki/Satya" title="Satya">Satya</a></i>, and called his movement <a href="/wiki/Satyagraha" title="Satyagraha">satyagraha</a>, which means "appeal to, insistence on, or reliance on the Truth".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup> The first formulation of the <i>satyagraha</i> as a political movement and principle occurred in 1920, which he tabled as "Resolution on Non-cooperation" in September that year before a session of the Indian Congress. It was the <i>satyagraha</i> formulation and step, states Dennis Dalton, that deeply resonated with beliefs and culture of his people, embedded him into the popular consciousness, transforming him quickly into Mahatma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[252]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:God_is_Truth.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2239" data-file-width="3124" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/God_is_Truth.jpg/220px-God_is_Truth.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/God_is_Truth.jpg/330px-God_is_Truth.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/God_is_Truth.jpg/440px-God_is_Truth.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:God_is_Truth.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"God is truth. The way to truth lies through <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a> (nonviolence)" – <a href="/wiki/Sabarmati_Ashram" title="Sabarmati Ashram">Sabarmati</a>, 13 March 1927</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi based <i>Satyagraha</i> on the Vedantic ideal of self-realisation, ahimsa (nonviolence), vegetarianism, and universal love. William Borman states that the key to his <i>satyagraha</i> is rooted in the Hindu <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishadic</a> texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup> According to Indira Carr, Gandhi's ideas on <i>ahimsa</i> and <i>satyagraha</i> were founded on the philosophical foundations of Advaita Vedanta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[254]</a></sup> I. Bruce Watson states that some of these ideas are found not only in traditions within Hinduism, but also in Jainism or Buddhism, particularly those about non-violence, vegetarianism and universal love, but Gandhi's synthesis was to politicise these ideas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Watson_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-256">[255]</a></sup> Gandhi's concept of <i>satya</i> as a civil movement, states Glyn Richards, are best understood in the context of the Hindu terminology of <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/%E1%B9%9Ata" title="Ṛta">Ṛta</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-richards1_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-richards1-257">[256]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi stated that the most important battle to fight was overcoming his own demons, fears, and insecurities. Gandhi summarised his beliefs first when he said "God is Truth". He would later change this statement to "Truth is God". Thus, <i>satya</i> (truth) in Gandhi's philosophy is "God".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parel2006_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-Parel2006-258">[257]</a></sup> Gandhi, states Richards, described the term "God" not as a separate power, but as the Being (Brahman, Atman) of the <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a> tradition, a nondual universal that pervades in all things, in each person and all life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-richards1_257-1"><a href="#cite_note-richards1-257">[256]</a></sup> According to Nicholas Gier, this to Gandhi meant the unity of God and humans, that all beings have the same one soul and therefore equality, that <i>atman</i> exists and is same as everything in the universe, ahimsa (non-violence) is the very nature of this <i>atman</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gier40_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-gier40-259">[258]</a></sup>
</p>
