<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Salt_March.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="933" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="321" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Salt_March.jpg/220px-Salt_March.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Salt_March.jpg/330px-Salt_March.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Salt_March.jpg/440px-Salt_March.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Salt_March.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi picking salt during <a href="/wiki/Salt_March" title="Salt March">Salt Satyagraha</a> to defy colonial law giving salt collection monopoly to the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[259]</a></sup> His <i>satyagraha</i> attracted vast numbers of Indian men and women.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[260]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The essence of <a href="/wiki/Satyagraha" title="Satyagraha">Satyagraha</a> is "soul force" as a political means, refusing to use brute force against the oppressor, seeking to eliminate antagonisms between the oppressor and the oppressed, aiming to transform or "purify" the oppressor. It is not inaction but determined passive resistance and non-co-operation where, states Arthur Herman, "love conquers hate".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[261]</a></sup> A euphemism sometimes used for Satyagraha is that it is a "silent force" or a "soul force" (a term also used by Martin Luther King Jr. during his "<a href="/wiki/I_Have_a_Dream" title="I Have a Dream">I Have a Dream</a>" speech). It arms the individual with moral power rather than physical power. Satyagraha is also termed a "universal force", as it essentially "makes no distinction between kinsmen and strangers, young and old, man and woman, friend and foe."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rules_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-rules-263">[262]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi wrote: "There must be no impatience, no barbarity, no insolence, no undue pressure. If we want to cultivate a true spirit of democracy, we cannot afford to be intolerant. Intolerance betrays want of faith in one's cause."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Civil_disobedience" title="Civil disobedience">Civil disobedience</a> and non-co-operation as practised under Satyagraha are based on the "law of suffering",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CollectedWorks20_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-CollectedWorks20-265">[264]</a></sup> a doctrine that <i>the endurance of suffering is a means to an end</i>. This end usually implies a moral upliftment or progress of an individual or society. Therefore, non-co-operation in Satyagraha is in fact a means to secure the co-operation of the opponent consistently with <a href="/wiki/Truth" title="Truth">truth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Justice" title="Justice">justice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sharma2008_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sharma2008-266">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>While Gandhi's idea of <i>satyagraha</i> as a political means attracted a widespread following among Indians, the support was not universal. For example, Muslim leaders such as Jinnah opposed the <i>satyagraha</i> idea, accused Gandhi to be reviving Hinduism through political activism, and began effort to counter Gandhi with Muslim nationalism and a demand for Muslim homeland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[267]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup> The untouchability leader <a href="/wiki/B._R._Ambedkar" title="B. R. Ambedkar">Ambedkar</a>, in June 1945, after his decision to convert to Buddhism and a key architect of the Constitution of modern India, dismissed Gandhi's ideas as loved by "blind Hindu devotees", primitive, influenced by spurious brew of Tolstoy and Ruskin, and "there is always some simpleton to preach them".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2008p586_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2008p586-270">[269]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[270]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> caricatured Gandhi as a "cunning huckster" seeking selfish gain, an "aspiring dictator", and an "atavistic spokesman of a pagan Hinduism". Churchill stated that the civil disobedience movement spectacle of Gandhi only increased "the danger to which white people there [British India] are exposed".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[271]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Nonviolence">Nonviolence</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_at_Darwen_with_women.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="769" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Gandhi_at_Darwen_with_women.jpg/220px-Gandhi_at_Darwen_with_women.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Gandhi_at_Darwen_with_women.jpg/330px-Gandhi_at_Darwen_with_women.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Gandhi_at_Darwen_with_women.jpg/440px-Gandhi_at_Darwen_with_women.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_at_Darwen_with_women.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi with textile workers at <a href="/wiki/Darwen" title="Darwen">Darwen</a>, Lancashire, 26 September 1931</div></div></div>
<p>Although Gandhi was not the originator of the principle of nonviolence, he was the first to apply it in the political field on a large scale.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup> The concept of nonviolence (<i><a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a></i>) has a long history in Indian religious thought, and is considered the highest dharma (ethical value virtue), a precept to be observed towards all living beings (<i>sarvbhuta</i>), at all times (<i>sarvada</i>), in all respects (<i>sarvatha</i>), in action, words and thought.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[273]</a></sup> Gandhi explains his philosophy and ideas about <i>ahimsa</i> as a political means in his autobiography <i><a href="/wiki/The_Story_of_My_Experiments_with_Truth" title="The Story of My Experiments with Truth">The Story of My Experiments with Truth</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Borman1986_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-Borman1986-275">[274]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Johnson2006_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson2006-277">[276]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi was criticised for refusing to protest the hanging of <a href="/wiki/Bhagat_Singh" title="Bhagat Singh">Bhagat Singh</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sukhdev" title="Sukhdev">Sukhdev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Udham_Singh" title="Udham Singh">Udham Singh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shivaram_Rajguru" title="Shivaram Rajguru">Rajguru</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rai_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rai-279">[278]</a></sup> He was accused of accepting a deal with the King's representative Irwin that released civil disobedience leaders from prison and accepted the death sentence against the highly popular revolutionary Bhagat Singh, who at his trial had replied, "Revolution is the inalienable right of mankind".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghose199_133-1"><a href="#cite_note-ghose199-133">[132]</a></sup> However Congressmen, who were votaries of non-violence, defended Bhagat Singh and other revolutionary nationalists being tried in Lahore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's views came under heavy criticism in Britain when it was under attack from <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, and later when the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust">Holocaust</a> was revealed. He told the British people in 1940, "I would like you to lay down the arms you have as being useless for saving you or humanity. You will invite Herr <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hitler" title="Hitler">Hitler</a> and Signor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mussolini" title="Mussolini">Mussolini</a> to take what they want of the countries you call your possessions... If these gentlemen choose to occupy your homes, you will vacate them. If they do not give you free passage out, you will allow yourselves, man, woman, and child, to be slaughtered, but you will refuse to owe allegiance to them."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolpert2002_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpert2002-281">[280]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_Orwell" title="George Orwell">George Orwell</a> remarked that Gandhi's methods confronted "an old-fashioned and rather shaky despotism which treated him in a fairly chivalrous way", not a totalitarian power, "where political opponents simply disappear."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a post-war interview in 1946, he said, "Hitler killed five million <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a>. It is the greatest crime of our time. But the Jews should have offered themselves to the butcher's knife. They should have thrown themselves into the sea from cliffs... It would have aroused the world and the people of Germany... As it is they succumbed anyway in their millions."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[282]</a></sup> Gandhi believed this act of "collective suicide", in response to the Holocaust, "would have been heroism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="&quot;would have been heroism&quot; does appear to be something Gandhi said, but isn't quoted in the Orwell article (May 2022)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Gandhi as a politician, in practice, settled for less than complete non-violence. His method of non-violent Satyagraha could easily attract masses and it fitted in with the interests and sentiments of business groups, better-off people and dominant sections of peasantry, who did not want an uncontrolled and violent social revolution which could create losses for them. His doctrine of ahimsa lay at the core of unifying role played by the Gandhian Congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup> But during Quit India movement even many staunch Gandhians used 'violent means'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-286">[285]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="On_inter-religious_relations">On inter-religious relations</span></h3>
<h4><span id="Buddhists.2C_Jains_and_Sikhs"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhists,_Jains_and_Sikhs">Buddhists, Jains and Sikhs</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi believed that Buddhism, Jainism and Sikhism were traditions of Hinduism, with a shared history, rites and ideas. At other times, he acknowledged that he knew little about Buddhism other than his reading of <a href="/wiki/Edwin_Arnold" title="Edwin Arnold">Edwin Arnold</a>'s book on it. Based on that book, he considered Buddhism to be a reform movement and the Buddha to be a Hindu.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jordens1998p107_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jordens1998p107-287">[286]</a></sup> He stated he knew Jainism much more, and he credited Jains to have profoundly influenced him. Sikhism, to Gandhi, was an integral part of Hinduism, in the form of another reform movement. Sikh and Buddhist leaders disagreed with Gandhi, a disagreement Gandhi respected as a difference of opinion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jordens1998p107_287-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jordens1998p107-287">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[287]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Muslims">Muslims</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi had generally positive and empathetic views of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, and he extensively studied the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>. He viewed Islam as a faith that proactively promoted peace, and felt that non-violence had a predominant place in the Quran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gorder_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gorder-289">[288]</a></sup> He also read the Islamic prophet <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>'s biography, and argued that it was "not the sword that won a place for Islam in those days in the scheme of life. It was the rigid simplicity, the utter self-effacement of the Prophet, the scrupulous regard for pledges, his intense devotion to his friends and followers, his intrepidity, his fearlessness, his absolute trust in God and in his own mission."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[289]</a></sup> Gandhi had a large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Muslim" title="Indian Muslim">Indian Muslim</a> following, who he encouraged to join him in a mutual nonviolent <a href="/wiki/Jihad" title="Jihad">jihad</a> against the social oppression of their time. Prominent Muslim allies in his nonviolent resistance movement included <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maulana_Abul_Kalam_Azad" title="Maulana Abul Kalam Azad">Maulana Abul Kalam Azad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Ghaffar_Khan" title="Abdul Ghaffar Khan">Abdul Ghaffar Khan</a>. However, Gandhi's empathy towards Islam, and his eager willingness to valorise peaceful Muslim social activists, was viewed by many Hindus as an appeasement of Muslims and later became a leading cause for his assassination at the hands of intolerant <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_extremists" title="Hindu extremists">Hindu extremists</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[290]</a></sup>
</p><p>While Gandhi expressed mostly positive views of Islam, he did occasionally criticise Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gorder_289-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gorder-289">[288]</a></sup> He stated in 1925 that he did not criticise the teachings of the Quran, but he did criticise the interpreters of the Quran. Gandhi believed that numerous interpreters have interpreted it to fit their preconceived notions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[291]</a></sup> He believed Muslims should welcome criticism of the Quran, because "every true scripture only gains from criticism". Gandhi criticised Muslims who "betray intolerance of criticism by a non-Muslim of anything related to Islam", such as the penalty of stoning to death under Islamic law. To Gandhi, Islam has "nothing to fear from criticism even if it be unreasonable".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi2004p193_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi2004p193-293">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nagler17_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-nagler17-294">[293]</a></sup> He also believed there were material contradictions between Hinduism and Islam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nagler17_294-1"><a href="#cite_note-nagler17-294">[293]</a></sup> and he criticised Muslims along with communists that were quick to resort to violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup>
</p><p>One of the strategies Gandhi adopted was to work with Muslim leaders of pre-partition India, to oppose the British imperialism in and outside the Indian subcontinent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paine20_108-4"><a href="#cite_note-paine20-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghosep161_109-4"><a href="#cite_note-ghosep161-109">[109]</a></sup> After the World War I, in 1919–22, he won Muslim leadership support of Ali Brothers by backing the <a href="/wiki/Khilafat_Movement" title="Khilafat Movement">Khilafat Movement</a> in favour the Islamic Caliph and his historic <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Caliphate" title="Ottoman Caliphate">Ottoman Caliphate</a>, and opposing the secular Islam supporting <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Mustafa Kemal Atatürk</a>. By 1924, Atatürk had ended the Caliphate, the Khilafat Movement was over, and Muslim support for Gandhi had largely evaporated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paine20_108-5"><a href="#cite_note-paine20-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghosep161_109-5"><a href="#cite_note-ghosep161-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1925, Gandhi gave another reason to why he got involved in the Khilafat movement and the Middle East affairs between Britain and the Ottoman Empire. Gandhi explained to his co-religionists (Hindu) that he sympathised and campaigned for the Islamic cause, not because he cared for the Sultan, but because "I wanted to enlist the Mussalman's sympathy in the matter of cow protection".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup> According to the historian M. Naeem Qureshi, like the then Indian Muslim leaders who had combined religion and politics, Gandhi too imported his religion into his political strategy during the Khilafat movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1940s, Gandhi pooled ideas with some Muslim leaders who sought religious harmony like him, and opposed the proposed partition of British India into India and Pakistan. For example, his close friend <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khan_Abdul_Ghaffar_Khan" title="Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan">Badshah Khan</a> suggested that they should work towards opening Hindu temples for Muslim prayers, and Islamic mosques for Hindu prayers, to bring the two religious groups closer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup> Gandhi accepted this and began having Muslim prayers read in Hindu temples to play his part, but was unable to get Hindu prayers read in mosques. The Hindu nationalist groups objected and began confronting Gandhi for this one-sided practice, by shouting and demonstrating inside the Hindu temples, in the last years of his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-godse1948_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-godse1948-197">[196]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Christians">Christians</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi criticised as well as praised Christianity. He was critical of Christian missionary efforts in British India, because they mixed medical or education assistance with demands that the beneficiary convert to Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bauman2015p56_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bauman2015p56-302">[301]</a></sup> According to Gandhi, this was not true "service" but one driven by an ulterior motive of luring people into religious conversion and exploiting the economically or medically desperate. It did not lead to inner transformation or moral advance or to the Christian teaching of "love", but was based on false one-sided criticisms of other religions, when Christian societies faced similar problems in South Africa and Europe. It led to the converted person hating his neighbours and other religions, and divided people rather than bringing them closer in compassion. According to Gandhi, "no religious tradition could claim a monopoly over truth or salvation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bauman2015p56_302-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bauman2015p56-302">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[302]</a></sup> Gandhi did not support laws to prohibit missionary activity, but demanded that Christians should first understand the message of Jesus, and then strive to live without stereotyping and misrepresenting other religions. According to Gandhi, the message of Jesus was not to humiliate and imperialistically rule over other people considering them inferior or second class or slaves, but that "when the hungry are fed and peace comes to our individual and collective life, then Christ is born".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coward81_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-coward81-304">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi believed that his long acquaintance with Christianity had made him like it as well as find it imperfect. He asked Christians to stop humiliating his country and his people as heathens, idolators and other abusive language, and to change their negative views of India. He believed that Christians should introspect on the "true meaning of religion" and get a desire to study and learn from Indian religions in the spirit of universal brotherhood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coward81_304-1"><a href="#cite_note-coward81-304">[303]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Eric_J._Sharpe" title="Eric J. Sharpe">Eric Sharpe</a> – a professor of Religious Studies, though Gandhi was born in a Hindu family and later became Hindu by conviction, many Christians in time thought of him as an "exemplary Christian and even as a saint".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[304]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some colonial era Christian preachers and faithfuls considered Gandhi as a saint.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Johnson_2006_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson_2006-306">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Markovits_2004_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-Markovits_2004-307">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rudolph_Rudolph_2010_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rudolph_Rudolph_2010-308">[307]</a></sup> Biographers from France and Britain have drawn parallels between Gandhi and Christian saints. Recent scholars question these romantic biographies and state that Gandhi was neither a Christian figure nor mirrored a Christian saint.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de_Saint-Cheron_2017_p._13_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-de_Saint-Cheron_2017_p._13-309">[308]</a></sup> Gandhi's life is better viewed as exemplifying his belief in the "convergence of various spiritualities" of a Christian and a Hindu, states Michael de Saint-Cheron.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de_Saint-Cheron_2017_p._13_309-1"><a href="#cite_note-de_Saint-Cheron_2017_p._13-309">[308]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Jews">Jews</span></h4>
<p>According to Kumaraswamy, Gandhi initially supported Arab demands with respect to Palestine. He justified this support by invoking Islam, stating that "non-Muslims cannot acquire sovereign jurisdiction" in <i>Jazirat al-Arab</i> (the Arabian Peninsula).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kumaraswamy2010p36_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kumaraswamy2010p36-310">[309]</a></sup> These arguments, states Kumaraswamy, were a part of his political strategy to win Muslim support during the <a href="/wiki/Khilafat_Movement#Khilafat_Movement_in_South_Asia" title="Khilafat Movement">Khilafat movement</a>. In the post-Khilafat period, Gandhi neither negated Jewish demands nor did he use Islamic texts or history to support Muslim claims against Israel. Gandhi's silence after the Khilafat period may represent an evolution in his understanding of the conflicting religious claims over Palestine, according to Kumaraswamy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kumaraswamy2010p36_310-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kumaraswamy2010p36-310">[309]</a></sup> In 1938, Gandhi spoke in favour of Jewish claims, and in March 1946, he said to the Member of British Parliament <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sidney_Silverman" title="Sidney Silverman">Sidney Silverman</a>, "if the Arabs have a claim to Palestine, the Jews have a prior claim", a position very different from his earlier stance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kumaraswamy2010p36_310-2"><a href="#cite_note-Kumaraswamy2010p36-310">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[310]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi discussed the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Germany#Jews_under_the_Nazis_(1933–1939)" title="History of the Jews in Germany">persecution of the Jews in Germany</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Aliyah#Zionist_Aliyah_(1882_on)" title="Aliyah">emigration of Jews from Europe to Palestine</a> through his lens of <a href="/wiki/Satyagraha" title="Satyagraha">Satyagraha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gs_187-1"><a href="#cite_note-gs-187">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup> In 1937, Gandhi discussed <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a> with his close Jewish friend Hermann Kallenbach.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dream_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-dream-313">[312]</a></sup> He said that Zionism was not the right answer to the problems faced by Jews<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jack_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jack-314">[313]</a></sup> and instead recommended Satyagraha. Gandhi thought the Zionists in Palestine represented European imperialism and used violence to achieve their goals; he argued that "the Jews should disclaim any intention of realising their aspiration under the protection of arms and should rely wholly on the goodwill of Arabs. No exception can possibly be taken to the natural desire of the Jews to find a home in Palestine. But they must wait for its fulfilment till Arab opinion is ripe for it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gs_187-2"><a href="#cite_note-gs-187">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1938, Gandhi stated that his "sympathies are all with the Jews. I have known them intimately in South Africa. Some of them became life-long companions." Philosopher <a href="/wiki/Martin_Buber" title="Martin Buber">Martin Buber</a> was highly critical of Gandhi's approach and in 1939 wrote an open letter to him on the subject. Gandhi reiterated his stance that "the Jews seek to convert the Arab heart", and use "<i>satyagraha</i> in confronting the Arabs" in 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[314]</a></sup> According to Simone Panter-Brick, Gandhi's political position on Jewish-Arab conflict evolved over the 1917–1947 period, shifting from a support for the Arab position first, and for the Jewish position in the 1940s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[315]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="On_life.2C_society_and_other_application_of_his_ideas"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="On_life,_society_and_other_application_of_his_ideas">On life, society and other application of his ideas</span></h3>
<h4><span id="Vegetarianism.2C_food.2C_and_animals"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Vegetarianism,_food,_and_animals">Vegetarianism, food, and animals</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi was brought up as a vegetarian by his devout Hindu mother.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kemmerer65_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-kemmerer65-318">[317]</a></sup> The idea of vegetarianism is deeply ingrained in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> Vaishnavism and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jain" title="Jain">Jain</a> traditions in India, such as in his native Gujarat, where meat is considered as a form of food obtained by violence to animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tahtinen1979p62_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tahtinen1979p62-319">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[319]</a></sup> Gandhi's rationale for vegetarianism was largely along those found in Hindu and Jain texts. Gandhi believed that any form of food inescapably harms some form of living organism, but one should seek to understand and reduce the violence in what one consumes because "there is essential unity of all life".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kemmerer65_318-1"><a href="#cite_note-kemmerer65-318">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-terchek204_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-terchek204-321">[320]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi believed that some life forms are more capable of suffering, and non-violence to him meant not having the intent as well as active efforts to minimise hurt, injury or suffering to all life forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-terchek204_321-1"><a href="#cite_note-terchek204-321">[320]</a></sup> Gandhi explored food sources that reduced violence to various life forms in the food chain. He believed that slaughtering animals is unnecessary, as other sources of foods are available.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tahtinen1979p62_319-1"><a href="#cite_note-Tahtinen1979p62-319">[318]</a></sup> He also consulted with vegetarianism campaigners during his lifetime, such as with <a href="/wiki/Henry_Stephens_Salt" title="Henry Stephens Salt">Henry Stephens Salt</a>. Food to Gandhi was not only a source of sustaining one's body, but a source of his impact on other living beings, and one that affected his mind, character and spiritual well being.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[321]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[322]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[323]</a></sup> He avoided not only meat, but also eggs and milk. Gandhi wrote the book <i>The Moral Basis of Vegetarianism</i> and wrote for the London Vegetarian Society's publication.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[324]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyond his religious beliefs, Gandhi stated another motivation for his experiments with diet. He attempted to find the most non-violent vegetarian meal that the poorest human could afford, taking meticulous notes on vegetables and fruits, and his observations with his own body and his <i>ashram</i> in Gujarat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herman89_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-herman89-326">[325]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gandhi328_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-gandhi328-327">[326]</a></sup> He tried fresh and dry fruits (<a href="/wiki/Fruitarianism" title="Fruitarianism">fruitarianism</a>), then just sun dried fruits, before resuming his prior vegetarian diet on advice of his doctor and concerns of his friends. His experiments with food began in the 1890s and continued for several decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herman89_326-1"><a href="#cite_note-herman89-326">[325]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gandhi328_327-1"><a href="#cite_note-gandhi328-327">[326]</a></sup> For some of these experiments, Gandhi combined his own ideas with those found on <a href="/wiki/Mitahara" title="Mitahara">diet</a> in Indian <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">yoga</a> texts. He believed that each vegetarian should experiment with their diet because, in his studies at his <i>ashram</i> he saw "one man's food may be poison for another".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[328]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi championed animal rights in general. Other than making vegetarian choices, he actively campaigned against dissection studies and experimentation on live animals (<a href="/wiki/Vivisection" title="Vivisection">vivisection</a>) in the name of science and medical studies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tahtinen1979p62_319-2"><a href="#cite_note-Tahtinen1979p62-319">[318]</a></sup> He considered it a violence against animals, something that inflicted pain and suffering. He wrote, "Vivisection in my opinion is the blackest of all the blackest crimes that man is at present committing against God and His fair creation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[329]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Fasting">Fasting</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_fasts_undertaken_by_Mahatma_Gandhi" title="List of fasts undertaken by Mahatma Gandhi">List of fasts undertaken by Mahatma Gandhi</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_fasting_1948.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2416" data-file-width="2366" decoding="async" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Gandhi_fasting_1948.jpg/220px-Gandhi_fasting_1948.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Gandhi_fasting_1948.jpg/330px-Gandhi_fasting_1948.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Gandhi_fasting_1948.jpg/440px-Gandhi_fasting_1948.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_fasting_1948.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhi's last political protest using fasting, in January 1948</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi used <a href="/wiki/Fasting" title="Fasting">fasting</a> as a political device, often threatening suicide unless demands were met. Congress publicised the fasts as a political action that generated widespread sympathy. In response, the government tried to manipulate news coverage to minimise his challenge to the Raj. He fasted in 1932 to protest the voting scheme for separate political representation for Dalits; Gandhi did not want them segregated. The British government stopped the London press from showing photographs of his emaciated body, because it would elicit sympathy. Gandhi's 1943 hunger strike took place during a two-year prison term for the anti-colonial Quit India movement. The government called on nutritional experts to demystify his action, and again no photos were allowed. However, his final fast in 1948, after the end of British rule in India, his hunger strike was lauded by the British press and this time did include full-length photos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[330]</a></sup>
</p><p>Alter states that Gandhi's fasting, vegetarianism and diet was more than a political leverage, it was a part of his experiments with self restraint and healthy living. He was "profoundly skeptical of traditional Ayurveda", encouraging it to study the scientific method and adopt its progressive learning approach. Gandhi believed yoga offered health benefits. He believed that a healthy nutritional diet based on regional foods and hygiene were essential to good health.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[331]</a></sup> Recently <a href="/wiki/Indian_Council_of_Medical_Research" title="Indian Council of Medical Research">ICMR</a> made Gandhi's health records public in a book 'Gandhi and Health@150'. These records indicate that despite being underweight at 46.7 kg Gandhi was generally healthy. He avoided modern medication and experimented extensively with water and earth healing. While his cardio records show his heart was normal, there were several instances he suffered from ailments like Malaria and was also operated on twice for piles and appendicitis. Despite health challenges, Gandhi was able to walk about 79000 km in his lifetime which comes to an average of 18 km per day and is equivalent to walking around the earth twice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[332]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Women">Women</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi strongly favoured the emancipation of women, and urged "the women to fight for their own self-development." He opposed <i><a href="/wiki/Purdah" title="Purdah">purdah</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Child_marriage" title="Child marriage">child marriage</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dowry" title="Dowry">dowry</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Sati_(practice)" title="Sati (practice)">sati</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norvell1997_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-Norvell1997-334">[333]</a></sup> A wife is not a slave of the husband, stated Gandhi, but his comrade, better half, colleague and friend, according to Lyn Norvell.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norvell1997_334-1"><a href="#cite_note-Norvell1997-334">[333]</a></sup> In his own life however, according to Suruchi Thapar-Bjorkert, Gandhi's relationship with his wife were at odds with some of these values.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-suruchi77_140-1"><a href="#cite_note-suruchi77-140">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>At various occasions, Gandhi credited his orthodox Hindu mother, and his wife, for first lessons in <i>satyagraha</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kishwar2008p132_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kishwar2008p132-335">[334]</a></sup> He used the legends of Hindu goddess <a href="/wiki/Sita" title="Sita">Sita</a> to expound women's innate strength, autonomy and "lioness in spirit" whose moral compass can make any demon "as helpless as a goat".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kishwar2008p132_335-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kishwar2008p132-335">[334]</a></sup> To Gandhi, the women of India were an important part of the "swadeshi movement" (Buy Indian), and his goal of decolonising the Indian economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kishwar2008p132_335-2"><a href="#cite_note-Kishwar2008p132-335">[334]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some historians such as Angela Woollacott and Kumari Jayawardena state that even though Gandhi often and publicly expressed his belief in the equality of sexes, yet his vision was one of gender difference and complementarity between them. Women, to Gandhi, should be educated to be better in the domestic realm and educate the next generation. His views on women's rights were less liberal and more similar to puritan-Victorian expectations of women, states Jayawardena, than other Hindu leaders with him who supported economic independence and equal gender rights in all aspects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[336]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Brahmacharya:_abstinence_from_sex_and_food">Brahmacharya: abstinence from sex and food</span></h4>
<p>Along with many other texts, Gandhi studied <i>Bhagavad Gita</i> while in South Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-apsharma154_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-apsharma154-338">[337]</a></sup> This Hindu scripture discusses <a href="/wiki/Jnana_yoga" title="Jnana yoga">jnana yoga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_yoga" title="Bhakti yoga">bhakti yoga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karma_yoga" title="Karma yoga">karma yoga</a> along with virtues such as non-violence, patience, integrity, lack of hypocrisy, self restraint and abstinence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[338]</a></sup> Gandhi began experiments with these, and in 1906 at age 37, although married and a father, he vowed to abstain from sexual relations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-apsharma154_338-1"><a href="#cite_note-apsharma154-338">[337]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's experiment with abstinence went beyond sex, and extended to food. He consulted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jain" title="Jain">Jain</a> scholar Rajchandra, whom he fondly called Raychandbhai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[339]</a></sup> Rajchandra advised him that milk stimulated sexual passion. Gandhi began abstaining from cow's milk in 1912, and did so even when doctors advised him to consume milk.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi1957_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi1957-238">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[340]</a></sup> According to Sankar Ghose, Tagore described Gandhi as someone who did not abhor sex or women, but considered sexual life as inconsistent with his moral goals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghose354_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-ghose354-342">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi tried to test and prove to himself his <i>brahmacharya</i>. The experiments began some time after the death of his wife in February 1944. At the start of his experiment, he had women sleep in the same room but in different beds. He later slept with women in the same bed but clothed, and finally, he slept naked with women. In April 1945, Gandhi referenced being naked with several "women or girls" in a letter to Birla as part of the experiments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parekh210_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-parekh210-343">[342]</a></sup> According to the 1960s memoir of his grandniece Manu, Gandhi feared in early 1947 that he and she may be killed by Muslims in the runup to India's independence in August 1947, and asked her when she was 18 years old if she wanted to help him with his experiments to test their "purity", for which she readily accepted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jadadams2012_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-jadadams2012-344">[343]</a></sup> Gandhi slept naked in the same bed with Manu with the bedroom doors open all night. Manu stated that the experiment had no "ill effect" on her. Gandhi also shared his bed with 18-year-old Abha, wife of his grandnephew Kanu. Gandhi would sleep with both Manu and Abha at the same time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jadadams2012_344-1"><a href="#cite_note-jadadams2012-344">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-majumdar224_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-majumdar224-345">[344]</a></sup> None of the women who participated in the <i>brahmachari</i> experiments of Gandhi indicated that they had sex or that Gandhi behaved in any sexual way. Those who went public said they felt as though they were sleeping with their ageing mother.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghose354_342-1"><a href="#cite_note-ghose354-342">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parekh210_343-1"><a href="#cite_note-parekh210-343">[342]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[345]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Sean Scalmer, Gandhi in his final year of life was an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ascetic" title="Ascetic">ascetic</a>, and his sickly skeletal figure was caricatured in Western media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[346]</a></sup> In February 1947, he asked his confidants such as Birla and Ramakrishna if it was wrong for him to experiment his <i>brahmacharya</i> oath.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ghose354_342-2"><a href="#cite_note-ghose354-342">[341]</a></sup> Gandhi's public experiments, as they progressed, were widely discussed and criticised by his family members and leading politicians. However, Gandhi said that if he would not let Manu sleep with him, it would be a sign of weakness. Some of his staff resigned, including two of his newspaper's editors who had refused to print some of Gandhi's sermons dealing with his experiments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jadadams2012_344-2"><a href="#cite_note-jadadams2012-344">[343]</a></sup> Nirmalkumar Bose, Gandhi's Bengali interpreter, for example, criticised Gandhi, not because Gandhi did anything wrong, but because Bose was concerned about the psychological effect on the women who participated in his experiments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-majumdar224_345-1"><a href="#cite_note-majumdar224-345">[344]</a></sup> Veena Howard states Gandhi's views on brahmacharya and religious renunciation experiments were a method to confront women issues in his times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-howard2013_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-howard2013-348">[347]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Untouchability_and_castes">Untouchability and castes</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi spoke out against untouchability early in his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jaffrelotp62_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jaffrelotp62-349">[348]</a></sup> Before 1932, he and his associates used the word <i>antyaja</i> for untouchables. In a major speech on untouchability at <a href="/wiki/Nagpur" title="Nagpur">Nagpur</a> in 1920, Gandhi called it a great evil in Hindu society but observed that it was not unique to Hinduism, having deeper roots, and stated that Europeans in South Africa treated "all of us, Hindus and Muslims, as untouchables; we may not reside in their midst, nor enjoy the rights which they do".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gandhi149_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-gandhi149-350">[349]</a></sup> Calling the doctrine of untouchability intolerable, he asserted that the practice could be eradicated, that Hinduism was flexible enough to allow eradication, and that a concerted effort was needed to persuade people of the wrong and to urge them to eradicate it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gandhi149_350-1"><a href="#cite_note-gandhi149-350">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Christophe_Jaffrelot" title="Christophe Jaffrelot">Christophe Jaffrelot</a>, while Gandhi considered untouchability to be wrong and evil, he believed that caste or class is based on neither inequality nor inferiority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jaffrelotp62_349-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jaffrelotp62-349">[348]</a></sup> Gandhi believed that individuals should freely intermarry whomever they wish, but that no one should expect everyone to be his friend: every individual, regardless of background, has a right to choose whom he will welcome into his home, whom he will befriend, and whom he will spend time with.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jaffrelotp62_349-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jaffrelotp62-349">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gandhi149_350-2"><a href="#cite_note-gandhi149-350">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1932, Gandhi began a new campaign to improve the lives of the untouchables, whom he began to call <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harijan" title="Harijan">harijans</a></i>, "the children of god".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coward2003_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coward2003-351">[350]</a></sup> On 8 May 1933, Gandhi began a 21-day fast of self-purification and launched a year-long campaign to help the <i>harijan</i> movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[351]</a></sup> This campaign was not universally embraced by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dalit_(outcaste)" title="Dalit (outcaste)">Dalit</a> community: Ambedkar and his allies felt Gandhi was being paternalistic and was undermining Dalit political rights. Ambedkar described him as "devious and untrustworthy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GreatSoulReview_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-GreatSoulReview-353">[352]</a></sup> He accused Gandhi as someone who wished to retain the caste system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dirks2011p267_155-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dirks2011p267-155">[154]</a></sup> Ambedkar and Gandhi debated their ideas and concerns, each trying to persuade the other.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[353]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[354]</a></sup> It was during the Harijan tour that he faced the first assassination attempt. While in Poona, a bomb was thrown by an unidentified assailant (described only as a <a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tan%C4%AB" title="Sanātanī">sanatani</a> in the press<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[355]</a></sup>) at a car belonging to his entourage but Gandhi and his family escaped as they were in the car that was following. Gandhi later declared that he "cannot believe that any sane sanatanist could ever encourage the insane act ... The sorrowful incident has undoubtedly advanced the Harijan cause. It is easy to see that causes prosper by the martyrdom of those who stand for them."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[356]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bombay_Chronicle_June_27_1934.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2475" data-file-width="1526" decoding="async" height="357" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Bombay_Chronicle_June_27_1934.jpg/220px-Bombay_Chronicle_June_27_1934.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Bombay_Chronicle_June_27_1934.jpg/330px-Bombay_Chronicle_June_27_1934.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Bombay_Chronicle_June_27_1934.jpg/440px-Bombay_Chronicle_June_27_1934.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bombay_Chronicle_June_27_1934.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Coverage of the assassination attempt, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bombay_Chronicle" title="The Bombay Chronicle">The Bombay Chronicle</a></i>, 27 June 1934</div></div></div>
<p>In 1935, Ambedkar announced his intentions to leave Hinduism and join Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dirks2011p267_155-2"><a href="#cite_note-Dirks2011p267-155">[154]</a></sup> According to Sankar Ghose, the announcement shook Gandhi, who reappraised his views and wrote many essays with his views on castes, intermarriage, and what Hinduism says on the subject. These views contrasted with those of Ambedkar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[357]</a></sup> Yet in the elections of 1937, excepting some seats in Mumbai which Ambedkar's party won, India's untouchables voted heavily in favour of Gandhi's campaign and his party, the Congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[358]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi and his associates continued to consult Ambedkar, keeping him influential. Ambedkar worked with other Congress leaders through the 1940s and wrote large parts of India's constitution in the late 1940s, but did indeed convert to Buddhism in 1956.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dirks2011p267_155-3"><a href="#cite_note-Dirks2011p267-155">[154]</a></sup> According to Jaffrelot, Gandhi's views evolved between the 1920s and 1940s; by 1946, he actively encouraged intermarriage between castes. His approach, too, to untouchability differed from Ambedkar's, championing fusion, choice, and free intermixing, while Ambedkar envisioned each segment of society maintaining its group identity, and each group then separately advancing the "politics of equality".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jaffrelotp62_349-3"><a href="#cite_note-Jaffrelotp62-349">[348]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ambedkar's criticism of Gandhi continued to influence the Dalit movement past Gandhi's death. According to Arthur Herman, Ambedkar's hatred for Gandhi and Gandhi's ideas was so strong that, when he heard of Gandhi's assassination, he remarked after a momentary silence a sense of regret and then added, "My real enemy is gone; thank goodness the eclipse is over now".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herman2008p586_270-1"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2008p586-270">[269]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[359]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Ramachandra_Guha" title="Ramachandra Guha">Ramachandra Guha</a>, "ideologues have carried these old rivalries into the present, with the demonization of Gandhi now common among politicians who presume to speak in Ambedkar's name."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[360]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Nai_Talim.2C_basic_education"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Nai_Talim,_basic_education">Nai Talim, basic education</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Nai_Talim" title="Nai Talim">Nai Talim</a></div>
<p>Gandhi rejected the colonial Western format of the education system. He stated that it led to disdain for manual work, generally created an elite administrative bureaucracy. Gandhi favoured an education system with far greater emphasis on learning skills in practical and useful work, one that included physical, mental and spiritual studies. His methodology sought to treat all professions equal and pay everyone the same.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber80_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-weber80-363">[362]</a></sup> This leads him to create a university in Ahmedabad, <a href="/wiki/Gujarat_Vidyapith" title="Gujarat Vidyapith">Gujarat Vidyapith</a>.
</p><p>Gandhi called his ideas <i>Nai Talim</i> (literally, 'new education'). He believed that the Western style education violated and destroyed the indigenous cultures. A different basic education model, he believed, would lead to better self awareness, prepare people to treat all work equally respectable and valued, and lead to a society with less social diseases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[364]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nai Talim evolved out of his experiences at the <a href="/wiki/Tolstoy_Farm" title="Tolstoy Farm">Tolstoy Farm</a> in South Africa, and Gandhi attempted to formulate the new system at the Sevagram ashram after 1937.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber80_363-1"><a href="#cite_note-weber80-363">[362]</a></sup> Nehru government's vision of an industrialised, centrally <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a> after 1947 had scant place for Gandhi's village-oriented approach.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[365]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his autobiography, Gandhi wrote that he believed every Hindu child must learn <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> because its historic and spiritual texts are in that language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Childhood_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-Childhood-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Swaraj.2C_self-rule"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Swaraj,_self-rule">Swaraj, self-rule</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Swaraj" title="Swaraj">Swaraj</a></div>
<p>Gandhi believed that <i>swaraj</i> not only can be attained with non-violence, but it can also be run with non-violence. A military is unnecessary, because any aggressor can be thrown out using the method of non-violent non-co-operation. While the military is unnecessary in a nation organised under <i>swaraj</i> principle, Gandhi added that a police force is necessary given human nature. However, the state would limit the use of weapons by the police to the minimum, aiming for their use as a restraining force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chakrabarty_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chakrabarty-367">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Gandhi, a non-violent state is like an "ordered anarchy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chakrabarty_367-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chakrabarty-367">[366]</a></sup> In a society of mostly non-violent individuals, those who are violent will sooner or later accept discipline or leave the community, stated Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chakrabarty_367-2"><a href="#cite_note-Chakrabarty-367">[366]</a></sup> He emphasised a society where individuals believed more in learning about their duties and responsibilities, not demanded rights and privileges. On returning from South Africa, when Gandhi received a letter asking for his participation in writing a world charter for human rights, he responded saying, "in my experience, it is far more important to have a charter for human duties."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[367]</a></sup>
</p><p>Swaraj to Gandhi did not mean transferring colonial era British power brokering system, favours-driven, bureaucratic, class exploitative structure and mindset into Indian hands. He warned such a transfer would still be English rule, just without the Englishman. "This is not the Swaraj I want", said Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[368]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[369]</a></sup> Tewari states that Gandhi saw democracy as more than a system of government; it meant promoting both individuality and the self-discipline of the community. Democracy meant settling disputes in a nonviolent manner; it required freedom of thought and expression. For Gandhi, democracy was a way of life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[370]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindu_nationalism_and_revivalism">Hindu nationalism and revivalism</span></h4>
<p>Some scholars state Gandhi supported a religiously diverse India,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[371]</a></sup> while others state that the Muslim leaders who championed the partition and creation of a separate Muslim Pakistan considered Gandhi to be Hindu nationalist or revivalist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[372]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[373]</a></sup> For example, in his letters to Mohammad Iqbal, Jinnah accused Gandhi to be favouring a Hindu rule and revivalism, that Gandhi led Indian National Congress was a fascist party.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[374]</a></sup>
</p><p>In an interview with C.F. Andrews, Gandhi stated that if we believe all religions teach the same message of love and peace between all human beings, then there is neither any rationale nor need for proselytisation or attempts to convert people from one religion to another.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singh79_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-singh79-376">[375]</a></sup> Gandhi opposed missionary organisations who criticised Indian religions then attempted to convert followers of Indian religions to Islam or Christianity. In Gandhi's view, those who attempt to convert a Hindu, "they must harbour in their breasts the belief that Hinduism is an error" and that their own religion is "the only true religion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singh79_376-1"><a href="#cite_note-singh79-376">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[376]</a></sup> Gandhi believed that people who demand religious respect and rights must also show the same respect and grant the same rights to followers of other religions. He stated that spiritual studies must encourage "a Hindu to become a better Hindu, a Mussalman to become a better Mussalman, and a Christian a better Christian."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singh79_376-2"><a href="#cite_note-singh79-376">[375]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Gandhi, religion is not about what a man believes, it is about how a man lives, how he relates to other people, his conduct towards others, and one's relationship to one's conception of god.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parekh82_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-parekh82-378">[377]</a></sup> It is not important to convert or to join any religion, but it is important to improve one's way of life and conduct by absorbing ideas from any source and any religion, believed Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parekh82_378-1"><a href="#cite_note-parekh82-378">[377]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Gandhian_economics">Gandhian economics</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gandhian_economics" title="Gandhian economics">Gandhian economics</a></div>
<p>Gandhi believed in the <i>sarvodaya</i> economic model, which literally means "welfare, upliftment of all".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rivett1_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-rivett1-379">[378]</a></sup> This, states Bhatt, was a very different economic model than the socialism model championed and followed by free India by Nehru – India's first prime minister. To both, according to Bhatt, removing poverty and unemployment were the objective, but the Gandhian economic and development approach preferred adapting technology and infrastructure to suit the local situation, in contrast to Nehru's large scale, socialised state owned enterprises.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[379]</a></sup>
</p><p>To Gandhi, the economic philosophy that aims at "greatest good for the greatest number" was fundamentally flawed, and his alternative proposal <i>sarvodaya</i> set its aim at the "greatest good for all". He believed that the best economic system not only cared to lift the "poor, less skilled, of impoverished background" but also empowered to lift the "rich, highly skilled, of capital means and landlords". Violence against any human being, born poor or rich, is wrong, believed Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rivett1_379-1"><a href="#cite_note-rivett1-379">[378]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[380]</a></sup> He stated that the mandate theory of majoritarian democracy should not be pushed to absurd extremes, individual freedoms should never be denied, and no person should ever be made a social or economic slave to the "resolutions of majorities".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[381]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi challenged Nehru and the modernisers in the late 1930s who called for rapid industrialisation on the Soviet model; Gandhi denounced that as dehumanising and contrary to the needs of the villages where the great majority of the people lived.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[382]</a></sup> After Gandhi's assassination, Nehru led India in accordance with his personal socialist convictions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[384]</a></sup> Historian Kuruvilla <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pandikattu" title="Pandikattu">Pandikattu</a> says "it was Nehru's vision, not Gandhi's, that was eventually preferred by the Indian State."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[385]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi called for ending poverty through improved agriculture and small-scale cottage rural industries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[386]</a></sup> Gandhi's economic thinking disagreed with Marx, according to the political theory scholar and economist <a href="/wiki/Bhikhu_Parekh" title="Bhikhu Parekh">Bhikhu Parekh</a>. Gandhi refused to endorse the view that economic forces are best understood as "antagonistic class interests".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parekh5_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-parekh5-388">[387]</a></sup> He argued that no man can degrade or brutalise the other without degrading and brutalising himself and that sustainable economic growth comes from service, not from exploitation. Further, believed Gandhi, in a free nation, victims exist only when they co-operate with their oppressor, and an economic and political system that offered increasing alternatives gave power of choice to the poorest man.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parekh5_388-1"><a href="#cite_note-parekh5-388">[387]</a></sup>
</p><p>While disagreeing with Nehru about the socialist economic model, Gandhi also critiqued capitalism that was driven by endless wants and a materialistic view of man. This, he believed, created a vicious vested system of materialism at the cost of other human needs, such as spirituality and social relationships.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parekh5_388-2"><a href="#cite_note-parekh5-388">[387]</a></sup> To Gandhi, states Parekh, both communism and capitalism were wrong, in part because both focused exclusively on a materialistic view of man, and because the former deified the state with unlimited power of violence, while the latter deified capital. He believed that a better economic system is one which does not impoverish one's culture and spiritual pursuits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[388]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Gandhism">Gandhism</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gandhism" title="Gandhism">Gandhism</a></div>
<p><i>Gandhism</i> designates the ideas and principles Gandhi promoted; of central importance is nonviolent resistance. A <a href="/wiki/Gandhians" title="Gandhians">Gandhian</a> can mean either an individual who follows, or a specific philosophy which is attributed to, Gandhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hardiman2001_100-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hardiman2001-100">[100]</a></sup> M. M. Sankhdher argues that Gandhism is not a systematic position in metaphysics or in political philosophy. Rather, it is a political creed, an economic doctrine, a religious outlook, a moral precept, and especially, a humanitarian world view. It is an effort not to systematise wisdom but to transform society and is based on an undying faith in the goodness of human nature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[389]</a></sup> However Gandhi himself did not approve of the notion of "Gandhism", as he explained in 1936:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>There is no such thing as "Gandhism", and I do not want to leave any sect after me. I do not claim to have originated any new principle or doctrine. I have simply tried in my own way to apply the eternal truths to our daily life and problems ... The opinions I have formed and the conclusions I have arrived at are not final. I may change them tomorrow. I have nothing new to teach the world. Truth and nonviolence are as old as the hills.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[390]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Literary_works">Literary works</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Young_India.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="484" data-file-width="350" decoding="async" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Young_India.png/170px-Young_India.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Young_India.png/255px-Young_India.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Young_India.png/340px-Young_India.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Young_India.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Young_India" title="Young India">Young India</a></i>, a weekly journal published by Gandhi from 1919 to 1932</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi was a prolific writer. His signature style was simple, precise, clear and as devoid of artificialities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[391]</a></sup> One of Gandhi's earliest publications, <i>Hind Swaraj</i>, published in Gujarati in 1909, became "the intellectual blueprint" for India's independence movement. The book was translated into English the next year, with a copyright legend that read "No Rights Reserved".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ie12_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-ie12-393">[392]</a></sup> For decades he edited several newspapers including <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harijan" title="Harijan">Harijan</a></i> in Gujarati, in <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a> and in the English language; <i><a href="/wiki/Indian_Opinion" title="Indian Opinion">Indian Opinion</a></i> while in South Africa and, <i><a href="/wiki/Young_India" title="Young India">Young India</a></i>, in English, and <i>Navajivan</i>, a Gujarati monthly, on his return to India. Later, <i>Navajivan</i> was also published in Hindi. In addition, he wrote letters almost every day to individuals and newspapers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[393]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi also wrote several books including his autobiography, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Story_of_My_Experiments_with_Truth" title="The Story of My Experiments with Truth">The Story of My Experiments with Truth</a> (Gujarātī "સત્યના પ્રયોગો અથવા આત્મકથા")</i>, of which he bought the entire first edition to make sure it was reprinted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GreatSoulReview_353-1"><a href="#cite_note-GreatSoulReview-353">[352]</a></sup> His other autobiographies included: <i>Satyagraha in South Africa</i> about his struggle there, <i><a href="/wiki/Hind_Swaraj_or_Indian_Home_Rule" title="Hind Swaraj or Indian Home Rule">Hind Swaraj or Indian Home Rule</a></i>, a political pamphlet, and a paraphrase in Gujarati of <a href="/wiki/John_Ruskin" title="John Ruskin">John Ruskin</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Unto_This_Last" title="Unto This Last">Unto This Last</a></i> which was an early <a href="/wiki/Critique_of_political_economy" title="Critique of political economy">critique of political economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unto_this_last_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-Unto_this_last-395">[394]</a></sup> This last essay can be considered his programme on economics. He also wrote extensively on vegetarianism, diet and health, religion, social reforms, etc. Gandhi usually wrote in Gujarati, though he also revised the Hindi and English translations of his books.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pareku_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pareku-396">[395]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's complete works were published by the Indian government under the name <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Collected_Works_of_Mahatma_Gandhi" title="s:The Collected Works of Mahatma Gandhi">The Collected Works of Mahatma Gandhi</a></i> in the 1960s. The writings comprise about 50,000 pages published in about a hundred volumes. In 2000, a revised edition of the complete works sparked a controversy, as it contained a large number of errors and omissions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[396]</a></sup> The Indian government later withdrew the revised edition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[397]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy_and_depictions_in_popular_culture">Legacy and depictions in popular culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_artistic_depictions_of_Mahatma_Gandhi" title="List of artistic depictions of Mahatma Gandhi">List of artistic depictions of Mahatma Gandhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_things_named_after_Mahatma_Gandhi" title="List of things named after Mahatma Gandhi">List of things named after Mahatma Gandhi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_roads_named_after_Mahatma_Gandhi" title="List of roads named after Mahatma Gandhi">List of roads named after Mahatma Gandhi</a></div>
<ul><li>The word <i><a href="/wiki/Mahatma" title="Mahatma">Mahatma</a></i>, while often mistaken for Gandhi's given name in the West, is taken from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskrit_language" title="Sanskrit language">Sanskrit</a> words <i>maha</i> (meaning <i>Great</i>) and <i>atma</i> (meaning <i>Soul</i>). <a href="/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Rabindranath Tagore">Rabindranath Tagore</a> is said to have accorded the title to Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tagore1998_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tagore1998-399">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[b]</a></sup> In his autobiography, Gandhi nevertheless explains that he never valued the title, and was often pained by it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[401]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[403]</a></sup></li>
<li>Innumerable streets, roads and localities in India are named after Gandhi. These include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M.G._Road" title="M.G. Road">M.G.Road</a> (the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Main_street" title="Main street">main street</a> of a number of Indian cities including <a href="/wiki/Mumbai" title="Mumbai">Mumbai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a>), <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Market" title="Gandhi Market">Gandhi Market</a> (near <a href="/wiki/Sion,_Mumbai" title="Sion, Mumbai">Sion</a>, Mumbai) and <a href="/wiki/Gandhinagar" title="Gandhinagar">Gandhinagar</a> (the capital of the state of <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>, Gandhi's birthplace).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup></li>
<li>Florian asteroid <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/120461_Gandhi" title="120461 Gandhi">120461 Gandhi</a> was named in his honour in September 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Followers_and_international_influence">Followers and international influence</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mahatmagandhi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2496" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Mahatmagandhi.jpg/170px-Mahatmagandhi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Mahatmagandhi.jpg/255px-Mahatmagandhi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Mahatmagandhi.jpg/340px-Mahatmagandhi.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mahatmagandhi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Statue" title="Statue">Statue</a> of Mahatma Gandhi at <a href="/wiki/York_University" title="York University">York University</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Soviet_Union_1969_CPA_3793_stamp_(Mahatma_Gandhi).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1009" data-file-width="739" decoding="async" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/The_Soviet_Union_1969_CPA_3793_stamp_%28Mahatma_Gandhi%29.jpg/170px-The_Soviet_Union_1969_CPA_3793_stamp_%28Mahatma_Gandhi%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/The_Soviet_Union_1969_CPA_3793_stamp_%28Mahatma_Gandhi%29.jpg/255px-The_Soviet_Union_1969_CPA_3793_stamp_%28Mahatma_Gandhi%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/The_Soviet_Union_1969_CPA_3793_stamp_%28Mahatma_Gandhi%29.jpg/340px-The_Soviet_Union_1969_CPA_3793_stamp_%28Mahatma_Gandhi%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Soviet_Union_1969_CPA_3793_stamp_(Mahatma_Gandhi).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mahatma Gandhi on a 1969 postage stamp of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Commons.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2616" data-file-width="3488" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Gandhi_Commons.jpg/170px-Gandhi_Commons.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Gandhi_Commons.jpg/255px-Gandhi_Commons.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Gandhi_Commons.jpg/340px-Gandhi_Commons.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Commons.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mahatma Gandhi at Praça Túlio Fontoura, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>, Brazil</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi influenced important leaders and political movements. Leaders of the <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights_movement" title="Civil rights movement">civil rights movement</a> in the United States, including <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_Lawson_(American_activist)" title="James Lawson (American activist)">James Lawson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/James_Bevel" title="James Bevel">James Bevel</a>, drew from the writings of Gandhi in the development of their own theories about nonviolence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[407]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[408]</a></sup> King said "Christ gave us the goals and Mahatma Gandhi the tactics."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tougas2011_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tougas2011-411">[409]</a></sup> King sometimes referred to Gandhi as "the little brown saint."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup> Anti-<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_South_Africa_in_the_Apartheid_Era" title="History of South Africa in the Apartheid Era">apartheid</a> activist and former President of South Africa, <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a>, was inspired by Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mandela-2000_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mandela-2000-413">[411]</a></sup> Others include <a href="/wiki/Steve_Biko" title="Steve Biko">Steve Biko</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vaclav_Havel" title="Vaclav Havel">Vaclav Havel</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[412]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Aung_San_Suu_Kyi" title="Aung San Suu Kyi">Aung San Suu Kyi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his early years, the former <a href="/wiki/President_of_South_Africa" title="President of South Africa">President of South Africa</a> Nelson Mandela was a follower of the nonviolent resistance philosophy of Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mandela-2000_413-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mandela-2000-413">[411]</a></sup> Bhana and Vahed commented on these events as "Gandhi inspired succeeding generations of South African activists seeking to end White rule. This legacy connects him to Nelson Mandela...in a sense, Mandela completed what Gandhi started."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BhanaVahed2005_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-BhanaVahed2005-416">[414]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's life and teachings inspired many who specifically referred to Gandhi as their mentor or who dedicated their lives to spreading Gandhi's ideas.
