In Europe, <a href="/wiki/Romain_Rolland" title="Romain Rolland">Romain Rolland</a> was the first to discuss Gandhi in his 1924 book <i>Mahatma Gandhi,</i> and Brazilian anarchist and feminist <a href="/wiki/Maria_Lacerda_de_Moura" title="Maria Lacerda de Moura">Maria Lacerda de Moura</a> wrote about Gandhi in her work on pacifism. In 1931, notable European physicist <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a> exchanged written letters with Gandhi, and called him "a role model for the generations to come" in a letter writing about him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Albano-Müller_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-Albano-Müller-417">[415]</a></sup> Einstein said of Gandhi:
</p>
<blockquote><p>Mahatma Gandhi's life achievement stands unique in political history. He has invented a completely new and humane means for the liberation war of an oppressed country, and practised it with greatest energy and devotion. The moral influence he had on the consciously thinking human being of the entire civilised world will probably be much more lasting than it seems in our time with its overestimation of brutal violent forces. Because lasting will only be the work of such statesmen who wake up and strengthen the moral power of their people through their example and educational works. We may all be happy and grateful that destiny gifted us with such an enlightened contemporary, a role model for the generations to come.
Generations to come will scarce believe that such a one as this walked the earth in flesh and blood.</p></blockquote>
<p><a href="/wiki/Farah_Omar" title="Farah Omar">Farah Omar</a>, a political activist from <a href="/wiki/Somaliland" title="Somaliland">Somaliland</a> visited India in 1930, where he met Mahatma Gandhi and was influenced by Gandhi's non-violent philosophy which he adopted in his campaign in <a href="/wiki/British_Somaliland" title="British Somaliland">British Somaliland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-418">[416]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Lanza_del_Vasto" title="Lanza del Vasto">Lanza del Vasto</a> went to India in 1936 intending to live with Gandhi; he later returned to Europe to spread Gandhi's philosophy and founded the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_the_Ark" title="Community of the Ark">Community of the Ark</a> in 1948 (modelled after Gandhi's ashrams). <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madeleine_Slade" title="Madeleine Slade">Madeleine Slade</a> (known as "Mirabehn") was the daughter of a British admiral who spent much of her adult life in India as a devotee of Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dhupelia-Mesthrie2005_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dhupelia-Mesthrie2005-419">[417]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[418]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition, the British musician <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a> referred to Gandhi when discussing his views on nonviolence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rolling_Stone_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rolling_Stone-421">[419]</a></sup> In 2007, former US Vice-President and environmentalist <a href="/wiki/Al_Gore" title="Al Gore">Al Gore</a> drew upon Gandhi's idea of <i>satyagraha</i> in a speech on climate change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Al_Gore_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-Al_Gore-422">[420]</a></sup>
</p><p>US President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> in a 2010 address to the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_India" title="Parliament of India">Parliament of India</a> said that:
</p>
<blockquote><p>I am mindful that I might not be standing before you today, as President of the United States, had it not been for Gandhi and the message he shared with America and the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Obama in September 2009 said that his biggest inspiration came from Gandhi. His reply was in response to the question "Who was the one person, dead or live, that you would choose to dine with?". He continued that "He's somebody I find a lot of inspiration in. He inspired Dr. King with his message of nonviolence. He ended up doing so much and changed the world just by the power of his ethics."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wakefield_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wakefield-424">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Time</i> magazine named <a href="/wiki/14th_Dalai_Lama" title="14th Dalai Lama">The 14th Dalai Lama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lech_Wa%C5%82%C4%99sa" title="Lech Wałęsa">Lech Wałęsa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cesar_Chavez" title="Cesar Chavez">Cesar Chavez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aung_San_Suu_Kyi" title="Aung San Suu Kyi">Aung San Suu Kyi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Benigno Aquino Jr.">Benigno Aquino Jr.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Desmond_Tutu" title="Desmond Tutu">Desmond Tutu</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a> as <i>Children of Gandhi</i> and his spiritual heirs to nonviolence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TimeTCOG_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-TimeTCOG-425">[423]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi_District" title="Mahatma Gandhi District">Mahatma Gandhi District</a> in <a href="/wiki/Houston" title="Houston">Houston</a>, Texas, United States, an ethnic Indian enclave, is officially named after Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MorenoCelebrates_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-MorenoCelebrates-426">[424]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's ideas had a significant influence on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/20th-century_philosophy" title="20th-century philosophy">20th-century philosophy</a>. It began with his engagement with <a href="/wiki/Romain_Rolland" title="Romain Rolland">Romain Rolland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Martin_Buber" title="Martin Buber">Martin Buber</a>. <a href="/wiki/Jean-Luc_Nancy" title="Jean-Luc Nancy">Jean-Luc Nancy</a> said that the French philosopher <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Blanchot" title="Maurice Blanchot">Maurice Blanchot</a> engaged critically with Gandhi from the point of view of "European spirituality".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloomsbury_Publishing_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloomsbury_Publishing-427">[425]</a></sup> Since then philosophers including <a href="/wiki/Hannah_Arendt" title="Hannah Arendt">Hannah Arendt</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Etienne_Balibar" title="Etienne Balibar">Etienne Balibar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Slavoj_%C5%BDi%C5%BEek" title="Slavoj Žižek">Slavoj Žižek</a> found that Gandhi was a necessary reference to discuss morality in politics. Recently in the light of climate change Gandhi's views on technology are gaining importance in the fields of <a href="/wiki/Environmental_philosophy" title="Environmental philosophy">environmental philosophy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Philosophy_of_technology" title="Philosophy of technology">philosophy of technology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloomsbury_Publishing_427-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bloomsbury_Publishing-427">[425]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Global_days_that_celebrate_Gandhi">Global days that celebrate Gandhi</span></h3>
<p>In 2007, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">United Nations General Assembly</a> declared Gandhi's birthday 2 October as "the <a href="/wiki/International_Day_of_Non-Violence" title="International Day of Non-Violence">International Day of Nonviolence</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_declares_2_October,_Gandhi's_birthday,_as_International_Day_of_Nonviolence_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_declares_2_October,_Gandhi's_birthday,_as_International_Day_of_Nonviolence-428">[426]</a></sup> First proposed by UNESCO in 1948, as the School Day of Nonviolence and Peace (DENIP in Spanish),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartadelapaz_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-cartadelapaz-429">[427]</a></sup> 30 January is observed as the <a href="/wiki/School_Day_of_Non-violence_and_Peace" title="School Day of Non-violence and Peace">School Day of Nonviolence and Peace</a> in schools of many countries<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DENIP_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-DENIP-430">[428]</a></sup> In countries with a Southern Hemisphere school calendar, it is observed on 30 March.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DENIP_430-1"><a href="#cite_note-DENIP-430">[428]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}html.client-js body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .mbox-text-span{margin-left:23px!important}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}</style><table class="box-Cleanup_rewrite plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg"><img alt="Crystal Clear app kedit.svg" data-file-height="128" data-file-width="128" decoding="async" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/40px-Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/60px-Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/80px-Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png 2x" width="40"/></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article may need to be <b>rewritten</b> to comply with Wikipedia's <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style">quality standards</a>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mahatma_Gandhi&amp;action=edit">You can help</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Talk:Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Talk:Mahatma Gandhi">talk page</a> may contain suggestions.</span> <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">November 2021</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Madrid_-_Plaza_Joan_Mir%C3%B3,_Monumento_a_Mohandas_K._Gandhi_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="1536" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Madrid_-_Plaza_Joan_Mir%C3%B3%2C_Monumento_a_Mohandas_K._Gandhi_2.jpg/170px-Madrid_-_Plaza_Joan_Mir%C3%B3%2C_Monumento_a_Mohandas_K._Gandhi_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Madrid_-_Plaza_Joan_Mir%C3%B3%2C_Monumento_a_Mohandas_K._Gandhi_2.jpg/255px-Madrid_-_Plaza_Joan_Mir%C3%B3%2C_Monumento_a_Mohandas_K._Gandhi_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Madrid_-_Plaza_Joan_Mir%C3%B3%2C_Monumento_a_Mohandas_K._Gandhi_2.jpg/340px-Madrid_-_Plaza_Joan_Mir%C3%B3%2C_Monumento_a_Mohandas_K._Gandhi_2.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Madrid_-_Plaza_Joan_Mir%C3%B3,_Monumento_a_Mohandas_K._Gandhi_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Monument to Gandhi in <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>, Spain</div></div></div>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">magazine</a> named Gandhi the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Time_Magazine_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Magazine Person of the Year">Man of the Year</a> in 1930. In the same magazine's 1999 list of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Most_Important_People_of_the_Century" title="The Most Important People of the Century">The Most Important People of the Century</a>, Gandhi was second only to <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>, who had called Gandhi "the greatest man of our age".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[429]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Nagpur" title="University of Nagpur">University of Nagpur</a> awarded him an <a href="/wiki/Legum_Doctor" title="Legum Doctor">LL.D.</a> in 1937.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[430]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a> awarded the annual <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Peace_Prize" title="Gandhi Peace Prize">Gandhi Peace Prize</a> to distinguished social workers, world leaders and citizens. <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a>, the leader of South Africa's struggle to eradicate racial discrimination and segregation, was a prominent non-Indian recipient. In 2011, <i>Time</i> named Gandhi as one of the top 25 political icons of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[431]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi did not receive the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a>, although he was nominated five times between 1937 and 1948, including the first-ever nomination by the <a href="/wiki/American_Friends_Service_Committee" title="American Friends Service Committee">American Friends Service Committee</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AFSC_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-AFSC-434">[432]</a></sup> though he made the short list only twice, in 1937 and 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tønnesson_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tønnesson-435">[433]</a></sup> Decades later, the Nobel Committee publicly declared its regret for the omission, and admitted to deeply divided nationalistic opinion denying the award.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tønnesson_435-1"><a href="#cite_note-Tønnesson-435">[433]</a></sup> Gandhi was nominated in 1948 but was assassinated before nominations closed. That year, the committee chose not to award the peace prize stating that "there was no suitable living candidate" and later research shows that the possibility of awarding the prize posthumously to Gandhi was discussed and that the reference to no suitable living candidate was to Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tønnesson_435-2"><a href="#cite_note-Tønnesson-435">[433]</a></sup> Geir Lundestad, Secretary of Norwegian Nobel Committee in 2006 said, "The greatest omission in our 106-year history is undoubtedly that Mahatma Gandhi never received the Nobel Peace prize. Gandhi could do without the Nobel Peace prize, whether Nobel committee can do without Gandhi is the question".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[434]</a></sup> When the <a href="/wiki/14th_Dalai_Lama" title="14th Dalai Lama">14th Dalai Lama</a> was awarded the Prize in 1989, the chairman of the committee said that this was "in part a tribute to the memory of Mahatma Gandhi".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tønnesson_435-3"><a href="#cite_note-Tønnesson-435">[433]</a></sup> In the summer of 1995, the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Vegetarian_Society" title="North American Vegetarian Society">North American Vegetarian Society</a> inducted him posthumously into the Vegetarian Hall of Fame.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[435]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Father_of_the_Nation">Father of the Nation</span></h4>
<p>Indians widely describe Gandhi as <a href="/wiki/Father_of_the_Nation" title="Father of the Nation">the father of the nation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive.indianexpress.com_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-archive.indianexpress.com-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-timesofindia.indiatimes.com_16-1"><a href="#cite_note-timesofindia.indiatimes.com-16">[16]</a></sup> Origin of this title is traced back to a radio address (on Singapore radio) on 6 July 1944 by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subhash_Chandra_Bose" title="Subhash Chandra Bose">Subhash Chandra Bose</a> where Bose addressed Gandhi as "The Father of the Nation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[436]</a></sup> On 28 April 1947, <a href="/wiki/Sarojini_Naidu" title="Sarojini Naidu">Sarojini Naidu</a> during a conference also referred Gandhi as "Father of the Nation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Father_of_the_Nation_RTI_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-Father_of_the_Nation_RTI-439">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution_does_not_permit_any_titles_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution_does_not_permit_any_titles-440">[438]</a></sup> However, in response to an <a href="/wiki/Right_to_Information_Act,_2005" title="Right to Information Act, 2005">RTI application</a> in 2012, the Government of India stated that the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_India" title="Constitution of India">Constitution of India</a> did not permit any titles except ones acquired through education or military service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[439]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Film.2C_theatre_and_literature"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Film,_theatre_and_literature">Film, theatre and literature</span></h3>
<p>A five-hour nine-minute long biographical documentary film,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[440]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Mahatma:_Life_of_Gandhi,_1869%E2%80%931948" title="Mahatma: Life of Gandhi, 1869–1948">Mahatma: Life of Gandhi, 1869–1948</a></i>, made by <a href="/wiki/Vithalbhai_Jhaveri" title="Vithalbhai Jhaveri">Vithalbhai Jhaveri</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[441]</a></sup> in 1968, quoting Gandhi's words and using black and white archival footage and photographs, captures the history of those times. <a href="/wiki/Ben_Kingsley" title="Ben Kingsley">Ben Kingsley</a> portrayed him in <a href="/wiki/Richard_Attenborough" title="Richard Attenborough">Richard Attenborough</a>'s 1982 film <i><a href="/wiki/Gandhi_(film)" title="Gandhi (film)">Gandhi</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[442]</a></sup> which won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award">Academy Award</a> for Best Picture. It was based on the biography by <a href="/wiki/Louis_Fischer" title="Louis Fischer">Louis Fischer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[443]</a></sup> The 1996 film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Making_of_the_Mahatma" title="The Making of the Mahatma">The Making of the Mahatma</a></i> documented Gandhi's time in South Africa and his transformation from an inexperienced barrister to recognised political leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Making_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-Making-446">[444]</a></sup> Gandhi was a central figure in the 2006 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">Bollywood</a> comedy film <i><a href="/wiki/Lage_Raho_Munna_Bhai" title="Lage Raho Munna Bhai">Lage Raho Munna Bhai</a></i>. Jahnu Barua's <a href="/wiki/Maine_Gandhi_Ko_Nahin_Mara" title="Maine Gandhi Ko Nahin Mara"><i>Maine Gandhi Ko Nahin Mara</i> (I did not kill Gandhi)</a>, places contemporary society as a backdrop with its vanishing memory of Gandhi's values as a metaphor for the senile forgetfulness of the protagonist of his 2005 film,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[445]</a></sup> writes <a href="/wiki/Vinay_Lal" title="Vinay Lal">Vinay Lal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[446]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1979 opera <i><a href="/wiki/Satyagraha_(opera)" title="Satyagraha (opera)">Satyagraha</a></i> by American composer <a href="/wiki/Philip_Glass" title="Philip Glass">Philip Glass</a> is loosely based on Gandhi's life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KostelanetzFlemming1999_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-KostelanetzFlemming1999-449">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Glass2015_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-Glass2015-450">[448]</a></sup> The opera's libretto, taken from the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a></i>, is sung in the original <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKostelanetzFlemming1999168_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKostelanetzFlemming1999168-451">[449]</a></sup>
</p><p>Anti-Gandhi themes have also been showcased through films and plays. The 1995 Marathi play <i>Gandhi Virudh Gandhi</i> explored the relationship between Gandhi and his son Harilal. The 2007 film, <i><a href="/wiki/Gandhi,_My_Father" title="Gandhi, My Father">Gandhi, My Father</a></i> was inspired on the same theme. The 1989 Marathi play <i><a href="/wiki/Me_Nathuram_Godse_Boltoy" title="Me Nathuram Godse Boltoy">Me Nathuram Godse Boltoy</a></i> and the 1997 Hindi play <i>Gandhi Ambedkar</i> criticised Gandhi and his principles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[450]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[451]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several biographers have undertaken the task of describing Gandhi's life. Among them are D. G. Tendulkar with his <i>Mahatma. Life of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi</i> in eight volumes, <a href="/wiki/Chaman_Nahal" title="Chaman Nahal">Chaman Nahal</a>'s Gandhi Quartet, and <a href="/wiki/Pyarelal_Nayyar" title="Pyarelal Nayyar">Pyarelal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sushila_Nayyar" title="Sushila Nayyar">Sushila Nayyar</a> with their <i>Mahatma Gandhi</i> in 10 volumes. The 2010 biography, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Soul:_Mahatma_Gandhi_and_His_Struggle_With_India" title="Great Soul: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India">Great Soul: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Lelyveld" title="Joseph Lelyveld">Joseph Lelyveld</a> contained controversial material speculating about Gandhi's sexual life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LelyveldNYT_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-LelyveldNYT-454">[452]</a></sup> Lelyveld, however, stated that the press coverage "grossly distort[s]" the overall message of the book.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LelyveldResponse_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-LelyveldResponse-455">[453]</a></sup> The 2014 film <i><a href="/wiki/Welcome_Back_Gandhi" title="Welcome Back Gandhi">Welcome Back Gandhi</a></i> takes a fictionalised look at how Gandhi might react to modern day India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[454]</a></sup> The 2019 play <i>Bharat Bhagya Vidhata</i>, inspired by <a href="/wiki/Rakesh_Jhaveri" title="Rakesh Jhaveri">Pujya Gurudevshri Rakeshbhai</a> and produced by <a href="/wiki/Sangeet_Natak_Akademi" title="Sangeet Natak Akademi">Sangeet Natak Akademi</a> and Shrimad Rajchandra Mission Dharampur takes a look at how Gandhi cultivated the values of truth and non-violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[455]</a></sup>
</p><p>"Mahatma Gandhi" is used by <a href="/wiki/Cole_Porter" title="Cole Porter">Cole Porter</a> in his lyrics for the song <a href="/wiki/You%27re_the_Top" title="You're the Top">You're the Top</a> which is included in the 1934 musical <a href="/wiki/Anything_Goes" title="Anything Goes">Anything Goes</a>. In the song, Porter rhymes "Mahatma Gandhi' with "Napoleon Brandy."
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Current_impact_within_India">Current impact within India</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Memorial_Kanyakumari.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="467" data-file-width="688" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Gandhi_Memorial_Kanyakumari.jpg/220px-Gandhi_Memorial_Kanyakumari.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Gandhi_Memorial_Kanyakumari.jpg/330px-Gandhi_Memorial_Kanyakumari.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Gandhi_Memorial_Kanyakumari.jpg/440px-Gandhi_Memorial_Kanyakumari.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Memorial_Kanyakumari.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Mandapam_(Chennai)" title="Gandhi Mandapam (Chennai)">Gandhi Mandapam</a>, a temple in <a href="/wiki/Kanyakumari" title="Kanyakumari">Kanyakumari</a> was erected in honour of Gandhi</div></div></div>
<p>India, with its rapid economic modernisation and urbanisation, has rejected <a href="/wiki/Gandhian_economics" title="Gandhian economics">Gandhi's economics</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[456]</a></sup> but accepted much of his politics and continues to revere his memory. Reporter Jim Yardley notes that, "modern India is hardly a Gandhian nation, if it ever was one. His vision of a village-dominated economy was shunted aside during his lifetime as rural romanticism, and his call for a national ethos of personal austerity and nonviolence has proved antithetical to the goals of an aspiring economic and military power." By contrast, Gandhi is "given full credit for India's political identity as a tolerant, secular democracy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Obama_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-Obama-459">[457]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's birthday, 2 October, is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_holiday_in_India" title="National holiday in India">national holiday in India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Jayanti" title="Gandhi Jayanti">Gandhi Jayanti</a>. Gandhi's image also appears on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi_Series_(banknotes)" title="Mahatma Gandhi Series (banknotes)">paper currency of all denominations</a> issued by <a href="/wiki/Reserve_Bank_of_India" title="Reserve Bank of India">Reserve Bank of India</a>, except for the <a href="/wiki/Indian_1-rupee_note" title="Indian 1-rupee note">one rupee note</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rbi_notes_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-rbi_notes-460">[458]</a></sup> Gandhi's date of death, 30 January, is commemorated as a <a href="/wiki/Martyrs%27_Day_(India)" title="Martyrs' Day (India)">Martyrs' Day</a> in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MDay_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-MDay-461">[459]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are three temples in India dedicated to Gandhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GandhiGod_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-GandhiGod-462">[460]</a></sup> One is located at <a href="/wiki/Sambalpur" title="Sambalpur">Sambalpur</a> in Odisha and the second at Nidaghatta village near Kadur in <a href="/wiki/Chikmagalur" title="Chikmagalur">Chikmagalur</a> district of <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a> and the third one at <a href="/wiki/Chityal,_Nalgonda_district" title="Chityal, Nalgonda district">Chityal</a> in the district of <a href="/wiki/Nalgonda_district" title="Nalgonda district">Nalgonda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Telangana" title="Telangana">Telangana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GandhiGod_462-1"><a href="#cite_note-GandhiGod-462">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[461]</a></sup> The Gandhi Memorial in <a href="/wiki/Kanyakumari" title="Kanyakumari">Kanyakumari</a> resembles central Indian Hindu temples and the <a href="/wiki/Tamukkam_Palace" title="Tamukkam Palace">Tamukkam or Summer Palace</a> in <a href="/wiki/Madurai" title="Madurai">Madurai</a> now houses the Mahatma Gandhi Museum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AbramEdwards2003_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-AbramEdwards2003-464">[462]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Descendants">Descendants</span></h3>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_family_tree.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="778" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="311" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Gandhi_family_tree.jpg/440px-Gandhi_family_tree.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Gandhi_family_tree.jpg/660px-Gandhi_family_tree.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Gandhi_family_tree.jpg/880px-Gandhi_family_tree.jpg 2x" width="440"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_family_tree.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Family tree of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi and <a href="/wiki/Kasturba_Gandhi" title="Kasturba Gandhi">Kasturba Gandhi</a> (source: Gandhi Ashram Sabarmati)</div></div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi's children and grandchildren live in India and other countries. Grandson <a href="/wiki/Rajmohan_Gandhi" title="Rajmohan Gandhi">Rajmohan Gandhi</a> is a professor in <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a> and an author of Gandhi's biography titled <i>Mohandas</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[463]</a></sup> while another, Tarun Gandhi, has authored several authoritative books on his grandfather. Another grandson, Kanu Ramdas Gandhi (the son of Gandhi's third son <a href="/wiki/Ramdas_Gandhi" title="Ramdas Gandhi">Ramdas</a>), was found living in an old age home in <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">Delhi</a> despite having taught earlier in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[464]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[465]</a></sup>
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Explanatory_notes">Explanatory notes</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">

</li>

<li id="cite_note-GangulyDocker20082-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-GangulyDocker20082_5-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFGangulyDocker2008">Ganguly, Debjani; Docker, John (2008), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=cId9AgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA4" rel="nofollow"><i>Rethinking Gandhi and Nonviolent Relationality: Global Perspectives</i></a>, Routledge, pp. 4–, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-134-07431-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-134-07431-0"><bdi>978-1-134-07431-0</bdi></a></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Rethinking+Gandhi+and+Nonviolent+Relationality%3A+Global+Perspectives&amp;rft.pages=4-&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-134-07431-0&amp;rft.aulast=Ganguly&amp;rft.aufirst=Debjani&amp;rft.au=Docker%2C+John&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DcId9AgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span> Quote: "... marks Gandhi as a hybrid cosmopolitan figure who transformed ... anti-colonial nationalist politics in the twentieth-century in ways that neither indigenous nor westernized Indian nationalists could."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Parel20162-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Parel20162_6-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFParel2016">Parel, Anthony J (2016), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=bMGSDAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA202" rel="nofollow"><i>Pax Gandhiana: The Political Philosophy of Mahatma Gandhi</i></a>, Oxford University Press, pp. 202–, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-049146-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-049146-8"><bdi>978-0-19-049146-8</bdi></a></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pax+Gandhiana%3A+The+Political+Philosophy+of+Mahatma+Gandhi&amp;rft.pages=202-&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-049146-8&amp;rft.aulast=Parel&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthony+J&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DbMGSDAAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA202&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span> Quote: "Gandhi staked his reputation as an original political thinker on this specific issue. Hitherto, violence had been used in the name of political rights, such as in street riots, regicide, or armed revolutions. Gandhi believes there is a better way of securing political rights, that of nonviolence, and that this new way marks an advance in political ethics."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Stein20102-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Stein20102_7-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFStein2010"><a href="/wiki/Burton_Stein" title="Burton Stein">Stein, Burton</a> (2010), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QY4zdTDwMAQC&amp;pg=GBS.PA289" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of India</i></a>, John Wiley &amp; Sons, pp. 289–, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4443-2351-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4443-2351-1"><bdi>978-1-4443-2351-1</bdi></a>, <q>Gandhi was the leading genius of the later, and ultimately successful, campaign for India's independence.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+India&amp;rft.pages=289-&amp;rft.pub=John+Wiley+%26+Sons&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4443-2351-1&amp;rft.aulast=Stein&amp;rft.aufirst=Burton&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQY4zdTDwMAQC%26pg%3DGBS.PA289&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-McGregor19932-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-McGregor19932_8-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMcGregor1993">McGregor, Ronald Stuart (1993). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/oxfordhindiengli00mcgr_0" rel="nofollow"><i>The Oxford Hindi-English Dictionary</i></a></span>. Oxford University Press. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/oxfordhindiengli00mcgr_0/page/799" rel="nofollow">799</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-864339-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-864339-5"><bdi>978-0-19-864339-5</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 August</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Hindi-English+Dictionary&amp;rft.pages=799&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1993&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-864339-5&amp;rft.aulast=McGregor&amp;rft.aufirst=Ronald+Stuart&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Foxfordhindiengli00mcgr_0&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span> Quote: (<i>mahā-</i> (S. "great, mighty, large, ..., eminent") + <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">ātmā</a></i> (S. "<b>1.</b> soul, spirit; the self, the individual; the mind, the heart; <i>2.</i> the ultimate being."): "high-souled, of noble nature; a noble or venerable man."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-rajmohan_gandhi_p1722-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-rajmohan_gandhi_p1722_9-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGandhi2006"><a href="/wiki/Rajmohan_Gandhi" title="Rajmohan Gandhi">Gandhi, Rajmohan</a> (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=FauJL7LKXmkC&amp;pg=PA172" rel="nofollow"><i>Gandhi: The Man, His People, and the Empire</i></a>. p. 172. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-520-25570-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-520-25570-8"><bdi>978-0-520-25570-8</bdi></a>. <q>...Kasturba would accompany Gandhi on his departure from <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">Cape Town</a> for <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> in July 1914 <i>en route</i> to India. ... In different South African towns (<a href="/wiki/Pretoria" title="Pretoria">Pretoria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">Cape Town</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bloemfontein" title="Bloemfontein">Bloemfontein</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">Johannesburg</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/KwaZulu-Natal" title="KwaZulu-Natal">Natal</a> cities of <a href="/wiki/Durban" title="Durban">Durban</a> and <a href="/wiki/Verulam,_KwaZulu-Natal" title="Verulam, KwaZulu-Natal">Verulam</a>), the struggle's martyrs were honoured and the Gandhi's bade farewell. Addresses in <a href="/wiki/Durban" title="Durban">Durban</a> and Verulam referred to Gandhi as a 'Mahatma', 'great soul'. He was seen as a great soul because he had taken up the poor's cause. The whites too said good things about Gandhi, who predicted a future for the Empire if it respected justice.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Gandhi%3A+The+Man%2C+His+People%2C+and+the+Empire&amp;rft.pages=172&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-520-25570-8&amp;rft.aulast=Gandhi&amp;rft.aufirst=Rajmohan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DFauJL7LKXmkC%26pg%3DPA172&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Khan2007-page1-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Khan2007-page1_10-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Khan2007-page1_10-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Khan2007-page1_10-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKhan2007">Khan, Yasmin (2007). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/greatpartitionma00khan/page/18" rel="nofollow"><i>The Great Partition: The Making of India and Pakistan</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Yale_University_Press" title="Yale University Press">Yale University Press</a>. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/greatpartitionma00khan/page/18" rel="nofollow">18</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-300-12078-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-300-12078-3"><bdi>978-0-300-12078-3</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 September</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Great+Partition%3A+The+Making+of+India+and+Pakistan&amp;rft.pages=18&amp;rft.pub=Yale+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-300-12078-3&amp;rft.aulast=Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Yasmin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fgreatpartitionma00khan%2Fpage%2F18&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span> Quote: "the Muslim League had only caught on among South Asian Muslims during the Second World War. ... By the late 1940s, the League and the Congress had impressed in the British their own visions of a free future for Indian people. ... one, articulated by the Congress, rested on the idea of a united, plural India as a home for all Indians and the other, spelt out by the League, rested on the foundation of Muslim nationalism and the carving out of a separate Muslim homeland." (p. 18)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-autogenerated3-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-autogenerated3_11-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKhan2007">Khan, Yasmin (2007). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/greatpartitionma00khan" rel="nofollow"><i>The Great Partition: The Making of India and Pakistan</i></a></span>. <a href="/wiki/Yale_University_Press" title="Yale University Press">Yale University Press</a>. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/greatpartitionma00khan/page/n30" rel="nofollow">1</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-300-12078-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-300-12078-3"><bdi>978-0-300-12078-3</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 September</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Great+Partition%3A+The+Making+of+India+and+Pakistan&amp;rft.pages=1&amp;rft.pub=Yale+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-300-12078-3&amp;rft.aulast=Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Yasmin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fgreatpartitionma00khan&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span> Quote: "South Asians learned that the British Indian Empire would be partitioned on 3 June 1947. They heard about it on the radio, from relations and friends, by reading newspapers and, later, through government pamphlets. Among a population of almost four hundred million, where the vast majority lived in the countryside, ..., it is hardly surprising that many ... did not hear the news for many weeks afterward. For some, the butchery and forced relocation of the summer months of 1947 may have been the first they know about the creation of the two new states rising from the fragmentary and terminally weakened British empire in India." (p. 1)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Brown1991-p380-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Brown1991-p380_12-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Brown1991-p380_12-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Brown1991-p380_12-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#Brown1991">Brown (1991)</a>, p. 380: "Despite and indeed because of his sense of helplessness Delhi was to be the scene of what he called his greatest fast. ... His decision was made suddenly, though after considerable thought – he gave no hint of it even to Nehru and Patel who were with him shortly before he announced his intention at a prayer-meeting on 12 January 1948. He said he would fast until communal peace was restored, real peace rather than the calm of a dead city imposed by police and troops. Patel and the government took the fast partly as condemnation of their decision to withhold a considerable cash sum still outstanding to Pakistan as a result of the allocation of undivided India's assets because the hostilities that had broken out in Kashmir; ... But even when the government agreed to pay out the cash, Gandhi would not break his fast: that he would only do after a large number of important politicians and leaders of communal bodies agreed to a joint plan for restoration of normal life in the city."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-talbot-singh-delhi-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-talbot-singh-delhi_13-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFTalbotSingh2009">Talbot, Ian; Singh, Gurharpal (2009), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=utKmPQAACAAJ&amp;pg=PA118" rel="nofollow"><i>The Partition of India</i></a>, Cambridge University Press, pp. 118–119, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85661-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85661-4"><bdi>978-0-521-85661-4</bdi></a>, <q>It is now almost a cliché that the Partition transformed Delhi from a Mughal to a Punjabi city. The bitter experiences of the refugees encouraged them to support right-wing Hindu parties. ... Trouble began in September (1947) after the arrival from refugees from Pakistan who were determined on revenge and driving Muslims out of properties which they could then occupy. Gandhi in his prayer meetings in Birla House denounced the 'crooked and ungentlemanly' squeezing out of Muslims. Despite these exhortations, two-thirds of the city's Muslims were to eventually abandon India's capital.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Partition+of+India&amp;rft.pages=118-119&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-85661-4&amp;rft.aulast=Talbot&amp;rft.aufirst=Ian&amp;rft.au=Singh%2C+Gurharpal&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DutKmPQAACAAJ%26pg%3DPA118&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-CushRobinson2008-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CushRobinson2008_14-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCushRobinsonYork2008">Cush, Denise; Robinson, Catherine; York, Michael (2008). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=i_T0HeWE-EAC&amp;pg=PA544" rel="nofollow"><i>Encyclopedia of Hinduism</i></a>. Taylor &amp; Francis. p. 544. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7007-1267-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7007-1267-0"><bdi>978-0-7007-1267-0</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131012221104/http://books.google.com/books?id=i_T0HeWE-EAC&amp;pg=PA544" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 12 October 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 August</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+Hinduism&amp;rft.pages=544&amp;rft.pub=Taylor+%26+Francis&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7007-1267-0&amp;rft.aulast=Cush&amp;rft.aufirst=Denise&amp;rft.au=Robinson%2C+Catherine&amp;rft.au=York%2C+Michael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Di_T0HeWE-EAC%26pg%3DPA544&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span> Quote: "The apotheosis of this contrast is the assassination of Gandhi in 1948 by a militant Nathuram Godse, on the basis of his 'weak' accommodationist approach towards the new state of Pakistan." (p. 544)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-archive.indianexpress.com-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-archive.indianexpress.com_15-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-archive.indianexpress.com_15-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140906121950/http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/gandhi-not-formally-conferred-father-of-the-nation-title-govt/973101" rel="nofollow">"Gandhi not formally conferred 'Father of the Nation' title: Govt"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Indian_Express" title="The Indian Express">The Indian Express</a></i>. 11 July 2012. </li>
<li id="cite_note-timesofindia.indiatimes.com-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-timesofindia.indiatimes.com_16-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-timesofindia.indiatimes.com_16-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170107223546/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Constitution-doesnt-permit-Father-of-the-Nation-title-Government/articleshow/16961980.cms" rel="nofollow">"Constitution doesn't permit 'Father of the Nation' title: Government"</a>. <i>The Times of India</i>. 26 October 2012. <li id="cite_note-Nehru-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Nehru_17-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFNehru">Nehru, Jawaharlal. <i>An Autobiography</i>. Bodley Head.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+Autobiography&amp;rft.pub=Bodley+Head&amp;rft.aulast=Nehru&amp;rft.aufirst=Jawaharlal&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-McAllister1982-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-McAllister1982_18-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-McAllister1982_18-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMcAllister1982">McAllister, Pam (1982). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/reweavingwebofli00mcal" rel="nofollow"><i>Reweaving the Web of Life: Feminism and Nonviolence</i></a></span>. New Society Publishers. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/reweavingwebofli00mcal/page/194" rel="nofollow">194</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-86571-017-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-86571-017-7"><bdi>978-0-86571-017-7</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 August</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Reweaving+the+Web+of+Life%3A+Feminism+and+Nonviolence&amp;rft.pages=194&amp;rft.pub=New+Society+Publishers&amp;rft.date=1982&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-86571-017-7&amp;rft.aulast=McAllister&amp;rft.aufirst=Pam&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Freweavingwebofli00mcal&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span> Quote: "With love, Yours, Bapu (You closed with the term of endearment used by your close friends, the term you used with all the movement leaders, roughly meaning 'Papa'." Another letter written in 1940 shows similar tenderness and caring.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Eck2003-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Eck2003_19-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFEck2003"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diana_Eck" title="Diana Eck">Eck, Diana L.</a> (2003). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=XpR0AmKLeY4C&amp;pg=PA210" rel="nofollow"><i>Encountering God: A Spiritual Journey from Bozeman to Banaras</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Beacon_Press" title="Beacon Press">Beacon Press</a>. p. 210. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8070-7301-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8070-7301-8"><bdi>978-0-8070-7301-8</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131012220529/http://books.google.com/books?id=XpR0AmKLeY4C&amp;pg=PA210" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 12 October 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 August</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encountering+God%3A+A+Spiritual+Journey+from+Bozeman+to+Banaras&amp;rft.pages=210&amp;rft.pub=Beacon+Press&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8070-7301-8&amp;rft.aulast=Eck&amp;rft.aufirst=Diana+L.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DXpR0AmKLeY4C%26pg%3DPA210&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span> Quote: "... his niece Manu, who, like others called this immortal Gandhi 'Bapu,' meaning not 'father,' but the familiar, 'daddy'." (p. 210)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Gandhi_name-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Gandhi_name_20-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTodd2012">Todd, Anne M. (2012). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=svxDMQZ7fakC&amp;pg=PA8" rel="nofollow"><i>Mohandas Gandhi</i></a>. Infobase Publishing. p. 8. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4381-0662-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4381-0662-5"><bdi>978-1-4381-0662-5</bdi></a>. <q>The name Gandhi means "grocer", although Mohandas's father and grandfather were politicians not grocers.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Mohandas+Gandhi&amp;rft.pages=8&amp;rft.pub=Infobase+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4381-0662-5&amp;rft.aulast=Todd&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne+M.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DsvxDMQZ7fakC%26pg%3DPA8&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Gandhi_DOB-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Gandhi_DOB_21-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFRajmohan2006">Gandhi, Rajmohan (2006)</a> <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=FauJL7LKXmkC" rel="nofollow">pp. 1–3</a>.</span>

<li id="cite_note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGuha2014">Guha, Ramachandra (15 October 2014). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=XS7UAAAAQBAJ&amp;q=%22the+subcaste+the+Gandhis+belonged+to+was+known+as+Modh+Bania,+the+prefix%22&amp;pg=PP42" rel="nofollow"><i>Gandhi before India</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-37">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGerard_Toffin2012">Gerard Toffin (2012). Joseph (eds.), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kcpDOVk5Gp8C&amp;pg=PA96" rel="nofollow"><i>Meditations on Gandhi : a Ravindra Varma festschrift</i></a>, New Delhi: Concept, pp. 96–112, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-7022-961-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-7022-961-2"><bdi>978-81-7022-961-2</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">8 September</span> 2012</span></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Gandhi+and+Tolstoy&amp;rft.btitle=Meditations+on+Gandhi+%3A+a+Ravindra+Varma+festschrift&amp;rft.place=New+Delhi&amp;rft.pages=96-112&amp;rft.pub=Concept&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-7022-961-2&amp;rft.aulast=Parel&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthony+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DkcpDOVk5Gp8C%26pg%3DPA96&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>

Appeal for enlistment", Nadiad, 22 June 1918.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-CollectedWorks17c-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CollectedWorks17c_99-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Gandhi (1965), <i>Collected Works</i>, <a class="external text" href="http://www.gandhiserve.org/cwmg/VOL017.PDF" rel="nofollow">Vol 17.</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20091015235028/http://www.gandhiserve.org/cwmg/VOL017.PDF" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 15 October 2009 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> "Chapter 8. Letter to J. L. Maffey", Nadiad, 30 April 1918.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-110">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRoderick_Matthews2012">Roderick Matthews (2012). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=r9A4AgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT31" rel="nofollow"><i>Jinnah vs. Gandhi</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-117">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAkbar_S._Ahmed1997">Akbar S. </li>
<li id="cite_note-152"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-152">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/blue-plaques/mahatma-gandhi-kingsley-hall/" rel="nofollow">"Mahatma Gandhi | Philosopher &amp; Teacher | Blue Plaques"</a>. <i>English Heritage</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2006-186"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-MetcalfMetcalf2006_186-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMetcalfMetcalf2006">Metcalf, Barbara Daly; Metcalf, Thomas R. <li id="cite_note-Khan2011-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Khan2011_203-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFKhan2011">Khan, Yasmin (2011). "Performing Peace: Gandhi's assassination as a critical moment in the consolidation of the Nehruvian state". <i><a href="/wiki/Modern_Asian_Studies" title="Modern Asian Studies">Modern Asian Studies</a></i>. <b>45</b> (1): 57–80. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FS0026749X10000223" rel="nofollow">10.1017/S0026749X10000223</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:144894540" rel="nofollow">144894540</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Modern+Asian+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=Performing+Peace%3A+Gandhi%27s+assassination+as+a+critical+moment+in+the+consolidation+of+the+Nehruvian+state&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=57-80&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FS0026749X10000223&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A144894540%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.aulast=Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Yasmin&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span> <span style="font-size:0.95em; font-size:95%; color:#555">(subscription required)</span></span>

<li id="cite_note-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-213">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLal,_Vinay2001">Lal, Vinay (January 2001). <a class="external text" href="http://www.sscnet.ucla.edu/southasia/History/Gandhi/HeRam_gandhi.html" rel="nofollow">"<span class="cs1-kern-left"></span>'Hey Ram': The Politics of Gandhi's Last Words"</a>. <i>Humanscape</i>. <b>8</b> (1): 34–38. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20040604013327/http://www.sscnet.ucla.edu/southasia/History/Gandhi/HeRam_gandhi.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 4 June 2004.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Humanscape&amp;rft.atitle=%27Hey+Ram%27%3A+The+Politics+of+Gandhi%27s+Last+Words&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=34-38&amp;rft.date=2001-01&amp;rft.au=Lal%2C+Vinay&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sscnet.ucla.edu%2Fsouthasia%2FHistory%2FGandhi%2FHeRam_gandhi.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-214"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-214">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWilliam_Borman1986">William Borman (1986). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/gandhinonviolenc0000borm" rel="nofollow"><i>Gandhi and Non-Violence</i></a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_University_of_New_York_Press" title="State University of New York Press">State University of New York Press</a>. pp. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/gandhinonviolenc0000borm/page/192" rel="nofollow">192</a>–95, 208–29. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-88706-331-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-88706-331-2"><bdi>978-0-88706-331-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Gandhi+and+Non-Violence&amp;rft.pages=192-95%2C+208-29&amp;rft.pub=State+University+of+New+York+Press&amp;rft.date=1986&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-88706-331-2&amp;rft.au=William+Borman&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fgandhinonviolenc0000borm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-215"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-215">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDennis_Dalton2012">Dennis Dalton (2012). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=KxUp1igCL_0C" rel="nofollow"><i>Mahatma Gandhi: Nonviolent Power in Action</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University_Press" title="Columbia University Press">Columbia University Press</a>. pp. 30–35. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-231-15959-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-231-15959-3"><bdi>978-0-231-15959-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Mahatma+Gandhi%3A+Nonviolent+Power+in+Action&amp;rft.pages=30-35&amp;rft.pub=Columbia+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-231-15959-3&amp;rft.au=Dennis+Dalton&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DKxUp1igCL_0C&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span>, Quote: "Yet he [Gandhi] must bear some of the responsibility for losing his followers along the way. The sheer vagueness and contradictions recurrent throughout his writing made it easier to accept him as a saint than to fathom the challenge posed by his demanding beliefs. Gandhi saw no harm in self-contradictions: life was a series of experiments, and any principle might change if Truth so dictated".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-brown93-216"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-brown93_216-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-brown93_216-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBrown,_Judith_M.Parel,_Anthony2011">Brown, Judith M. &amp; Parel, Anthony (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=KLM8kMZZu-IC&amp;pg=PA93" rel="nofollow"><i>The Cambridge Companion to Gandhi</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>. p. 93. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-13345-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-13345-6"><bdi>978-0-521-13345-6</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Cambridge+Companion+to+Gandhi&amp;rft.pages=93&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-13345-6&amp;rft.au=Brown%2C+Judith+M.&amp;rft.au=Parel%2C+Anthony&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DKLM8kMZZu-IC%26pg%3DPA93&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-217"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-217">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFIndira_Carr2012">Indira Carr (2012). (eds.). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=UZQqBgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA263" rel="nofollow"><i>Biographical Dictionary of Twentieth-Century Philosophers</i></a>. Routledge. pp. 263–64. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-134-92796-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-134-92796-8"><bdi>978-1-134-92796-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Biographical+Dictionary+of+Twentieth-Century+Philosophers&amp;rft.pages=263-64&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-134-92796-8&amp;rft.au=Indira+Carr&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DUZQqBgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA263&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span>, Quote: "Gandhi, Mohandas Karamchand. Indian. born: 2 October 1869, Gujarat; (...) Influences: <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-218"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-218">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJ._Jordens1998">J. <li id="cite_note-Spodek-230"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Spodek_230-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSpodek1971">Spodek, Howard (1971). </li>
<li id="cite_note-231"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-231">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFB._Srinivasa_Murthy1987">B. <li id="cite_note-244"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-244">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRichard_H._Davis2014">Richard H. <li id="cite_note-245"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-245">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSuhrud2018"><a href="/wiki/Tridip_Suhrud" title="Tridip Suhrud">Suhrud, Tridip</a> (November–December 2018). </li>
<li id="cite_note-246"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-246">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFChatterjee2005">Chatterjee, Margaret (2005). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=_06rcmT0b7UC&amp;pg=PA119" rel="nofollow"><i>Gandhi and the Challenge of Religious Diversity: Religious Pluralism Revisited</i></a>. Bibliophile South Asia. p. 119. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-85002-46-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-85002-46-0"><bdi>978-81-85002-46-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Gandhi+and+the+Challenge+of+Religious+Diversity%3A+Religious+Pluralism+Revisited&amp;rft.pages=119&amp;rft.pub=Bibliophile+South+Asia&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-85002-46-0&amp;rft.aulast=Chatterjee&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D_06rcmT0b7UC%26pg%3DPA119&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-247"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-247">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFiala2018">Fiala, Andrew (2018). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Y35KDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT94" rel="nofollow"><i>The Routledge Handbook of Pacifism and Nonviolence</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Routledge" title="Routledge">Routledge</a>. p. 94. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-317-27197-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-317-27197-0"><bdi>978-1-317-27197-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Routledge+Handbook+of+Pacifism+and+Nonviolence&amp;rft.pages=94&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-317-27197-0&amp;rft.aulast=Fiala&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DY35KDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPT94&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span>, Fiala quotes Ambitabh Pal, "Gandhi himself followed a strand of Hinduism that with its emphasis on service and on poetry and songs bore similarities to Sufi Islam".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ghose275-248"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ghose275_248-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ghose275_248-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ghose275_248-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ghose275_248-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGhose,_Sankar1991">Ghose, Sankar (1991). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=5l0BPnxN1h8C&amp;pg=PA275" rel="nofollow"><i>Mahatma Gandhi</i></a>. Allied Publishers. p. 275. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-7023-205-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-7023-205-6"><bdi>978-81-7023-205-6</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Mahatma+Gandhi&amp;rft.pages=275&amp;rft.pub=Allied+Publishers&amp;rft.date=1991&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-7023-205-6&amp;rft.au=Ghose%2C+Sankar&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D5l0BPnxN1h8C%26pg%3DPA275&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-249"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-249">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.mkgandhi.org/short/ev6.htm" rel="nofollow">"Returning his Medals"</a>. Bombay Sarvodaya Mandal &amp; Gandhi Research Foundation<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">16 May</span> 2021</span>. <q>When the war was declared, my personal sympathies were all with the Boers, but my loyalty to the British rule drove me to participation with the British in that war. I felt that, if I demanded rights as a British citizen, it was also my duty, as such to participate in the defence of the British Empire. so I collected together as many comrades as possible, and with very great difficulty got their services accepted as an ambulance corps.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Returning+his+Medals&amp;rft.pub=Bombay+Sarvodaya+Mandal+%26+Gandhi+Research+Foundation&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mkgandhi.org%2Fshort%2Fev6.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>
</li>

(eds.). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=McwfCgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA70" rel="nofollow"><i>The Oxford Handbook of Indian Foreign Policy</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. pp. 71–73. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-106118-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-106118-9"><bdi>978-0-19-106118-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Handbook+of+Indian+Foreign+Policy&amp;rft.pages=71-73&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-106118-9&amp;rft.au=Rahul+Sagar&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DMcwfCgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA70&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMahatma+Gandhi"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-261"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-261">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSita_Anantha_Raman2009">Sita Anantha Raman (2009). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=KwKrCQAAQBAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Women in India: A Social and Cultural History</i></a>.
